original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'vatso virājaḥ' ityṛcā pṛśnimantho jihvāyā ādi maiśradhānye mantha opya dadhimadhumiśritaṃ kṛtvā sampātyābhimantryāśnāti
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā vatsaḥ virājaḥ iti ṛcā pṛśnimanthaḥ jihvāyāḥ ādi maiśradhānye manthaḥ opya dadhi madhu miśritam kṛtvā sampātya abhimantrya aśnāti
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Abhimantrana, having ground the speckled jujube fruit with the verse The calf of Virāj, having mixed it with curd and honey, having poured the remnants, having consecrated it, he eats it.

analyzed: abhyātāna ādi uttara tantram  sarva sāmpadāni karmāṇi samāptāni
translated: The rites up to the Abhimantrana are to be performed.🔽All the rites of the Sāmpāta are completed.
In all cases, there is an option of rites.
The meaning is for all desires.

analyzed: sarva sāmpadāni putra paśu dhana dhānya prajā patnī jaya vijaya lābha lakṣmī aśva hasti nara yānā arāma grāma gṛhak pataḍāga vāpī veda pāṭha kalpa pāṭha veda artha jñāna mīmāṃsā jñāna vyākaraṇa jñāna sūtra jñāna
translated: All the rites of the Sāmpāta are for the sake of sons, cattle, wealth, grains, offspring, wife, victory, conquest, gain, prosperity, horses, elephants, vehicles, gardens, villages, houses, ponds, wells, knowledge of the Vedas, knowledge of the Kalpas, knowledge of the meaning of the Vedas, knowledge of Mīmāṃsā, knowledge of grammar, knowledge of the aphorisms,

analyzed: āvasathya agni tretāgni kāma jyotiṣṭhoma kāma satra kāma dharma artha kāma viśeṣeṣu
translated: knowledge of the domestic fire, the three fires, the desire for the Jyotiṣṭoma, the desire for the Satra, the desire for Dharma, Artha and Kāma,

analyzed: pareṣu śatruṣu uccāṭana vaśīkaraṇa gṛha kalaha utpatti vidveṣaṇa stambhana ādi jatu rasāyana dhātuvāda ādi rasa strī bhoga ādi kāma medhya vastu vṛṣabha abhicāra svastyayana āyuṣya caturaṅga bala puṣṭi devatā jñāna ādi sampadaḥ
translated: in the case of enemies, the desire for expulsion, subjugation, domestic quarrels, hatred, paralysis, the elixir of long life, alchemy, the enjoyment of women, the desire for impure things, the desire for witchcraft, benediction, longevity, the nourishment of the four-fold army, the desire for the knowledge of deities, and so on.
Thus.
The various kinds of prosperity are mentioned.
Prosperity is the attainment of what was not before.
There is no sequence of actions everywhere.
There is an option everywhere.

analyzed: phala arthinaḥ abhyāsena punar punar kriyā abhyāsena karma siddhiḥ
translated: For one who desires results, the accomplishment of action is by practice, by repeatedly performing the action.
The enumeration of desires is made because desires are infinite.

analyzed: sarva sāmpadāni iti loka aneka kāma sampad iti ucyate
translated: All kinds of prosperity are called having many kinds of prosperity.
Desiring specific wealth.
Desiring specific sons.

analyzed: kapila varṇa gaura varṇa putrāḥ evaṃvidham bhavati iti
translated: May I have sons with the color of a tawny cow or the color of a white cow.

original: karmaṇāṃ kramo'pi nāsti tantreṇa karma paṭhitam /
analyzed: karmaṇām kramaḥ upi na asti tantreṇa karma paṭhitam
translated: There is also no sequence of actions. The action is recited in a series.
The method of prosperous action is completed.
Actions for concord
We will explain the method of actions for those who are in concord.

analyzed: sahṛdayam tat u su  sam jānīdhvam
translated: With a sympathetic heart, may they be united.
Be of one mind.

analyzed: sam vaḥ pṛcyantām  sam vaḥ manāṃsi
translated: Come here.🔽May your minds be united.
May our minds be united.
Thus are the actions for concord.

original: udakulijaṃ sampātavantaṃ grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati // / / //
analyzed: uda kulijam sampātavantam grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having gone around a village with water and barley, he throws it in the middle.

original: ājyatantramabhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayaṃ sāmmanasyam' iti sūktenodakulijamudakumbhaṃ sampātya grāmapārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sahṛdayam sāmmanasyam iti sūktena uda kulijam uda kumbham sampātya grāma pārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he should besmear the water-pot with water with the verse, May there be harmony and unanimity, and having whirled it around near the village, he should pour it down in the middle.
Then the subsequent rites.

analyzed: sāmmanasya adhikāre ā varcasyebhyaḥ karmabhyaḥ yāvat
translated: The section on unanimity is up to the rites for the Varcasvins.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityṛcā kumbhaṃ sampātya grāmapārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā tat u su te iti ṛcā kumbham sampātya grāma pārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the rite, he should besmear the pot with the verse, That is yours, and having whirled it around near the village, he should pour it down in the middle.
Then the subsequent rites.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena kumbhaṃ sampātya taṃ ghaṭaṃ gṛhītvā grāmapārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena kumbham sampātya tam ghaṭam gṛhītvā grāma pārśve bhrāmayitvā madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he should besmear the pot with the verse, Be united, and having taken that pot, he should whirl it around near the village and pour it down in the middle.
The subsequent rites are from the Ājyabhāgas.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāmudakumbhaṃ sampātya grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ā iha yātu sam vaḥ pṛcyantām iti sūktābhyām uda kumbham sampātya grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he should besmear the water-pot with the two verses, Come hither and May your thoughts be united, and having carried it around the village, he should pour it down in the middle.
Then the subsequent rites.

analyzed: anena sūktena jñāti putrasya sāmmanasyam kriyate
translated: By this verse, unanimity is brought about for the son of a kinsman.
As long as they live, there is harmony among the kinsmen, among the relatives, and among the clansmen.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ vo manāṃsi' iti tisṛbhirṛgbhirudakumbhaṃ sampātya grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā sam vaḥ manāṃsi iti tisṛbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ uda kumbham sampātya grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the Tanu rite, he consecrates a water-pot with the three verses beginning with May your minds be united, and having carried it around the village, he pours it out in the middle.
The subsequent rite is as prescribed.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sañjñānaṃ naḥ' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāmudakulijaṃ sampātya grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sañjñānam naḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām uda kulijam sampātya grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya rite, he consecrates a water-pot with the two verses beginning with May we be united, and having carried it around the village, he pours it out in the middle.
Then the subsequent rite.
In the same way, with Sura and Kulīja.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayam' iti sūktena surākulijaṃ sampātitaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sahṛdayam iti sūktena surā kulijam sampātitam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed up to the Ābhyānamāna rite, having consecrated Sura and Kulīja with the hymn Sahṛdaya, he carries it around the village and pours it out in the middle.
Then the subsequent rite.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityṛcā surākulijaṃ sampātitaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā tat u su te iti ṛcā surā kulijam sampātitam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed up to the Ābhyānamāna rite, having consecrated Sura and Kulīja with the verse Tadū ṣu te, he carries it around the village and pours it out in the middle.
Then the subsequent rite.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena surākulijaṃ sampātitaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena surā kulijam sampātitam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed up to the Ābhyānamāna rite, having consecrated Sura and Kulīja with the hymn Saṃ jānīdhvam, he carries it around the village and pours it out in the middle.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāṃ surākulijaṃ sampātavantaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ā iha yātu sam vaḥ pṛcyantām iti sūktābhyām surā kulijam sampātavantam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed up to the Ājyabhāgas, having prepared the Sura and Kulmāṣa along with the remnants of the oblations with the two hymns Come hither and May your minds be united, he carries it around the village and pours it in the middle.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ vo manāṃsi' iti tisṛbhirṛgbhiḥ surākulijaṃ
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sam vaḥ manāṃsi iti tisṛbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ surā kulijam
translated: Having performed up to the Ājyabhāgas, having prepared the Sura and Kulmāṣa along with the remnants of the oblations with the three verses beginning May your minds be united,

original: sampātavantaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: sampātavantam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: he carries it around the village and pours it in the middle.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sañjñānaṃ naḥ' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāṃ surākulijaṃ sampātavantaṃ kṛtvā grāmaṃ parihṛtya madhye ninayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sañjñānam naḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām surā kulijam sampātavantam kṛtvā grāmam parihṛtya madhye ninayati
translated: Having performed the Ājy upacara, having prepared the Sura and Kulmāṣa along with the remnants of the oblations with the two verses beginning May we be united, he carries it around the village and pours it in the middle.

analyzed: tatas uttara tantram  trihāyaṇyāḥ vatsataryāḥ śuktāni piśitāni āśayati
translated: Then the subsequent ritual.🔽He places the white and raw flesh of a three-year-old heifer.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayam' iti sūktena trivarṣavatsikāyāḥ śuktāni piśitāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sahṛdayam iti sūktena tri varṣa vatsikāyāḥ śuktāni piśitāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed up to the Ājyabhāgas, he consecrates the white and raw flesh of a three-year-old heifer with the Sāmidhenī verses, and then with the hymn With a friendly mind, he places it after consecrating it with the remnants of the oblations.
The subsequent ritual is as before.

original: ājyatantramabhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityṛcāmlena rasena siktāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram abhyātāna antam kṛtvā tat u su te iti ṛcā amlena rasena siktāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajy upacara rites down to the Abhyarana, he consecrates the meat sprinkled with the juice of sour substances with the Rk verse beginning with Tadūṣu te.
The subsequent rites are as before.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena śuktāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena śuktāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he consecrates the sour meat with the Sukta beginning with Sam jānīdhvam.
Then the subsequent rites.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāṃ traihāyaṇyā vatsataryāḥ śuktāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā ā iha yātu sam vaḥ pṛcyantām iti sūktābhyām traihāyaṇyāḥ vatsataryāḥ śuktāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya rites, he consecrates the sour meat of a three-year-old heifer with the two Suktas beginning with Eha yātu and Sam vo 'priyantaṃ.
Then the subsequent rites.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ vo manāṃsi' iti sūktena śuktāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sam vaḥ manāṃsi iti sūktena śuktāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya rites, he consecrates the sour meat with the Sukta beginning with Sam vo manāṃsi.
The subsequent rites.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sañjñānaṃ naḥ' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāṃ traihāyaṇyā vatsataryā śuktāni māṃsāni sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sañjñānam naḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām traihāyaṇyā vatsataryā śuktāni māṃsāni sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya rites, he consecrates the sour meat of a three-year-old heifer with the two Ṛks beginning with Sañjñānaṃ naḥ.
Then the subsequent rites.
He consecrates the cooked food, wine, and well with the Sampāta.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayam' iti sūktena bhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sahṛdayam iti sūktena bhaktam sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya Tantra, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the Sukta beginning with Sahṛdayam, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
Then the subsequent Tantra.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityekayā bhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā tat u su te iti ekayā bhaktam sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Tantra, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the one verse beginning with Tadūṣu te, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
Then the subsequent Tantra.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena bhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena bhaktam sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Ajya Tantra, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the Sukta beginning with Sam jānīdhvam, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
The subsequent Tantra is from the Abhimantrana.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāṃ bhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /

translated: Having performed the Tantra, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the two Suktas beginning with Eha yātu and Sam vo 'pṛcyantām, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
The subsequent Tantra is from the Abhimantrana.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ vo manāṃsi' iti tisṛbhirṛgbhibhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sam vaḥ manāṃsi iti tisṛbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ bhaktam sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed up to the Abhimantrana, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the three verses beginning with Sam vo manāṃsi, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
Then the subsequent Tantra.

original: vedyāditantraṃ kṛtvā 'sañjñānaṃ naḥ' iti dvābhyāṃ bhaktaṃ sampātyābhimantryāśayati /
analyzed: vedya ādi tantram kṛtvā sañjñānam naḥ iti dvābhyām bhaktam sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Having performed the Tantra beginning with the altar, he causes the food to be sprinkled with the two verses beginning with Sañjñānam naḥ, recites over it, and makes it eaten.
Then the subsequent Tantra.
The Brahmana Tarpaṇa.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayam' iti sūktena surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sahṛdayam iti sūktena surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the Sukta Sahṛdayam.
For men who are in agreement, belonging to the three social classes.
The subsequent rites are the same as before.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityekayā surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā tat u su te iti ekayā surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites in the Ājya, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the one verse Tadūṣu te.
The subsequent rites are the same as before.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the Sukta Saṃ jānīdhvam,
The subsequent rites are the same as before.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāṃ surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ā iha yātu sam vaḥ pṛcyantām iti sūktābhyām surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the two Suktas Eha yātu and Saṃ vo mṛḍātām,
The subsequent rites are the same as before.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ vo manāṃsi' iti tṛcena sūktena surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sam vaḥ manāṃsi iti tṛcena sūktena surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites in the Ājya, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the three verses Saṃ vo manāṃsi,
The subsequent rites are the same as before.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sañjñānaṃ naḥ' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāṃ surāṃ sampātyābhimantrya prayacchati /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sañjñānam naḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām surām sampātya abhimantrya prayacchati
translated: Having performed the rites in the Ājya, he consecrates and gives Sura, having caused it to be sprinkled with the two Ṛiks Saṃjñānaṃ naḥ,
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'sahṛdayam' iti sūktena prapodakaṃ sampātyābhimantrya pāyayet /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sahṛdayam iti sūktena prapodakam sampātya abhimantrya pāyayet
translated: Having performed the Ajya ritual, one should consecrate and make the patient drink the Prāpoḍaka, reciting the Sūkta beginning with Sahṛdayam.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'tadū ṣu te' ityekayā prapodakaṃ sampātyābhimantrya pāyayet /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā tat u su te iti ekayā prapodakam sampātya abhimantrya pāyayet
translated: Having performed the Ajya ritual, one should consecrate and make the patient drink the Prāpoḍaka, reciting the single verse Tadū ṣu te.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ājyatantraṃ kṛtvā 'saṃ jānīdhvam' iti sūktena prapodakaṃ sampātyābhimantrya pāyayet /
analyzed: ājya tantram kṛtvā sam jānīdhvam iti sūktena prapodakam sampātya abhimantrya pāyayet
translated: Having performed the Ajya ritual, one should consecrate and make the patient drink the Prāpoḍaka, reciting the Sūkta beginning with Saṃ jānīdhvam.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'eha yātu' 'saṃ vaḥ pṛcyantām' iti sūktābhyāṃ prapodakaṃ sampātyābhimantrya pāyayet /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ā iha yātu sam vaḥ pṛcyantām iti sūktābhyām prapodakam sampātya abhimantrya pāyayet

analyzed: tatas ājyena uttara tantram  pradāna antāni vāpyāni
translated: Then the subsequent Tantra with ghee.🔽Or the Āpyas ending with the offerings.

analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena saktūn juhoti
translated: Having performed up to the Ābhyāsana, he offers the barley grains with the Anuvāka beginning with The arms that rise up...
Then the subsequent Tantra for the battle.

original: sāṅgrāmikaṃ tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena dhanuridhme'gnau pṛṣadājyenāktā dhanuḥsamidha ādadhāti /
analyzed: sāṅgrāmikam tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena dhanuḥ idhma ignau pṛṣadājyena aktāḥ dhanuḥ samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: Having performed the Tantra for the battle, he offers the bow-kindling sticks smeared with speckled ghee in the fire on the bow-kindling with the Anuvāka beginning with The arms that rise up...
Then the subsequent Tantra.

original: pūrvatantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākeneṣvidhme'gnau pṛṣadājyenāktā iṣusamidha ādadhāti /
analyzed: pūrva tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena iṣu idhma ignau pṛṣadājyena aktāḥ iṣu samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: Having performed the previous Tantra, he offers the arrow-kindling sticks smeared with speckled ghee in the fire on the arrow-kindling with the Anuvāka beginning with The arms that rise up...
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ājyena pūrvatantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena pṛṣadājyena dhanuḥ sampātyābhimantrya vimṛjya yoddhre prayacchati /
analyzed: ājyena pūrva tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena pṛṣadājyena dhanuḥ sampātya abhimantrya vimṛjya yoddhre prayacchati
translated: Having performed the prior ritual with ghee, he consecrates the bow with the Pṛṣadājya by reciting the Anuvāka beginning with Ye bāhvaḥ, wipes it, and gives it to the warrior.
Then the subsequent ritual with ghee.

original: ājyena pūrvatantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena bhāṅgapāśān pṛṣadājyena sampātya kruddho'bhimantrya senākrameṣu vapati /
analyzed: ājyena pūrva tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena bhāṅga pāśān pṛṣadājyena sampātya senā krameṣu vapati
translated: Having performed the prior ritual with ghee, he consecrates the Bhāṅga nooses with the Pṛṣadājya by reciting the Anuvāka beginning with Ye bāhvaḥ, recites the mantra while angry, and casts them into the army's path.
Then the subsequent ritual with ghee.

original: sarvatra pāśeṣu āśvattheṣu kūṭeṣu bhāṅgeṣu jāleṣu bādhakadaṇḍeṣu vajrarūpeṣu pātreṣu ca iṅgiḍālaṅkaraṇaṃ kruddhābhimantraṇaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: sarvatra pāśeṣu āśvattheṣu kūṭeṣu bhāṅgeṣu jāleṣu bādhaka daṇḍeṣu vajra rūpeṣu pātreṣu ca iṅgiḍa alaṅkaraṇam kruddha abhimantraṇam kuryāt
translated: In all the nooses, in the Aśvattha nooses, in the Kūṭa nooses, in the Bhāṅga nooses, in the Jāla nooses, in the Bādhaka staff nooses, in the Vajrarūpa vessels, and in the Pañcaka vessels, one should perform the angry recitation and consecration with the Iṅgiḍa ornament.

original: ājyena tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena mauñjapāśān pṛṣadājyena sampātyābhimantrya senākrameṣu vapati /
analyzed: ājyena tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena mauñja pāśān pṛṣadājyena sampātya abhimantrya senā krameṣu vapati
translated: Having performed the prior ritual with ghee, he consecrates the Muñja nooses with the Pṛṣadājya by reciting the Anuvāka beginning with Ye bāhvaḥ, recites the mantra, and casts them into the army's path.
The subsequent ritual with ghee.

original: ājyena tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena āmapātrāṇi pṛṣadājyena sampātyābhimantrya senāyuddhasthāne vapati /
analyzed: ājyena tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena āma pātrāṇi pṛṣadājyena sampātya abhimantrya senā yuddha sthāne vapati
translated: Having performed the prior ritual with ghee, he consecrates the raw vessels with the Pṛṣadājya by reciting the Anuvāka beginning with Ye bāhvaḥ, recites the mantra, and casts them into the place of the army's battle.
The subsequent rite is with clarified butter.

analyzed: vāpyaiḥ tri sandhīni vajra rūpāṇi arbudi rūpāṇi
translated: With the Vāpīs, the three-jointed iron forms, the Arbudi forms,

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena triṣandhīni lohamayāni sampātyābhimantrya senākrameṣu vapati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena tri sandhīni loha mayāni sampātya abhimantrya senā krameṣu vapati
translated: Having performed the rite, with the Anuvāka Ye bāhvaḥ, he strikes the three-jointed iron ones, consecrates them, and throws them into the army's path.
The subsequent rite.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena vajrarūpāṇi sampātyābhimantrya senākrameṣu vapati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena vajra rūpāṇi sampātya abhimantrya senā krameṣu vapati
translated: Having performed the rite, with the Anuvāka Ye bāhvaḥ, he strikes the iron forms, consecrates them, and throws them into the army's path.
Then the subsequent rite.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena vajrarūpāṇi lohamayāni arbudirūpāṇi sampātyābhimantrya senākrameṣu vapati /
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena vajra rūpāṇi loha mayāni arbudi rūpāṇi sampātya abhimantrya senā krameṣu vapati
translated: Having performed the rite, with the Anuvāka Ye bāhvaḥ, he strikes the iron forms, the three-jointed iron forms, the Arbudi forms, consecrates them, and throws them into the army's path.
Then the subsequent rite.

analyzed: śitipadīm sampātavatīm darbha rajjvā kṣatriyāya upāsaṅga daṇḍe badhnāti
translated: He ties a black-footed ewe, which has been struck, with a darbha rope, to the yoke-pin of a Kṣatriya.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena śitipadīm ajāṃ pṛṣadājyena sampātyābhimantrya rājñe darbharajjvā upāsaṅgadaṇḍe badhnāti /🔽ājyenottaratantram //
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena śitipadīm ajām pṛṣadājyena sampātya abhimantrya rājñe darbha rajjvā upāsaṅga daṇḍe badhnāti  ājyena uttara tantram
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ājyabhāgas, he strikes a black-footed ewe with Pṛṣadājya, consecrates it with the Anuvāka Ye bāhvaḥ, and ties it to the yoke-pin of the king with a darbha rope.🔽The subsequent rite is with clarified butter.
He throws a second one.

original: sāṅgrāmikaṃ tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ye bāhavaḥ' ityanuvākena dvitīyāṃ śitipadīṃ sampātyābhimantrya śatrusenāṃ prakṣipati /
analyzed: sāṅgrāmikam tantram kṛtvā ye bāhavaḥ iti anuvākena dvitīyām śitipadīm sampātya abhimantrya śatru senām prakṣipati
translated: Having performed the Saṅgrāma Tantra, he throws the second Śitipadī, having consecrated it with the Anuvāka beginning with Ye bāhvaḥ, into the enemy's army.
The Uttaratantrā is with clarified butter.
Then, the release of the army fire.
And the Avabhṛtha.
Having conquered the enemy, he performs the completion of the rite.
In all cases, there is an option of rites.
The Saṅgrāma rites are complete.

analyzed: śiti padyoḥ dvayoḥ api ekam karma
translated: For the two Śitipadīs, there is only one rite.
Elsewhere, there is an option.
By this rite, victory is certainly obtained.

analyzed: atha rāṣṭra praveśa abhigamana karma vidhim vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Now we will explain the rite for entering and approaching the kingdom.
In this, Vasu. Thus, entering the kingdom.

original: svarāṣṭre yo niṣkrāntaḥ śatruṇā punaḥ praveśamicchati tasyedaṃ karma //
analyzed: sva rāṣṭre yaḥ niṣkrāntaḥ śatruṇā punar praveśam icchati tasya idam karma
translated: This rite is for one who has left his own kingdom and desires to re-enter it with the enemy.

analyzed: ānuśūkānām vrīhīṇām āvraska jaiḥ kāmpīlaiḥ śṛtam sārūpavat samāśayati
translated: He makes the cow with a calf of the same color eat Vrīhi rice of the Anūṣukā variety cooked with the Avraṣka and Kāmpīla plants.

original: ājyatantramabhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'asmin vasu' iti sūktenānuśūkānāṃ vrīhīṇāmāvraskajaiḥ kāmpīlaiḥ śṛtaṃ sārūpavatsamodanaṃ sampātyābhimantrya
analyzed: ājya tantram abhyātāna antam kṛtvā asmin vasu iti sūktena anuśūkānām vrīhīṇām āvraska jaiḥ kāmpīlaiḥ śṛtam sārūpavat samodanam sampātya abhimantrya
translated: Having performed the Ajyataantra up to the Abhyarana, with the Sukta In this wealth, he consecrates the rice of the Anushuka variety, cooked with the Avraska Kampeeka grains, together with the Sarupavat rice, with the remnants.

analyzed: abhyātāna ādi uttara tantram  rāṣṭre yaḥ udvāsitaḥ tasya idam karma praveśa artham
translated: The Abhyarana and the subsequent rites.🔽This rite is for the king who has been expelled from his kingdom, for the purpose of re-entry.

analyzed: anena karmaṇā sva rāṣṭra praveśaḥ bhavati
translated: By this rite, he regains his own kingdom.

original: sarvasyāṃ marditāyāṃ bhūmau yadā niṣkrānto rājā tadedaṃ karma karoti /
analyzed: sarvasyām marditāyām bhūmau yadā niṣkrāntaḥ rājā tadā idam karma karoti
translated: When the entire earth has been conquered, and the king has gone out, then he performs this rite.

analyzed: rāṣṭra praveśana kāmaḥ  ānuśūkālanāḥ vrīhayaḥ punar utthitāḥ
translated: One who desires to enter the kingdom.🔽The rice of the Anushuka variety is grown again.
Those which are cut and grow again are the Avraskas.
With the Abhivarta.

analyzed: iti ratha nemi maṇi mayaḥ sīsa loha rajata tāmra veṣṭitam hema nābhim vāsitam baddhvā
translated: Thus, having made a golden navel covered with a chariot wheel, a gem, a stone, iron, silver, copper, and gold, having perfumed it, having tied it,

original: sūtrotaṃ barhiṣi kṛtvā sampātavantaṃ pratyṛcaṃ bhṛṣṭīrabhīvartottamābhyāmācṛtati // / / //
analyzed: sūtra ūtam barhiṣi kṛtvā sampātavantam pratyṛcam bhṛṣṭīḥ abhīvarta uttamābhyām ācṛtati
translated: having wound it with a thread on the sacrificial grass, having consecrated it, he offers the burnt rice with the Abhivarta, with the last two verses of the Rikas.

analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā abhīvartena iti caturbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ ratha cakra nemi maṇi mayaḥ sīsa loha rajata tāmra veṣṭitam
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Abhimantrana, with the four verses beginning with Abhivṛte, having made a golden navel covered with the rim of a chariot wheel, gems, lead, iron, silver, and copper,

original: hemanābhiṃ trirvāsitaṃ kṛtvā sūtrotaṃ barhiṣi kṛtvā pratyṛcaṃ sampātyābhimantrya🔽'udasau sūryaḥ' / /
analyzed: hema nābhim tris vāsitam kṛtvā sūtra ūtam barhiṣi kṛtvā pratyṛcam sampātya abhimantrya  udasau sūryaḥ
translated: having thrice perfumed it, having woven it with a thread on sacrificial grass, having sprinkled it with water over each verse, having enchanted it,🔽with the two verses beginning Udasau sūryaḥ,
he ties it.

original: tata uttaratantram /🔽atikrānta ardhamardite rāṣṭra idaṃ karma /
analyzed: tatas uttara tantram  atikrānte ardha mardite rāṣṭre idam karma
translated: Then the subsequent procedure.🔽This rite is to be performed when half of the kingdom has been conquered and trampled.

analyzed: anena karmaṇā rāṣṭra vṛddhiḥ ca bhavati
translated: By this rite, the kingdom becomes prosperous.
He has roared. Come to you.

original: iti yasmādrāṣṭrādavaruddhastasyāśāyāṃ śayanavidhaṃ puroḍāśaṃ darbheṣūdake ninayati // / / //
analyzed: iti yasmāt rāṣṭrāt avaruddhaḥ tasya āśāyām śayana vidham puroḍāśam darbheṣu udake ninayati
translated: With these two verses, he pours into water on darbha grass a cake shaped like a bed from the direction from which the kingdom has been conquered.

analyzed: tatas loṣṭena jyotiḥ āyatanam saṃstīrya kṣīra odanam aśnāti
translated: Then, having covered the abode of light with a clod, he eats rice boiled in milk.

original: 'acikradad' / 'ā tvā gan' iti sūktābhyāṃ śayanākāraṃ puroḍāśamabhimantrya darbheṣūdake ninayati /
analyzed: acikradat ā tvā gan iti sūktābhyām śayana ākāram puroḍāśam abhimantrya darbheṣu udake ninayati
translated: He has roared. Come to you. With these two hymns, he enchants a cake shaped like a bed and pours it into water on darbha grass.
Then he should fill it with a clod.
In place of darbha grass, there is the covering with clay.
Having performed the rites up to the Abhyatāna, with the two hymns beginning with 'He has roared'

original: 'ā tvā gan' iti sūktābhyāṃ kṣīraudanaṃ sthālīpākaṃ sampātyābhimantrya rājānamāśayati /
analyzed: ā tvā gan iti sūktābhyām kṣīraudanam sthālīpākam sampātya abhimantrya rājānam āśayati
translated: and 'Come to you', he consecrates the king with milk-rice cooked in a pot, having consecrated it with the two hymns.
Then the subsequent rites.
From where the clod is, from there the materials are collected.

analyzed: tasmāt sthānāt sambhāra āharaṇam yasmāt niṣkrāntaḥ rājā
translated: From that place the collection of materials is brought, from which the king has gone out.
They invite the king for the three morning-eaten cakes.

original: tisṛṇāṃ prātaraśite puroḍāśe bhakṣite punaratra rāṣṭre rājā praveśaṃ labhate /
analyzed: tisṛṇām prātar aśite puroḍāśe bhakṣite punar atra rāṣṭre rājā praveśam labhate
translated: When the three morning-eaten cakes have been eaten, the king again obtains entry into the kingdom here.
This is for the purpose of knowing the rite of the cakes.
The rites for entering one's own kingdom are complete.
Entry is definitely made.

original: bhayaṃ vā mṛtyurvā vighnaṃ daivopaghāto vā śatrorbhavati /
analyzed: bhayam vā mṛtyuḥ vā vighnam daiva upaghātaḥ vā śatroḥ bhavati
translated: Or fear, or death, or an obstacle, or harm from fate, occurs to the enemy.
The meaning is that entry is definitely made.
Only the king's rites are performed.
The rite of entering one's own kingdom is complete.
The seventh section is concluded.
Now the rite of light consecration is described.
The being in beings.

analyzed: iti rājānam abhiṣekṣyan mahānade śāntyudakam karoti ādiṣṭānām
translated: Thus, when about to consecrate the king, he performs the great river peace water rite for the appointed ones.

analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā śāntyudaka vidhānena śāntyudakam karoti
translated: Having performed up to the Abhyarana, he performs the peace water rite according to the procedure for peace water.

original: mahānadyā udakaṃ vanapuṣkariṇīnāmudakaṃ devavṛṣṭyudakaṃ divyamudakaṃ ca /
analyzed: mahā nadyāḥ udakam vana puṣkariṇīnām udakam deva vṛṣṭi udakam divyam udakam ca
translated: The water of the great river, the water of the forest ponds, the water of divine rain, and the divine water.

analyzed: udakānām vikalpaḥ samuccayaḥ vā śāntyudakam ādiṣṭānām
translated: The waters are optional or cumulative for the peace water for the appointed ones.

original: sthālīpākaṃ śrapayitvā dakṣiṇataḥ parigṛhyāyā darbheṣu tiṣṭhantamabhiṣiñcati // / / //
analyzed: sthālīpākam śrapayitvā dakṣiṇatas parigṛhyāyāḥ darbheṣu tiṣṭhantam abhiṣiñcati
translated: Having cooked the Sthalipaka, having taken it to the south, he consecrates the king standing on the Darbha grass.

analyzed: tatas carum śrapayati nadyā udakena samudra udakena vā
translated: Then he cooks the Charu with river water or ocean water.

original: vedyā dakṣiṇataḥ darbhānāstīrya tatroparyūrdhvaṃ sthitaṃ rājānaṃ 'bhūto bhūteṣu' iti sūktena śāntyudakakalaśamabhimantrya purodhā rājānamabhiṣiñcati
analyzed: vedyāḥ dakṣiṇatas darbhān āstīrya tatra upari ūrdhvam sthitam rājānam bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu iti sūktena śāntyudaka kalaśam abhimantrya purodhāḥ rājānam abhiṣiñcati
translated: Having spread Darbha grass to the south of the altar, he consecrates the king standing above it with the Sukta Bhūta bhūteṣu while reciting the peace water pot.
He makes him ascend the bull's hide.
The consecrated one has bathed.

original: khaṭvāyāmārṣabhaṃ carmāstīrya tatra rājānamārohayati 'bhūto bhūteṣu' iti sūktena //
analyzed: khaṭvāyām ārṣabham carma āstīrya tatra rājānam ārohayati bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu iti sūktena
translated: Having spread the bull's hide on the bed, he makes the king ascend it with the Sukta Bhūta bhūteṣu.
They sprinkle the water-pot together.
They exchange (the water-pots).

analyzed: uda pātram ubhau api āsiñcataḥ dhārāyāḥ udakena
translated: They both sprinkle the water-pot with the stream of water.

original: sahaiva nau sukṛtaṃ saha duṣkṛtam iti brahmā brūyāt // / / //
analyzed: saha eva nau sukṛtam saha duṣkṛtam iti brahmā brūyāt
translated: Brahman should say, 'May our good deeds be together, and our evil deeds.'

original: yo duṣkṛtaṃ karavattasya duṣkṛtaṃ sukṛtaṃ nau saha iti // / / //
analyzed: yaḥ duṣkṛtam karavat tasya duṣkṛtam sukṛtam nau sahaḥ iti
translated: 'The evil deeds of him who does evil deeds, and our good deeds be together,' (should be said by the king).

analyzed: saha eva naḥ iti rājā brūte
translated: The king says, 'May our good deeds be together.'
Brahman should say, 'The evil deeds of him who does evil deeds.'
He deposits (the water-pot).

original: tataḥ sthālīpākaṃ 'bhūto bhūteṣu' iti sūktena sampātyābhimantryāśayati //
analyzed: tatas sthālīpākam bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu iti sūktena sampātya abhimantrya āśayati
translated: Then he consecrates the Sthâlîpâka with the Sûkta 'Bhûto bhûteṣu' , and deposits it.
Having made the horse ascend, he makes it go to the Aparâjitâ (the unconquered).

analyzed: tatas ūśvam ārohayati bhūtaḥ bhūteṣu iti sūktena
translated: Then he makes the horse ascend with the Sûkta 'Bhûto bhûteṣu.'
He makes it go to the Aparâjitâ.

analyzed: vāhena upaniṣkramya punar gṛhe āgatya abhyātāna ādi uttara tantram  sahasram grāma varaḥ dakṣiṇā
translated: Having gone out with the Vâha, he again comes to the house. The Abhyâtâna and the subsequent ritual (are performed).🔽A thousand (cows) and the best village are the sacrificial fee.

analyzed: sahasram gavām dakṣiṇā grāma varaḥ ca
translated: A thousand cows and the best village are the sacrificial fee.
The consecration is finished.
The ritual up to the exchange (of the water-pots) has been explained by (the performance of) one king.

original: māṇḍalikasya sāmantasya yuvarājasya senāpateranyasya kasyacidabhiṣekaḥ anena vidhānena kāryaḥ /
analyzed: māṇḍalikasya sāmantasya yuvarājasya senāpateḥ anyasya kasyacid abhiṣekaḥ anena vidhānena kāryaḥ
translated: The consecration of a provincial king, a neighboring king, a prince, a general, or anyone else should be done according to this procedure.

analyzed: tasya api purohita varaṇe kṛte sati abhiṣekaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: Even for him, after the selection of the priest is done, the consecration should be performed.

original: abhiṣekādanantaraṃ ghṛtāvekṣaṇamārātrikaṃ rājakarmāṇi piṣṭarātryādīni pratyahaṃ kartavyāni /
analyzed: abhiṣekāt anantaram ghṛta avekṣaṇam ārātrikam rāja karmāṇi piṣṭa rātri ādīni pratyaham kartavyāni
translated: After the consecration, the examination of ghee, the night-long vigil, royal duties, and the night-long feast with ground flour etc. should be performed daily.
According to the procedure, he gives all the gifts.

analyzed: puṣpa abhiṣeka mahānavamī indrotsava vṛṣotsarga janmadina ādi prativarṣam kāryāṇi
translated: The flower consecration, the great ninth day, the Indra festival, the bull release, the birthday etc. should be performed every year.
The consecration of the universal monarch is described.
We will explain the procedure for the great consecration.
He consecrates on a bed of darbha grass.
It is for the universal monarch.

analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā tatas śāntyudakam karoti
translated: Having performed up to the abhyanjana, he then performs the śānti water.

original: caturṇāṃ sāgarāṇāṃ tu mahānadīnāṃ śatasya ca /
analyzed: caturṇām sāgarāṇām tu mahā nadīnām śatasya ca

translated: Having gone to the field, he ties the plough and the ploughshare with the hymn They yoke the ploughs.
He first yokes the right ploughshare.

original: 'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktena yugasya dakṣiṇato vṛṣabhaṃ yunakti //
analyzed: sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena yugasya dakṣiṇatas vṛṣabham yunakti
translated: With the Sûkta, 'They yoke the ploughs,' he yokes a bull to the right of the yoke.
'Come, O full one,' the next (verse).

original: 'ehi pūrṇaka' iti mantreṇa uttarato dvitīyaṃ vṛṣabhaṃ yunakti //
analyzed: ehi pūrṇakaḥ iti mantreṇa uttaratas dvitīyam vṛṣabham yunakti
translated: With the Mantra, 'Come, O full one,' he yokes a second bull to the left (of the yoke).
The ploughmen (the other oxen) (he yokes) with the other (verse).
'May the ploughmen follow the beasts of burden.'

original: iti pādena hāliko'nyān caturo vṛṣabhān yunakti /
analyzed: iti pādena hālikonyān caturaḥ vṛṣabhān yunakti
translated: With this quarter-verse the ploughman yokes the other four bulls.
Because it is said, 'The plough consists of six parts.'
'May the two Asvins make the plough ready, may Brihaspati protect it.

analyzed: yathā asat bahu dhānyam ayakṣmam bahu pūruṣam iti phālam atikarṣati
translated: That it may be full of much grain, free from disease, and full of many men,' thus he ploughs over the ploughshare.

original: irāvānasi dhārtarāṣṭre tava me sattre rādhyatām iti pratimimīte // / / //🔽apahatāḥ pratiṣṭhāḥ ityapūpaiḥ pratihatya kṛṣati // / / //
analyzed: irāvān asi dhārtarāṣṭre tava me sattre rādhyatām iti pratimimīte  apahatāḥ pratiṣṭhāḥ iti apūpaiḥ pratihatya kṛṣati
translated: 'Thou art full of food, O son of Dhritarashtra; may thy sacrifice be successful for me,' thus he measures (the ground).🔽'The standing (plants) are destroyed,' thus he ploughs, having struck (the ground) with cakes.

analyzed: aśvinā phālam iti ṛcā loha phālam abhimantrya hale pratikarṣati
translated: Having recited over the iron ploughshare the verse, 'The two Asvins,' he draws it over the plough.

analyzed: irāvān asi iti mantreṇa phālam abhimantrayate
translated: With the Mantra, 'Thou art full of food,' he recites over the ploughshare.

analyzed: apahatāḥ iti mantreṇa apūpān abhimantrya hale phāla mukhe dadāti
translated: Having recited the mantra Aphata over the cakes, he gives them to the plough in front of the ploughshare.

original: tataḥ 'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktena kartā halena kṛṣati //
analyzed: tatas sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena kartā halena kṛṣati
translated: Then with the hymn Sira yunajanti the performer ploughs with the plough.
Having reached the end of the hymn, he gives (the plough to the ploughman).

original: sūktaṃ samāpya tato halaṃ hālikāya prayacchati //
analyzed: sūktam samāpya tatas halam hālikāya prayacchati
translated: Having completed the hymn, he then gives the plough to the ploughman.

analyzed: tisraḥ sītāḥ prācīḥ gamayanti kalyāṇīḥ vācaḥ vadantaḥ
translated: Three furrows are ploughed eastwards, while they utter auspicious words.
The ploughman ploughs three furrows eastwards.

analyzed: kalyāṇīḥ vācaḥ vadantaḥ puṇya aha ādīni ca
translated: While uttering auspicious words and (reciting) the auspicious days etc.
We pay homage to you, O furrow.

analyzed: iti āvartayitvā uttarasmin sītā ante puroḍāśena indram yajate
translated: Having recited this, he offers to Indra in the northern furrow with a cake.

analyzed: sīte vandāmahe tvā iti ṛcā kartā anumantrayate
translated: The performer recites the verse We pay homage to you, O furrow.
The mantra is repeated three times.
Having done it at the end of the northern furrow.

original: tatrājyabhāgāntaṃ pākatantraṃ kṛtvā🔽'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktenendradaivatyaṃ puroḍāśaṃ juhoti /
analyzed: tatra ājyabhāga antam pāka tantram kṛtvā  sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena indra daivatyam puroḍāśam juhoti
translated: Having performed the rites of cooking up to the offering of ghee there,🔽he offers a cake sacred to Indra with the hymn They yoke the ploughs.

original: indradevatāke puroḍāśe carudharmā aviruddhāḥ puroḍāśasya sarve bhavanti //
analyzed: indra devatāke puroḍāśe caru dharmāḥ a viruddhāḥ puroḍāśasya sarve bhavanti
translated: All the rites of the cooked rice are applicable to the cake offered to Indra without any contradiction.
The two Asvins with a Sthâlîpâka.

original: aśvinādevatākaṃ caruṃ 'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktena juhoti //
analyzed: aśvinā devatākam carum sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena juhoti
translated: He sacrifices a mess of boiled rice sacred to the two Asvins with the Sûkta, 'They yoke the ploughs' .
They bring the Sîmantonnayana (oblations) into the Sîtâ .

original: tataḥ abhyātānāni hutvā 'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktenottarasyāṃ sītāyāṃ sampātānānayati //
analyzed: tatas abhyātānāni hutvā sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena uttarasyām sītāyām sampātān ānayati
translated: Then having performed the Abhyâtâna oblations, he brings the Sîmantonnayana (oblations) into the northern Sîtâ with the Sûkta, 'They yoke the ploughs' .

analyzed: uda pātre uttarān  śaṣpa haviṣām avadhāya
translated: The northern (oblations) into the water-pot.🔽Having put the oblations of grass into the fire,
he brings the northern Sîmantonnayana (oblations) into the water-pot.

original: tata udapātre havīṃṣi śaṣpaṃ vrīhīn virūḍhaṃ ca nidadhāti //
analyzed: tatas uda pātre havīṃṣi śaṣpam vrīhīn virūḍham ca nidadhāti
translated: Then he puts the oblations, the grass, the ripe rice, and the (cake) into the water-pot.
He anoints everything.
With that water he anoints the plough everywhere.

original: yatra sampātānānayati tato loṣṭaṃ dhārayantaṃ patnī pṛcchati akṛkṣata iti // / / //
analyzed: yatra sampātān ānayati tatas loṣṭam dhārayantam patnī pṛcchati akṛkṣata iti
translated: Where he brings the Sîmantonnayana (oblations), there the wife, holding a clod, asks, 'Have they ploughed?'
'They have ploughed,' (is the answer).
'What have they brought?'

original: vittiṃ bhūtiṃ puṣṭiṃ prajāṃ paśūnannamannādyam iti // / / //
analyzed: vittim bhūtim puṣṭim prajām paśūn annam annādyam iti
translated: 'Wealth, prosperity, increase, offspring, cattle, food, and food-supply.'

original: yatra sītā sampātitā tasmāt sthānāt mṛttikāṃ patnī gṛhṇāti hastena /
analyzed: yatra sītā sampātitā tasmāt sthānāt mṛttikām patnī gṛhṇāti hastena
translated: From that place where the Sîtâ has been ploughed, the wife takes with her hand some earth.

analyzed: tata anyaḥ manuṣyaḥ pṛcchati kim āhārṣīḥ
translated: Then another man asks, 'What have they brought?'

analyzed: tatas patnī brūte vittim bhūtim iti
translated: Then the wife says, 'May there be prosperity, not misfortune.'
To the north, he pours (the earth) into the middle one.

original: tato madhyamāyāṃ sītāyāṃ mṛttikāṃ nidadhāti patnī tūṣṇīm //
analyzed: tatas madhyamāyām sītāyām mṛttikām nidadhāti patnī tūṣṇīm
translated: Then, on the middle furrow, the wife silently puts earth.

analyzed: abhyajya uttara phālam prātar āyojanāya nidadhāti
translated: He anoints the upper part of the plough with ghee and places it for the morning ploughing.

original: tato lohaphālaṃ ghṛtenābhyajya tatraiva kṣetre nidadhāti tato'bhyātānādyuttaratantram //🔽sītāśiraḥsu darbhānāstīrya plakṣodumbarasya trīṃstrīṃścamasān nidadhāti // / / //
analyzed: tatas loha phālam ghṛtena abhyajya tatra eva kṣetre nidadhāti tatas abhyātāna ādi uttara tantram  sītā śiraḥsu darbhān āstīrya plakṣa udumbarasya trīn trīn camasān nidadhāti
translated: Then, having anointed the iron ploughshare with ghee, he places it in the same field. Then, the Abhijit and other rites follow.🔽Having spread Darbha grass on the heads of the furrows, he places three each of the sacrificial ladles of Plakṣa and Udumbara wood.

original: tataḥ sītāśiraḥsu darbhānāstīrya darbhopari plakṣacamasānaudumbaracamasāṃstrīṃstrīn nidadhāti //
analyzed: tatas sītā śiraḥsu darbhān āstīrya darbha upari plakṣa camasān audumbara camasān trīn trīn nidadhāti
translated: Then, having spread Darbha grass on the heads of the furrows, he places three each of the Plakṣa ladles and Udumbara ladles on the Darbha grass.

original: rasavato dakṣiṇe śaṣpavato madhyame puroḍāśavata uttare // / / //
analyzed: rasavataḥ dakṣiṇe śaṣpavataḥ madhyame puroḍāśavataḥ uttare
translated: The one full of juice on the south, the one full of sprouts in the middle, and the one full of cakes on the north.

original: ekaikasyāḥ sītāyāḥ dakṣiṇeṣu camaseṣu rasān prakṣipya madhyameṣu virūḍhaṃ prakṣipyottareṣu puroḍāśaṃ nidadhāti //🔽darbhān pratyavabhujya saṃvapati // / / //
analyzed: ekaikasyāḥ sītāyāḥ dakṣiṇeṣu camaseṣu rasān prakṣipya madhyameṣu virūḍham prakṣipya uttareṣu puroḍāśam nidadhāti  darbhān pratyavabhujya saṃvapati
translated: Having put the juices into the southern ladles of each furrow, having put the sprouts into the middle ones, he places the cakes into the northern ones.🔽Having eaten the Darbha grass, he pours the oblation.
He places Darbha grass on top of the ladles.
Then he covers the pots with dust.
He puts earth there.

original: tataḥ prabhāte avaśyaṃ tasmin kṣetre dvitīye'hani karṣayitavyam /
analyzed: tatas prabhāte avaśyam tasmin kṣetre dvitīyehani karṣayitavyam
translated: Then in the morning, on the second day, he must necessarily plough in that field.
All this is one rite.

analyzed: kṛṣi karma samāptam  vṛṣabha lābha karmā ucyate
translated: The ploughing rite is complete.🔽Now the rite for obtaining a bull is described.

analyzed: sārūpavatse śakṛt piṇḍān guggulu lavaṇe pratinīya aśnāti
translated: In a cow with a calf of the same color, he takes dung balls, guggula and salt, and eats them.
The place of the bull.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'sīrā yuñjanti' iti sūktena sārūpavatsa odane śakṛtpiṇḍān prakṣipya guggulu lavaṇaṃ ca prakṣipya tasminnodane sampātyābhimantryāśnāti
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sīrā yuñjanti iti sūktena odane śakṛt piṇḍān prakṣipya guggulu lavaṇam ca prakṣipya tasmin odane sampātya abhimantrya aśnāti
translated: Having performed the abhyatāna rite, with the verse They yoke the ploughs, he puts dung balls into rice cooked by a cow with a calf of the same color, puts guggula and salt, offers oblations into that rice, and eats it after incantation.
Then the subsequent rite.
A cow is the fee.
The rite for obtaining a bull is complete.

original: anena karmaṇā kṛtena bahavo vṛṣabhāḥ sampadyante /
analyzed: anena karmaṇā kṛtena bahavaḥ vṛṣabhāḥ sampadyante
translated: By performing this rite, many bulls are obtained.
Because of the statement The place of the bull,
The third section.
Now the rite for making solid is described.
The nourishing ones.
Thus is the making solid.

original: śāntaphalaśilākṛtiloṣṭavalmīkarāśivāpaṃ trīṇi kūdīprāntāni madhyamapalāśe darbheṇa pariveṣṭya rāśipalyeṣu karoti // / / //
analyzed: śānta phala śilā ākṛti loṣṭa valmīka rāśi vāpam trīṇi kūdī prāntāni madhyama palāśe darbheṇa pariveṣṭya rāśi palyeṣu karoti
translated: The three ends of the tail, having made them into the middle leaf of a Darbha blade, he puts them into the heaps of ashes, having wrapped them with a Darbha blade.

original: śāntaphalaṃ tasyāvasitamākṛtiloṣṭaṃ valmīkamṛttikā tasyāmantaṃ vapā ca /🔽trīṇi kūdyāḥ prāntānyagrāṇi madhyamapalāśe kṛtvā darbheṇa pariveṣṭya śāntipuṣṭivadvā 'payasvatīḥ' iti sūktenābhimantrya rāśipalyeṣu karotyadhastāt
analyzed: śānta phalam tasya avasitam ākṛtiloṣṭam valmīka mṛttikā tasyām antam vapā ca  trīṇi kūdyāḥ prāntāni agrāṇi madhyama palāśe kṛtvā darbheṇa pariveṣṭya śānti puṣṭi vat vā payasvatīḥ iti sūktena abhimantrya rāśi palyeṣu karoti adhastāt
translated: The peaceful fruit, the shape, the clod, the anthill clay, and the omentum, these are the end.

Having made the three ends of the tail into the middle leaf of a Darbha blade, having wrapped them with a Darbha blade, having consecrated them with the Sukta beginning with Apāṃ tvā vasūnām (RV 1.154.1), he puts them into the heaps of ashes below.🔽They eat in the evening.
They put back the remainder.
Until the time of eating.
He recites after them.

original: 'payasvatīḥ' iti sūktena yadā yadā bhaktaṃ rādhyate tadā tadābhimantrayate yadā dīyate /
analyzed: payasvatīḥ iti sūktena yadā yadā bhaktam rādhyate tadā tadā abhimantrayate yadā dīyate
translated: With the Sukta beginning with Apāṃ tvā vasūnām (RV 1.154.1), whenever food is prepared, then at that time he recites it when it is given.

original: kaṇḍane peṣaṇe niṣpavane randhane pariveṣaṇe dāne ca sarvatrābhimantraṇam //
analyzed: kaṇḍane peṣaṇe niṣpavane randhane pariveṣaṇe dāne ca sarvatra abhimantraṇam
translated: Recitation at every stage - in pounding, grinding, winnowing, cooking, serving, and giving.
This lord of the sky is ours.

analyzed: iti palyeśmānam samprokṣya anvṛcam kāśīnopya āvāpayati
translated: Having sprinkled the stone with the Palya water, he causes it to be brought with the Anuvāka beginning with Iha gāvaḥ (RV 1.154.2).

original: 'ayaṃ no nabhasaspatiḥ' iti sūktenāśmānaṃ abhimantrya palye nidadhāti /
analyzed: ayam naḥ nabhasaspatiḥ iti sūktena aśmānam abhimantrya palye nidadhāti
translated: With the verse, This is our lord of the sky, he recites over a stone and places it on the threshing roller.

original: aśmanopari trīn anvṛcaṃ muṣṭiṃ dhānyaṃ nidadhāti /
analyzed: aśmanā upari trīn anvṛcam muṣṭim dhānyam nidadhāti
translated: On the stone, he places three handfuls of grain, one for each verse.

analyzed: sthira dhānyam akṣayam bhavati  samāptāni sphāti karaṇāni
translated: The grain becomes firm and inexhaustible.🔽The rites for making grain abundant are complete.

original: puṣṭikarmāṇyeva vartante 🔽ā gāvaḥ / iti gāḥ āyatīḥ pratyuttiṣṭhati // / / //
analyzed: puṣṭikarmāṇi eva vartante  ā gāvaḥ iti gāḥ āyatīḥ pratyuttiṣṭhati
translated: Now the rites for prosperity follow.🔽With the verse, Come, O cows, he goes forth to meet the cows coming back.

original: 'ā gāvaḥ' iti sūktena sandhyākāle gā āyatīḥ pratyuttiṣṭhati //
analyzed: ā gāvaḥ iti sūktena sandhyā kāle gāḥ āyatīḥ pratyuttiṣṭhati
translated: At twilight, he goes forth to meet the cows coming back with the verse, Come, O cows.

analyzed: prāvṛṣi prathama dhārasya indrāya tris juhoti
translated: In the rainy season, when the first rain falls, he offers three times to Indra.

original: yadā prathamaṃ homamicchati tadedaṃ karma karoti pākayajñavidhānena /
analyzed: yadā prathamam homam icchati tadā idam karma karoti pākayajña vidhānena
translated: When he desires the first oblation, he performs this rite according to the rules of the domestic sacrifice.

original: tasyā dugdhenendradevatākaṃ caruṃ śrapayitvā 'ā gāvaḥ' iti ṣaḍbhirṛgbhirdvābhyāṃ dvābhyāṃ trayo homāḥ kartavyāḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ dugdhena indra devatākam carum śrapayitvā ā gāvaḥ iti ṣaḍbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ dvābhyām dvābhyām trayaḥ homāḥ kartavyāḥ
translated: Having cooked a porridge for Indra with her milk, he should make three oblations with the six verses beginning with Come, O cows, two by two.
I offer what is pleasing to Indra.
There is a special rule for sprinkling and strewing the sacrificial grass.
May they be full of offspring.
He recites this verse to the cows as they are going out to pasture.🔽May they be full of offspring.

analyzed: prajāvatīḥ sū yavasāḥ iti ṛcā araṇye gacchantīḥ gāḥ anumantrayate
translated: With the verse, 'Rich in offspring, rich in food,' he follows the cows going to the forest.

analyzed: karkī pravādānām dvādaśa dāmnyām sampātavatyām ayam ghāsaḥ
translated: For the Kirki-proclaimers, on the twelve-versed (hymn) with the 'Sampāta' (oblation), this is the fodder.
Here the calf.

analyzed: iti mantra uktam  abhyātāna antam kṛtvā sūryasya raśmīn anu
translated: Thus it is stated in the mantra.🔽Having performed up to the Ābhyāmāna, with the three verses, 'Following the rays of the sun'

original: iti tisṛbhirdvādaśadāmnyāṃ sampātitāyāṃ vatsāṃ badhnāti /🔽'iha vatsāṃ nibadhnīmaḥ' iti pādena vatsāṃ badhnāti /
analyzed: iti tisṛbhiḥ dvādaśa dāmnyām sampātitāyām vatsām badhnāti  iha vatsām nibadhnīmaḥ iti pādena vatsām badhnāti
translated: on the twelve-versed (hymn) with the 'Sampāta' (oblation), he ties the calf.🔽With the quarter verse, 'Here we tie the calf,' he ties the calf.

original: 'ayaṃ ghāsaḥ' iti pādena ghāsaṃ dadāti gobhyo vatsebhyaśca /
analyzed: ayam ghāsaḥ iti pādena ghāsam dadāti gobhyaḥ vatsebhyaḥ ca
translated: With the quarter verse, 'This is the fodder,' he gives fodder to the cows and calves.
The Ābhyāmāna and the subsequent procedure.
The cow-pacification is complete.
The rites for the 'Sampad' of cloth are stated.
The one for your grief.

analyzed: iti vastra sāmpadī  tisraḥ kūdī mayīḥ ūrṇanābhi kulāya parihitāḥ anvaktāḥ ādadhāti
translated: Thus is the 'Sampad' of cloth.🔽He places three balls of wool covered with a woolen blanket, anointed with ghee, with the three verses, 'The one for your grief.'

original: 'yaste śokāya' ityṛcā tisraḥ kūdīmayīḥ ūmayakulāyasūtreṇāveṣṭya ghūtenāktā ādadhāti /
analyzed: yaḥ te śokāya iti ṛcā tisraḥ kūdī mayīḥ ūmaya kulāya sūtreṇa āveṣṭya ghūtena aktāḥ ādadhāti
translated: With the verse, 'The one for your grief,' he places three balls of wool wrapped with a woolen blanket, anointed with ghee.
The mantra is repeated three times.
Ūma is wool.
By this rite performed, clothes are accomplished.

original: atyanteṣīkā mauñjaparihitā madhunā pralipya cikkaśeṣu paryasya // / / //
analyzed: atyanta iṣīkāḥ mauñja parihitāḥ madhunā pralipya cikkaseṣu paryasya
translated: With the very sharp blades of grass, having put on the Muñja grass, having smeared with honey, having placed in the burning coals,

original: 'yaste śokāya' ityṛcā muñjena saha iṣīkāstisro madhunā praliptā cikkaśeṣvādadhāti /
analyzed: yaḥ te śokāya iti ṛcā muñjena saha iṣīkāḥ tisraḥ madhunā praliptāḥ cikkaseṣu ādadhāti
translated: with the verse 'That which is thy grief' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), together with the Muñja grass, he places three blades of grass smeared with honey in the burning coals.
The mantra is repeated three times.
The rites for obtaining clothes are completed.

analyzed: jyeṣṭhena putreṇa saha bhāga vidhim vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will now explain the rules for sharing the inheritance with the eldest son.

analyzed: uta putraḥ iti jyeṣṭham putram avasāyayati
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he dismisses the eldest son.

original: 'uta putraḥ' ityṛcā gṛhakāṣṭheṣṭakādyā abhimantrya gṛhaṃ kārayet /
analyzed: uta putraḥ iti ṛcā gṛha kāṣṭha iṣṭakā ādyāḥ abhimantrya gṛham kārayet
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he should consecrate the house-wood, bricks, etc., and have a house built.
One who desires prosperity.

original: putro vā sāmpadaṃ karoti pitā vā //
analyzed: putraḥ vā sāmpadam karoti pitā vā
translated: Either the son or the father performs the rite for obtaining prosperity.
One who has a limited shelter performs the rite for obtaining prosperity.

analyzed: uta putraḥ iti ṛcā sarva sāmpadam kurute
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he performs the rite for obtaining all prosperity.

analyzed: uta putraḥ iti ṛcā audumbara samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he places Udumbara sticks.

analyzed: uta putraḥ iti ṛcā pālāśa samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he places Palasha sticks.

analyzed: uta putraḥ iti ṛcā bṛhadbadarī samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: With the verse 'Or the son' (Taitt. Sam. 1.1.1.1), he places large jujube sticks.

original: catuṣpathe vyādhitaṃ kṛtvā tasya śirasi darbheṇḍukaṃ kṛtvā tasyopari kapālamagnipūrṇaṃ
analyzed: catuṣpathe vyādhitam kṛtvā tasya śirasi darbheṇḍukam kṛtvā tasya upari kapālam agni pūrṇam
translated: Having placed the patient on the crossroad, having made two Darbha blades on his head, on top of them a vessel filled with fire,

Having kindled a fire, in the kindled fire, with the Sûkta, 'The divine Gandharva' (Rig-v. 1, 119), he sacrifices all herbs anointed with ghee.

analyzed: catuṣpathe ca śirasi darbha iṇḍu eṅgāra kapāle prajvālita ignau imam me agne iti
translated: On a cross-road, on the head, on two Darbha blades, on a charcoal-vessel, in a kindled fire, with the four (verses), 'This Agni, O Agni' (Taitt. Samh., loc. cit.),

original: catasṛbhirājyenāktāḥ sarvauṣadhīrjuhoti pratyṛcaṃ śirasi home na tantram //

original: titauni pratīpaṃ gāhamāno vapatītaro'vasiñcati paścāt // / / //🔽vyādhitasya vallaṇikāṃ sarvauṣadhisahitāṃ haste kṛtvā nadyudakasammukhaṃ praveśya tato'vagāhayati /
analyzed: pratīpam gāhamānaḥ vapati itaraḥ uvasiñcati paścāt  vyādhitasya vallaṇikām sarva oṣadhi sahitām haste kṛtvā nadī udaka sammukham praveśya tatas uvagāhayati

analyzed: āma pātre opya āsicya mauñje tri pāde vayaḥ niveśane prabadhnāti

original: tato mṛnmaya āmapātre homaśeṣaḥ sarvauṣadhīḥ kṛtvā pakṣiṇo yasmin vṛkṣe vasanti tatra tripāde śikye kṛtvā badhnāti /

analyzed: tatas kartā tam avasiñcati vyādhitam imam me iti catasṛbhiḥ
translated: Then the performer sprinkles that person with the four verses beginning with This one to me, O Agni (RV 1.190.1-4).

translated: Having put it in a new earthen pot, having sprinkled it, he ties it in a three-legged sling made of Muñja grass in a tree where no animal dwells.

Aghashatri (RV 1.191.1).
Sham no devi (RV 1.191.2).
Varana (RV 1.191.3).
Pippali (RV 1.191.4).🔽Yad vidradhasya (RV 1.191.5).
Ya babhravaḥ (RV 1.191.6).

analyzed: prathamena mantra uktam badhnāti  dvitīyena mantra uktasya sampātavatā anulimpati

translated: With these two hymns, he consecrates water and makes the patient sip it, if it is poisonous.

original: takṣakāya namaskāraṃ kṛtvā 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāmudakamabhimantrya samprokṣati viṣaduṣṭam /
analyzed: takṣakāya namaskāram kṛtvā brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām udakam abhimantrya samprokṣati viṣa duṣṭam
translated: Having made salutations to Takshaka, with the two hymns 'the Brahmin was born', 'the giver of water', he consecrates water and sprinkles the patient affected by poison.
The remedy for Skanda poison.

analyzed: kṛmuka śakalam saṅkṣudya dūrśa jarat ajina avakara jvālena
translated: Having chopped up a piece of the Kṛmiku tree, with the flame of a lamp made of old rags and cow dung, he should burn it.

original: 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāṃ kṛmukavṛkṣaśakalaṃ sahodakamabhimantrya tata ācāmayati /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām kṛmuka vṛkṣa śakalam saha udakam abhimantrya tatas ācāmayati
translated: The Brahmin was born, the giver of water - with these two hymns, he consecrates a piece of the Kṛmiku tree along with water and then makes the patient sip it.
The remedy for Skanda poison.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām kṛmuka vṛkṣa śakalam saha udakam abhimantrya abhyukṣati
translated: With the two hymns, 'The Brâhmana was born' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 1), 'The giver of rain' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 2), he recites over a piece of the Krikû wood and water, and sprinkles (the patient).

analyzed: tatas mārjanam ācamanam ca sarvam tūṣṇīm
translated: Then the wiping (of the body) and the sipping of water, all silently.

analyzed: dūrśā avajvālitam udakam abhimantrya vyādhitam avasiñcati  mārjana ācamane ca
translated: He recites over water in which a Dûrvâ leaf has been lighted, and sprinkles the patient with it.🔽And the wiping (of the body) and the sipping of water.
All silently.

original: 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' iti sūktābhyāṃ jīrṇahariṇacarmāvajvālitamudake prakṣipya tamabhimantrya tato'vasiñcati /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe iti sūktābhyām jīrṇa hariṇa carma avajvālitam udake prakṣipya tam abhimantrya tatas avasiñcati
translated: With the two hymns, 'The Brâhmana was born' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 1), 'The giver of rain' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 2), he throws into the water a piece of an old deer-skin which has been lighted, recites (the two hymns) over it, and then sprinkles (the patient).
A remedy against poison.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām sammārjanikā vakara tṛṇaiḥ avajvālitam udakam abhimantrya avasiñcati
translated: With the two hymns, 'The Brâhmana was born' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 1), 'The giver of rain' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 2), he recites over water in which a straw of the Sammârjanî has been lighted, and sprinkles (the patient).

original: skandaviṣabhaiṣajyam //🔽sampātavatyudapātra ūrdhvaphalābhyāṃ digdhābhyāṃ manthamupamathya rayidhāraṇāpiṇḍānanvṛcaṃ prakīrya chardayate // / / //
analyzed: skanda viṣa bhaiṣajyam  sampātavati uda pātre ūrdhva phalābhyām digdhābhyām mantham upamathya rayi dhāraṇā piṇḍān anvṛcam prakīrya chardayate
translated: A remedy against the poison of the Skandavishas.🔽In a water-pot which contains the remnants (of a sacrifice), he mixes with the churned buttermilk two (kinds of) upward-growing plants, strews over it, verse by verse, the balls of the Rayidharaṇa, and makes (the patient) vomit.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāmudapātraṃ sampātyābhimantryāplāvayati viṣaduṣṭam /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām uda pātram sampātya abhimantrya āplāvayati viṣa duṣṭam
translated: Having gone through the preliminaries as far as the Âgyabhâga oblations, he pours out the water of the pot in which the remnants (of a sacrifice) are kept, and recites over it the two hymns, 'The Brâhmana was born' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 1), 'The giver of rain' (Rig-v. 1, 191, 2), and sprinkles (the patient) who is affected by poison.
Antidote for poison.

original: 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāṃ viṣaliptābhyāṃ phalābhyāṃ saktumanthamupamathya tato'bhimantrya pāyayati /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām viṣa liptābhyām phalābhyām saktu mantham upamathya pāyayati
translated: With the two hymns The Brahmana was born and The giver of water, he mixes barley flour and water with poisoned fruits, then consecrates it with the hymns and makes the patient drink it.
Antidote for poison.

original: 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāṃ madanaphalāni pratyṛcamabhimantrya bhakṣayati /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām madana phalāni pratyṛcam abhimantrya bhakṣayati
translated: With the two hymns The Brahmana was born and The giver of water, he consecrates madana fruits with each verse and makes the patient eat them.
As soon as he vomits, he should do the same.
Antidote for the poison of Skanda.
He makes the patient drink turmeric mixed with ghee.

original: 'brāhmaṇo jajñe' 'vāridam' iti sūktābhyāṃ haridrāṃ sarpiṣā sahitāmabhimantrya pāyayati /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ jajñe vāri dam iti sūktābhyām haridrām sarpiṣā sahitām abhimantrya pāyayati
translated: With the two hymns The Brahmana was born and The giver of water, he consecrates turmeric mixed with ghee and makes the patient drink it.
The antidote for the poison of Skanda is complete.

analyzed: atha śastra ādi abhighāte rudhira pravāhe bhaiṣajyāni ucyante
translated: Now, antidotes are mentioned for bleeding caused by weapons etc.
Rohani. He sprinkles it under the constellation Avana.

analyzed: rohaṇī asi iti sūktena lākṣā udakam kvāthitam abhimantrya vyādhi deśam avasiñcati
translated: With the hymn You are Rohani, he consecrates red chalk water boiled with the hymn and sprinkles the affected part.
The rite is to be performed at dawn.

analyzed: asthi bhaṅge rudhira pravāhe daṃśa śastra abhighāta ādau bhaiṣajyam
translated: In case of fracture of bones, bleeding, or injury by a bite or weapon, there is a remedy.
He causes the child to drink the Pṛṣadājya and anoints it.🔽With the formula, You are the ascending one, he consecrates the Pṛṣadājya mixed with ghee and causes the child to drink it.

original: 'rohaṇyasi' iti pṛṣātakaṃ ghṛtamiśraṃ dugdhamabhimantrya pāyayati /🔽'rohaṇyasi' iti sūktena kṣīraṃ ghṛtamiśraṃ kṛtvā vyādhideśaṃ mrakṣati /🔽aṅgabhaṅge'ṅgachede'ṅgarudhirapravāhe'ṅgābhighāte'ṅgabhagne'ṅgamūḍhābhighāte'ṅgavṛkṣābhighāte
analyzed: rohaṇī asi iti pṛṣātakam ghṛta miśram dugdham abhimantrya pāyayati  rohaṇī asi iti sūktena kṣīram ghṛta miśram kṛtvā vyādhi deśam mrakṣati  aṅga bhaṅga iṅga cheda iṅga rudhira pravāha iṅga abhighāta iṅga bhagna iṅga mūḍha abhighāta iṅga vṛkṣa abhighāte
translated: With the verse, You are the ascending one, he mixes milk with ghee, and anoints the affected part of the body.🔽In case of fracture of a limb, cutting off of a limb, bleeding from a limb, injury to a limb, fracture of a limb, injury to a limb that has lost sensation, injury to a limb that is like a tree,

analyzed: muṣṭi loṣṭa iṣṭikā paśu śṛṅga agni pāṣāṇa lakuṭa śastra ādi abhighāte rudhira pravāhe vā śarīra cheda ādau
translated: or in case of bleeding from a wound caused by a fist, clod, brick, animal horn, fire, stone, stick, weapon, etc., or in case of cutting of the body,
the remedy is complete.

original: atha rakṣobhaiṣajyamucyate 🔽ā paśyati / iti sadampuṣpāmaṇiṃ badhnāti // / / //🔽tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ā paśyati' iti sūktena sadampuṣpāmaṇiṃ sampātyābhimantrya badhnāti /
analyzed: atha rakṣaḥ bhaiṣajyam ucyate  ā paśyati iti sadampuṣpāmaṇim badhnāti  tantram kṛtvā ā paśyati iti sūktena sadampuṣpā maṇim sampātya abhimantrya badhnāti
translated: Now the remedy for Rākṣasa affliction is stated.🔽He sees, thus he ties the Sadampuspa amulet.🔽Having performed the rite, with the verse, He sees, he consecrates the Sadampuspa amulet by striking it, and ties it.
The rite beginning with the pouring of clarified butter is to be done afterwards.
The Sadampuspa is well-known as the three junctions.

original: brahmagrahe kṣatriyagrahe vaiśyagrahe śūdragrahe vānyeṣāṃ vyantarāṇāṃ piśācānāṃ rakṣasāṃ ca bhaiṣajyaṃ samāptam //
analyzed: brahma grahe kṣatriya grahe vaiśya grahe śūdra grahe vā anyeṣām vyantarāṇām piśācānām rakṣasām ca bhaiṣajyam samāptam
translated: The remedy for the seizure by Brahman, for the seizure by a Kshatriya, for the seizure by a Vaishya, for the seizure by a Shudra, and for other intermediate beings, pishachas, and rakshasas is complete.
Now the remedy for all diseases is described.
Bhavani and Sharva.

original: iti sapta kāmpīlapuṭānapāṃ pūrṇān sampātavataḥ kṛtvā dakṣiṇenāvasicya paścādvidhyati // / / //
analyzed: iti sapta kāmpīla puṭān apām pūrṇān sampātavataḥ kṛtvā dakṣiṇena avasicya paścāt vidhyati
translated: Thus, having made seven Kampee pots full of water with the remnants of the oblation, he sprinkles with the southern one, and then pierces from the back.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'bhavāśarvau manve vām' iti sūktena saptarcenaikaikayarcā kāmpīlasaptapuṭakānudakapūrṇān sampātyarcarcā tataḥ pratyṛcamabhimantrya
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā bhavāśarvau manve vām iti sūktena sapta ṛcena ekaikayā ṛcā kāmpīla sapta puṭakān udaka pūrṇān sampātya ṛcā ṛcā tatas pratyṛcam abhimantrya
translated: Having performed the abhyanana rite, with the seven-verse hymn I meditate on Bhavani and Sharva, he consecrates each Kampee pot filled with water with one verse, and then consecrates each verse with the verse.
Then he sprinkles the patient.
Then he throws the pot from the back.
Thus the second, thus the third.

analyzed: tatas uttara tantram  samāptam sarva vyādhi bhaiṣajyam
translated: Then the subsequent procedure.🔽The remedy for all diseases is complete.
The remedy for all spirit possession is described.
By you in the beginning.
Thus, with the sheath, Shami powder in the food.

original: 'tvayā pūrvam' iti sūktena śamīparṇacūrṇaṃ śamīphale kṛtvābhimantrya saktumadhye dadāti bhakṣārtham /
analyzed: tvayā pūrvam iti sūktena śamī parṇa cūrṇam śamī phale kṛtvā abhimantrya saktu madhye dadāti bhakṣa artham
translated: With the verse By thee in the beginning he makes a powder of Śamī leaves in a Śamī fruit, consecrates it, and gives it to the patient to eat mixed with flour.
A remedy for possession by a Rākṣasa.
In the case of a decoration.

original: 'tvayā pūrvam' iti sūktena śamīparṇacūrṇaṃ śamīphale kṛtvābhimantryālaṅkāre dadāti vyādhitasya /
analyzed: tvayā pūrvam iti sūktena śamī parṇa cūrṇam śamī phale kṛtvā abhimantrya alaṅkāre dadāti vyādhitasya
translated: With the verse By thee in the beginning he makes a powder of Śamī leaves in a Śamī fruit, consecrates it, and gives it to the patient to wear as a decoration.
A remedy for all kinds of possession.
He strews around a hall.

original: 'tvayā pūrvam' iti sūktena śamīcūrṇaṃ kṛtvābhimantrya śālāṃ cūrṇaiḥ parikirati /
analyzed: tvayā pūrvam iti sūktena śamī cūrṇam kṛtvā abhimantrya śālām cūrṇaiḥ parikirati
translated: With the verse By thee in the beginning he makes a powder of Śamī, consecrates it, and scatters the powder around the hall.
The hall of the patient.

analyzed: rakṣaḥ graha apsaraḥ graha gandharva graha sarva graha bhaiṣajyam samāptam
translated: The remedy for possession by Rākṣasas, Apsarases, Gandharvas, and all kinds of possession is complete.

analyzed: atha a mati gṛhīte bhaiṣajyam ucyate
translated: Now a remedy is prescribed for possession by a demon.
And thou art immortal.
With this verse he gives food to one possessed by a demon.

original: 'utāmṛtāsuḥ' ityṛcā bhojanakāle bhaktamabhimantrya dadāti bhakṣaṇārtham prajñāpranaṣṭe'jñānagṛhīte'dharmagṛhīte trivarge ca vinaṣṭe dyūtakrīḍādyatipratte
analyzed: uta amṛta asuḥ iti ṛcā bhojana kāle bhaktam abhimantrya dadāti bhakṣaṇa artham prajñā pranaṣṭe jñāna gṛhīte dharma gṛhīte trivarge ca vinaṣṭe dyūta krīḍā ādi atipratte
translated: At the time of eating he consecrates the food with the verse And thou art immortal, and gives it to the patient to eat. When wisdom is lost, when one is possessed by ignorance, when one is possessed by unrighteousness, when the three goals are destroyed, when one is excessively addicted to gambling and play,
The remedy for bad thoughts.

original: rājayakṣmaṇi śiroroge kuṣṭhāmaye sarvagātravedanāyāṃ bhaiṣajyamucyate 🔽kuṣṭhaliṅgābhirnavanītamiśreṇāpratīhāraṃ pralimpati // / / //
analyzed: rājayakṣmaṇi śiraḥ roge kuṣṭha āmaye sarva gātra vedanāyām bhaiṣajyam ucyate  kuṣṭha liṅgābhiḥ navanīta miśreṇa apratīhāram pralimpati
translated: The remedy is stated for royal consumption, headache, leprosy, and pain in all limbs.
He anoints the body of the patient with the paste of kushtha mixed with ghee, with the mantra You who are born in the mountains.
With the hymn Three times to the Shambhus, to the Angiras,

original: iti caturṛcena kuṣṭhapiṣṭaṃ navanītamiśraṃ kṛtvābhimantryāpratīhāraṃ vyādhitasya śarīraṃ pralimpati /
analyzed: iti caturṛcena kuṣṭha piṣṭam navanīta miśram kṛtvā abhimantrya a pratīhāram vyādhitasya śarīram pralimpati
translated: and with the four-verse hymn, he prepares a paste of kushtha mixed with ghee, consecrates it with the mantra, and anoints the body of the patient with it.

original: rājayakṣmaṇi śiroroge kuṣṭhāmaye sarvagātravedanāsu bhaiṣajyaṃ samāptam //
analyzed: rājayakṣmaṇi śiraḥ roge kuṣṭha āmaye sarva gātra vedanāsu bhaiṣajyam samāptam
translated: The remedy for royal consumption, headache, leprosy, and pain in all limbs is complete.

analyzed: atha śastra ādi abhighāte bhaiṣajyam ucyate  lākṣā liṅgābhiḥ dugdhe phāṇṭān pāyayati
translated: Now the remedy for injury by weapons etc. is stated.🔽He makes the patient drink the gruel boiled with lac, with the mantra Lac is the mother.

original: 'rātrī mātā' / iti sūktena dugdhe lākṣāṃ kvāthayitvābhimantrya pāyayati /
analyzed: rātrī mātā iti sūktena dugdhe lākṣām kvāthayitvā abhimantrya pāyayati
translated: With the hymn Night is the mother, he boils lac in milk, consecrates it with the mantra, and makes the patient drink it.

analyzed: śastra ādi abhighāte pāṣāṇa patana abhighāta agni dāhe sarva śarīra abhighāte bhaiṣajyam samāptam
translated: The remedy for injury by weapons etc., for injury by falling rocks, for burns by fire, and for injury to the whole body is complete.

analyzed: sūtikā strī ariṣṭakasya ca bhaiṣajyāni ucyante
translated: Now the remedies for a woman who has recently given birth and for a woman with a difficult delivery are stated.
Brahman, the unborn,
Thus he describes the misfortune of childbirth.
Brahma, the unborn one...
Those who are not satisfied...
You who have a thousand streams...
Having enchanted the food with this hymn, he gives it.
For the purpose of eating.

original: pūrvaṃ strī praveśya tūṣṇīṃ tataḥ paścāt kartā tūṣṇīṃ praviśya sūktena bhaktamabhimantrya dadyāt //
analyzed: pūrvam strī praveśya tūṣṇīm tatas paścāt kartā tūṣṇīm praviśya sūktena bhaktam abhimantrya dadyāt
translated: First, a woman should enter silently, then the performer should enter silently from the back, enchant the food with the hymn, and give it.
The churning, sipping, and worship of the sun.

original: 'brahma jajñānam' 'anāptā ye' 'sahasradhāra eva te' iti sūktena saktumanthamabhimantrya pāyayati /
analyzed: brahma jajñānam an āptāḥ ye sahasra dhāre eva te iti sūktena saktu mantham abhimantrya pāyayati
translated: Having enchanted the barley flour gruel with the hymn Brahma, the unborn one... Those who are not satisfied... You who have a thousand streams..., he makes [the patient] drink it.
With the same hymn, the worship of the sun.

analyzed: brahma jajñānam iti sūktena udakam abhimantrya ācāmayati
translated: Having enchanted water with the hymn Brahma, the unborn one..., he makes [the patient] sip it.

analyzed: samāptam strī prasava doṣe sūtikā roge ca bhaiṣajyam
translated: The remedy for the faults of childbirth and the illness of childbirth is complete.

analyzed: adbhuta darśane doṣa nāśana bhaiṣajyam samāptam
translated: The remedy for destroying the faults in seeing a wonder is complete.

analyzed: sarva adbhuteṣu bhakta karma vā ācamana karma vā kuryāt
translated: In all wonders, one should perform the rite of food or the rite of sipping water.

original: yāni carakādivaidyakeṣvadbhutāni paṭhyante'svasthaśārīraviṣaye teṣāṃ sarveṣāmiyaṃ śāntirbhaiṣajyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yāni caraka ādi vaidyakeṣu adbhutāni paṭhyante svastha śārīra viṣaye teṣām sarveṣām iyam śāntiḥ bhaiṣajyam bhavati
translated: And for all the portents that are recited in the medical treatises such as the Caraka, which are not about the healthy body, this is the pacification, this is the remedy for all of them.

original: yāni cādbhutāni śarīraroge jyotiṣe paṭhyante teṣāmapīdaṃ karma //
analyzed: yāni ca adbhutāni śarīra roge jyotiṣe paṭhyante teṣām api idam karma
translated: And for all the portents that are recited in astrology about bodily diseases, this is the remedy for them.
Now the remedy for all diseases is described.
To Divā, svāhā. This barley.

analyzed: iti caturaḥ uda pātre sampātān ānayati
translated: Thus he brings down four oblations into a water pot.

original: tantraṃ kṛtvā 'dive svāhā' iti sūktena catura udapātre sampātānānayati //
analyzed: tantram kṛtvā dive svāhā iti sūktena caturaḥ uda pātre sampātān ānayati
translated: Having performed the Tantric ritual, he brings down four oblations into a water pot with the hymn To Divā, svāhā.
Two on the ground.
Having retrieved them, he pours them out.

original: dvau sampātau bhūmau dattvā tataḥ sampātitāṃ bhūmimṛttikāṃ saṅgṛhya tata udapātre prakṣipya tato'bhimantraṇaṃ kṛtvā vyādhitamāplāvayati /🔽'dive svāhā' iti tribhiḥ svāhākārairekaḥ sampātaḥ /
analyzed: dvau sampātau bhūmau dattvā tatas sampātitām bhūmi mṛttikām saṅgṛhya tatas uda pātre prakṣipya tatas abhimantraṇam kṛtvā vyādhitam āplāvayati  dive svāhā iti tribhiḥ svāhākāraiḥ ekaḥ sampātaḥ
translated: Having offered two oblations on the ground, then having collected the earth from the oblations, having thrown it into the water pot, then having performed the incantation, he pours it out on the patient.🔽With the three svāhā-utterances of To Divā, svāhā, there is one oblation.
With the three svāhā-utterances, there are three oblations.
Two oblations with two Ṛc verses.
Thus there are six.
The subsequent ritual is from the Ābhyāmāna.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'imaṃ yavam' iti sūktenārdharcenārdharcena homaḥ /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā imam yavam iti sūktena ardharcena ardharcena homaḥ
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ābhyānat, he offers with the verse This barley half a verse at a time.

analyzed: uda pātre sampātān ānīya dvau bhūmau sampātau
translated: Having brought down the Sampātas into a water-pot, he makes two Sampātas on the ground.

analyzed: tau gṛhītvā uda pātre prakṣipya tatas abhimantraṇam
translated: Having taken them, he throws them into the water-pot, and then he recites the mantra over it.
Then he makes the sick person bathe in it.
The rites up to the Ābhyānat and the subsequent rites follow.
This is a remedy for all diseases.

analyzed: sa yave ca uttareṇa yavam badhnāti
translated: And with the next verse, he ties barley to the patient's head.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'dive svāhā' iti sūktena ṣaṭ sampātān karoti yavasahita udapātre caturaḥ sampātānānayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam kṛtvā dive svāhā iti sūktena ṣaṭ sampātān karoti yava sahite uda pātre caturaḥ sampātān ānayati
translated: Having performed the rites up to the Ābhyānat, he makes six Sampātas with the verse To Dyaus svāhā. He brings down four Sampātas into a water-pot together with barley.

original: dvau sampātau bhūmau dattvā mṛttikāmudapātre prakṣipya tato'bhimantraṇamāplāvanaṃ ca /
