translated: Having performed the Tantric rite, he should consecrate a water-pot with the two Suktas beginning with Ma jyesttham and Tritê devâḥ, and having tied it with Muñja grass, he should then cause it to float with the pot containing Darbha grass.

original: tata uttaratantram /🔽uttarapāśaṃ 'nadīnāṃ phenān' ityardharcena nadīphene nidadhāti /
analyzed: tatas uttara tantram  uttara pāśam nadīnām phenān iti ardharcena nadī phene nidadhāti
translated: Then the subsequent Tantric rite.🔽He should place the upper noose in the foam of the river with half a verse beginning with Nadīnām phenān.

original: adharapāśān gṛhītvā nadīmadhye praviśya tūṣṇīṃ prakṣipati //
analyzed: adhara pāśān gṛhītvā nadī madhye praviśya tūṣṇīm prakṣipati
translated: Having taken the lower nooses, he should enter the middle of the river and silently throw them in.
And having entered with all (the Mantras), with the Apām Suktas.

original: 'mā jyeṣṭham' 'trite devāḥ' iti sūktābhyāmudakamabhimantrya tato bandhanaṃ kṛtvā tato'vasiñcati /
analyzed: mā jyeṣṭham trite devāḥ iti sūktābhyām udakam abhimantrya tatas bandhanam kṛtvā tatas uvasiñcati
translated: Having consecrated water with the two Suktas beginning with Ma jyesttham and Tritê devâḥ, and having tied (the nooses), he should then cause them to float.
The loosing of the nooses is as before.

original: abhyātānāntaṃ tantraṃ kṛtvā 'ambayo yanti' ityādibhiḥ sarvairapāṃ sūktairghaṭaṃ sampātyābhimantryāplāvayati /
analyzed: abhyātāna antam tantram kṛtvā ambayaḥ yanti ityādibhiḥ sarvaiḥ apām sūktaiḥ ghaṭam sampātya abhimantrya āplāvayati
translated: Having performed the Tantric rite up to the Abhigit, he should consecrate a pot with all the Apām Suktas beginning with Ambayo yanti, and having consecrated it, he should cause it to float.
The subsequent Tantric rite.
The expiation for one who has married a girl who has had a previous lover, or for one who has married a girl who has had a previous lover.

analyzed: ambayaḥ yanti ityādibhiḥ sarvaiḥ apām sūktaiḥ udakam abhimantrya avasiñcati
translated: With all the hymns beginning with 'The mothers go' (RV 10.97.1), he recites over the water and sprinkles it.
The expiation for the Parivitti and the Parivettri is complete.
For the two, it is separate for each.
Now, this rite is performed when the Ācārya dies,
as stated in the mantra of Devahāyana.
To the Ācārya...
One should offer...
With the Devahāyana Anuvāka.
He offers ghee with the Sruva.

original: mṛta ācārya āhitāgnau idaṃ karma bhavati //
analyzed: mṛte ācārye āhitāgnau idam karma bhavati
translated: This rite is performed when the Ācārya dies for one who has established the sacred fires.

original: atha devapitṛvarjitakhadāśayahitasyānnasya yājñikena karmaṇā bhavati taducyate
analyzed: atha deva pitṛ varjita khadā śaya hitasya annasya yājñikena karmaṇā bhavati tat ucyate
translated: Now, what is to be done with food fit for Khādaśayas, excluding gods and ancestors, by a sacrificial rite, is stated.
For the Khādaśaya, one should sow...
One performs the sacrifice to Vaivasvata...
One gives a four-cornered vessel...

original: 'yaddevā devaheḍanam' ityanuvākena khadāyā annāduddhṛtya setikāmekāṃ juhoti /
analyzed: yat devāḥ deva heḍanam iti anuvākena khadāyāḥ annāt uddhṛtya setikām ekām juhoti
translated: Having taken out food from the Khāda, one offers one oblation with the desire for this, with the Anuvāka beginning 'What the gods, O gods, is the offense' (RV 10.97.1).
It is an option for the Tantra.🔽The offering of barley is done for each verse.

original: vaivasvatadevatākaṃ pākayajñamājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'yaddevā devaheḍanam' ityanuvākena caruṃ juhoti /
analyzed: vaivasvata devatākam pākayajñam ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā yat devāḥ deva heḍanam iti anuvākena carum juhoti
translated: Having performed the Pākayajña with Vaivasvata as the deity, up to the Ajyabhāga, one offers the cooked rice with the Anuvāka beginning 'What the gods, O gods, is the offense' (RV 10.97.1).
The expiation for one who has eaten from a pit.
The subsequent ritual of the parvana and other (rites).

original: yaddevā devaheḍanamityanuvākena khadānnaṃ catuḥśarāvaparimitamabhimantrya tato brāhmaṇāya dadāti /
analyzed: yat devāḥ deva heḍanam iti anuvākena khada annam catur śarāva parimitam abhimantrya tatas brāhmaṇāya dadāti
translated: Having enchanted the food from the pit with the anuvaka yad devā devāheḍanam, measured with four potsherds, he then gives it to a Brahmin.

analyzed: khadā śaya anna saṃskāra śāntiḥ samāptā  atha mṛte dhanike ṛṇikasya ṛṇa dāna śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: The peace for the purification of food by one who has eaten from a pit is completed.🔽Now, the peace for the giving of debt by the debtor when the creditor is dead is stated.
When the creditor dies, he gives it to his son.
The three hymns beginning with 'apamityamapraittan' (RV 1.114.1-3).

analyzed: iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyam abhimantrya putrāya dadāti
translated: Having enchanted the substance with these three hymns, he gives it to his son.
He becomes free from debt.
To one of the same gotra.🔽The three hymns beginning with 'apamityamapraittan' (RV 1.114.1-3).

analyzed: apamityam apratīttam iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyam abhimantrya gotriṇe dadāti
translated: Having enchanted the substance with these three hymns, he gives it to one of the same gotra.
He becomes free from debt.
He throws it into the cremation ground.🔽The three hymns beginning with 'apamityamapraittan' (RV 1.114.1-3).

original: 'apamityamapratīttam' iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyamabhimantrya dhanikasya śmaśāne nikṣipati /
analyzed: apamityam apratīttam iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyam abhimantrya dhanikasya śmaśāne nikṣipati
translated: Having enchanted the substance with these three hymns, he deposits it in the cremation ground of the creditor.
He becomes free from debt.
And at the crossroads.

analyzed: apamityam apratīttam iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyam abhimantrya grāma catuṣpathe nikṣipet
translated: With the three hymns beginning with 'Apamittyam apratīttam' he should consecrate the substance and deposit it at the crossroads of the village.
He becomes free from debt.
He lights the armpits.

original: 'apamityamapratīttam' iti tribhiḥ sūktairdravyamabhimantryāgnau prajvalite prakṣipya tato'nṛṇo bhavati /
analyzed: apamityam apratīttam iti tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ dravyam abhimantrya agnau prajvalite prakṣipya tatonṛṇaḥ bhavati
translated: With the three hymns beginning with 'Apamittyam apratīttam' he should consecrate the substance and throw it into the burning fire, then he becomes free from debt.
The propitiation for the debt of giving is completed.

original: ākāśodakena śarīrāplavane doṣo bhavati tasya śāntirucyate
analyzed: ākāśa udakena śarīra āplavane doṣaḥ bhavati tasya śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: There is a fault in bathing the body with sky-water, the propitiation for that is stated.

original: divo nu mām / iti vīdhrabindūn prakṣālayati // / / //
analyzed: divaḥ nu mām iti vīdhra bindūn prakṣālayati
translated: With the verse 'Divonumām' he washes the sky-drops.
He touches with the mantras stated.

original: 'divo nu māṃ bṛhataḥ' iti sūktenodakamabhimantrya śarīraṃ prakṣālayati /
analyzed: divaḥ nu mām bṛhataḥ iti sūktena udakam abhimantrya śarīram prakṣālayati
translated: With the hymn 'Divonumām bṛhatas' he should consecrate water and wash the body.
The fault of the falling sky-drops does not occur.

original: 'divo nu māṃ bṛhataḥ' iti sūktenaikatra tailaṃ sarvauṣadhiḥ gandhaṃ hiraṇyaṃ vāsa etānyabhimantrya śarīramudvartayet /
analyzed: divaḥ nu mām bṛhataḥ iti sūktena ekatra tailam sarva oṣadhiḥ gandham hiraṇyam vāsaḥ etāni abhimantrya śarīram udvartayet
translated: With the hymn 'Divonumām bṛhatas' he should consecrate in one place oil, all herbs, fragrance, gold, and cloth, and anoint the body with them.
Then there is peace.
The propitiation for the fault of the sky-drops is completed.

original: atha kumārasya kumāryā vā yasyottamadantau pūrvau jātau tatra mātāpitrormaraṇaśaṅkā bhavati tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha kumārasya kumāryāḥ vā yasya uttama dantau pūrvau jātau tatra mātā pitroḥ maraṇa śaṅkā bhavati tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, if for a boy or girl, whichever has the two upper teeth born first, there is fear of death for the parents, then a peace offering is prescribed.

analyzed: yasya uttama dantau pūrvau jāyete yau vyāghrau
translated: For whom the two upper teeth are born first, which are the two tigers.

original: ityāvapati // / / //🔽'yau vyāghrau' iti sūktena vrīhiñjuhoti /🔽'yau vyāghrau' iti sūktena yavāñjuhoti /
analyzed: iti āvapati  yau vyāghrau iti sūktena vrīhin juhoti  yau vyāghrau iti sūktena yavān juhoti
translated: Thus he sows.🔽With the verse Which two tigers, he offers rice.🔽With the verse Which two tigers, he offers barley.

analyzed: yau vyāghrau iti sūktena tilān juhoti
translated: With the verse Which two tigers, he offers sesame seeds.
The tantra is optional.
In all cases, there is no sequence.
He bites with the mantra-mentioned.

analyzed: yau vyāghrau iti sūktena vrīhi yava tila māṣān ekīkṛtvā abhimantrya uttama jāta dantābhyām daṃśayati
translated: With the verse Which two tigers, having mixed rice, barley, sesame seeds, and beans, he incants them and bites them with the two upper teeth that were born first.
He offers the cooked food consecrated with the peace water to those who are indicated.

original: pitarau ca // / / //🔽athājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā vrīhiyavatilamāṣānekīkṛtya tataḥ śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā sthālīpākaṃ
analyzed: pitarau ca  atha ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā vrīhi yava tila māṣān ekīkṛtya tatas śāntyudakam kṛtvā sthālīpākam
translated: And to the parents.🔽Then, having performed up to the end of the two portions of clarified butter, having mixed rice, barley, sesame seeds, and beans, then having prepared the peace water, having cooked the oblation,

original: śrapayitvā tato'bhyātānāni hutvā 'yau vyāghrau' iti sūktena sthālīpākaṃ sampātyābhimantrya
analyzed: śrapayitvā tatobhyātānāni hutvā yau vyāghrau iti sūktena sthālīpākam sampātya abhimantrya
translated: then having offered the abhyatanas, he consecrates the oblation with the verse Which two tigers and offers it.
Then he makes the child touch the best of the teeth.
The father and mother make him touch.
The cooking of the Sthālīpāka is done with Śānti water.

analyzed: ājyabhāga ante sarvatra śāntyudaka kriyā kartavyā
translated: At the end of the Ājyabhāgas, the Śānti water rite should be performed everywhere.
The Abhimantrana and the Uttara Tantras.

analyzed: uttama danta jāta doṣa śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The pacification of the fault of the best teeth being born is completed.

original: atha śirasi aṅge vā kākopaviṣṭadoṣaḥ śrūyate tasya śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha śirasi aṅge vā kāka upaviṣṭa doṣaḥ śrūyate tasya śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, the fault of a crow sitting on the head or body is heard, the pacification of that is stated.

analyzed: idam yat kṛṣṇaḥ  iti kṛṣṇa śakuninā adhikṣiptam prakṣālayati
translated: This which is black.🔽With these two verses, he makes the person whose body has been pecked by a black bird wash.

analyzed: idam yat kṛṣṇaḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām udakam abhimantrya śarīram prakṣālayati
translated: He makes the person whose body has been pecked by a black bird wash with water enchanted with these two verses, This which is black.
The fault of a crow sitting does not occur.
Or he takes a bath.
He performs the Paryagnikaraṇa on what has been wiped.

original: 'idaṃ yatkṛṣṇaḥ' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāmulmukamabhimantrya kākamukhenopamṛṣṭaṃ puruṣaṃ paryagni karoti /
analyzed: idam yat kṛṣṇaḥ iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām ulmukam abhimantrya kāka mukhena upamṛṣṭam puruṣam paryagni karoti
translated: With these two verses, This which is black, he enchants a torch, and performs the Paryagnikaraṇa on a person whose mouth has been pecked by a crow.
Having whirled it above, he throws it far away.
The pacification of the fault of a crow sitting is completed.
Now, the pacification of the fault of contact is stated.
It bears fruit in the future.
Thus he puts the Apamarga sticks on the Apamarga fire.

original: barhirlavanādyājyatantra idhmasthāne'pāmārgedhmamupasamādhāya tato'bhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'pratīcīnaphalaḥ' iti tisṛbhirṛgbhirapāmārgasamidha ādadhāti
analyzed: barhiḥ lavana ādi ājya tantre idhma sthāne ipāmārga idhmam upasamādhāya tatobhyātāna antam kṛtvā pratīcīna phalaḥ iti tisṛbhiḥ ṛgbhiḥ apāmārga samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: After spreading the Barhis grass, in place of the kindling wood, having put the Apamarga kindling wood on the fire, then having performed up to the Abhyarana, he offers Apamarga sticks with the three verses beginning with Having fruits turned inward (RV 10.169.1-3).
Everywhere the sticks are one span long.
The subsequent procedure is as in the Abhyarana.

analyzed: athavā apāmārga kāṣṭha prajvalita ignau pratīcīna phalaḥ iti tisṛbhiḥ apāmārga samidhaḥ ādadhāti
translated: Or, in a fire kindled with Apamarga wood, he offers Apamarga sticks with the three verses beginning with Having fruits turned inward.
Because it is a hand-offering, there is an option in the procedure.

original: sarveṣu rogeṣu śyāvadatā kunakhinā ṣaṇḍena jvareṇāpāmārgādi sarveṣu rogeṣu saṃsargeṣu sarvadoṣānmucyate /
analyzed: sarveṣu rogeṣu śyāva datā kunakhinā ṣaṇḍena jvareṇa apāmārga ādi sarveṣu rogeṣu saṃsargeṣu sarva doṣāt mucyate
translated: In all diseases, in one with a discolored face, with bad nails, with a goiter, with fever, in all diseases, in all contacts, one is freed from all faults.
The pacification of faults in contact is complete.
What is below that.🔽Thus he sips water.

analyzed: yat arvācīnam iti ṛcā udakam abhimantrya ācāmayati  anṛtam uktvā ācamanam karoti
translated: Having enchanted water with the verse What is below that, he makes one sip water.🔽Having told a lie, one performs the sipping of water.
Having committed a lie in trade, one performs the sipping of water.
There is no fault of lying.

analyzed: anṛta vacana doṣa śamana śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The pacification for removing the fault of speaking untruth is complete.
Whatever is yours, O Earth...
Thus he digs...

original: yatra kvacit khanati tatra sarvatra 'yatte bhūme' ityṛcā khanati gṛhanidhau vā sthūṇāgarte vā snānārthaṃ mṛttikāgrahaprakaraṇārthaṃ sarvatra
analyzed: yatra kvacid khanati tatra sarvatra yat te bhūme iti ṛcā khanati gṛha nidhau vā sthūṇā garte vā snāna artham mṛttikā graha prakaraṇa artham sarvatra
translated: Wherever he digs, there everywhere he digs with the verse Whatever is yours, O Earth, in a household treasure, in a hole for a pillar, or for the sake of bathing, for the purpose of taking clay, everywhere
The digging of clay is prescribed.
With the verse Whatever is lacking... he pours in...

original: 'yatta ūnam' ityṛcā gṛhādi pūrayati sarvatrānena vidhānena pūraṇam /🔽khanane khananadoṣo na bhavati /
analyzed: yat te ūnam iti ṛcā gṛha ādi pūrayati sarvatra anena vidhānena pūraṇam  khanane khanana doṣaḥ na bhavati
translated: With the verse Whatever is lacking, he fills in houses and so on, everywhere by this prescription the filling in.🔽In digging, there is no fault of digging.
In filling, there is no fault of filling.
The pacification of digging and filling is complete.
Now the pacification of birds is described

original: prehi pra hara iti kāpiñjalāni svastyayanāni bhavanti // / / //
analyzed: prehi pra haraḥ iti kāpiñjalāni svastyayanāni bhavanti
translated: Go forth, drive away... The Ka-piñjala oblations are for the sake of well-being...

original: prehi pra hara vā dāvān gṛhebhyaḥ svastaye /
analyzed: prehi pra hara vā dāvān gṛhebhyaḥ svastaye
translated: Go forth, drive away the fires from the houses for the sake of well-being.

analyzed: kapiñjala pradakṣiṇam śata patra abhi naḥ vada
translated: O Ka-piñjala, speak to us in a clockwise direction with a hundred leaves.

analyzed: bhadram vada dakṣiṇatas bhadram uttaratas vada
translated: Speak well from the south, speak well from the north,

original: bhadraṃ purastānno vada bhadraṃ paścāt kapiñjala //
analyzed: bhadram purastāt naḥ vada bhadram paścāt kapiñjala
translated: Speak good to us from the front, O Kapinjala, speak good from the back.

analyzed: śunam vada dakṣiṇatas śunam uttaratas vada
translated: Speak well from the right, speak well from the left.

original: śunaṃ purastānno vada śunaṃ paścāt kapiñjala //🔽bhadraṃ vada putrairbhadraṃ vada gṛheṣu ca /
analyzed: śunam purastāt naḥ vada śunam paścāt kapiñjala  bhadram vada putraiḥ bhadram vada gṛheṣu ca
translated: Speak well to us from the front, speak well from the back, O Kapinjala.🔽Speak good to us with our sons, speak good to us in our homes.

original: bhadramasmākaṃ vada bhadraṃ no abhayaṃ vada //🔽āvadaṃstvaṃ śakune bhadramā vada tūṣṇīmāsīnaḥ sumatiṃ cikiddhi naḥ /
analyzed: bhadram asmākam vada bhadram naḥ abhayam vada  āvadan tvam śakune bhadramāḥ vada tūṣṇīm āsīnaḥ sumatim cikiddhi naḥ
translated: Speak good to us, speak safety to us.🔽O bird, speaking, speak good to us. Sitting silently, seek good will for us.

original: yadutpatan vadasi karkariryathā bṛhadvadema vidathe suvīrāḥ //
analyzed: yat utpatan vadasi karkariḥ yathā bṛhat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
translated: When flying, as you cry out like a drum, may we speak grandly in the assembly with good sons.

original: yauvanāni mahayasi jigyuṣāmiva dundubhiḥ /🔽kapiñjala pradakṣiṇaṃ śatapatrābhi no vada iti kāpiñjalāni svastyayanāni bhavanti // / / //
analyzed: yauvanāni mahayasi jigyuṣām iva dundubhiḥ  kapiñjala pradakṣiṇam śata patra abhi naḥ vada iti kāpiñjalāni svastyayanāni bhavanti
translated: You magnify the youthful energies, as if a drum for the victorious.🔽O Kapinjala, speak to us with auspicious sounds like a hundred-petaled lotus. The Kapinjala blessings are for...

original: 'prehi pra hara vā dāvān' iti sūktena ṣaḍarcenāpaśabdaṃ śrutvā japati kapiñjalavāsitaṃ
analyzed: prehi pra hara vā dāvān iti sūktena ṣaḍarcena apaśabdam śrutvā japati kapiñjala vāsitam
translated: With the hymn Go forth, or carry the fires in six verses, one murmurs when hearing an inauspicious sound, the cry of a Kapinjala.

original: śrutvā grāme'raṇye pakṣivāsitaṃ śrutvā vā svayaṃ vā kruddhabhāṣaṇaṃ kṛtvānyasyāsadvacanaṃ
analyzed: śrutvā grāma iraṇye pakṣi vāsitam śrutvā vā svayam vā kruddha bhāṣaṇam kṛtvā anyasya asat vacanam
translated: Having heard the cry of a bird in a village or forest, or having oneself spoken angrily, the bad words of another,

original: śrutvā sāgovāse vā ulūkavāsane kapotavāsane pūrvato vottarato vā loke ninditaḥ /
analyzed: śrutvā sā a go vāse vā ulūka vāsane kapota vāsane pūrvatas vā uttaratas vā loke ninditaḥ
translated: Having heard, whether in a house by the sea, or in a house of owls, or in a house of pigeons, or in the east or north, one is censured in the world.

original: yatkiñcillokaviruddhaṃ dṛṣṭvā śrutvā vā sarvatra japane svastyayanaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yat kiñcid loka viruddham dṛṣṭvā śrutvā vā sarvatra japane svastyayanam bhavati
translated: Whatever is seen or heard to be contrary to the world, in all cases, by reciting, there is well-being.

original: 'prehi pra hara' iti sūktaṃ nityaṃ japati /
analyzed: prehi pra haraḥ iti sūktam nityam japati
translated: The verse Prehi pra hara one always recites.
One who desires well-being.
The daily recitation for well-being is completed.
The recitation for well-being against bad omens is completed.

original: yo abhyu babhruṇāyasi svapantamatsi puruṣaṃ śayānamagatsvalam /
analyzed: yaḥ abhi u babhruṇā āyasi svapantam atsi puruṣam śayānam agat svalam
translated: You who strike the sleeping man with the tawny one, you who bite the lying man, you who go to the trembling one,

original: ayasmayena brahmaṇāśmamayena varmaṇā paryasmān varuṇo dadhat ityabhyavakāśe saṃviśatyabhyavakāśe saṃviśati // / / //

analyzed: haviṣya bhakṣaṇa ādi kartā kārayitā patnī ca karoti
translated: The performer and the one who causes it to be done, along with the wife, perform the eating of sacrificial food and so on.

original: śvo bhūte yajñopavītī śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā yajñavāstu ca samprokṣya brahmaudanikamagniṃ mathitvā //
analyzed: śvas bhūte yajña upavītī śāntyudakam kṛtvā yajña vāstu ca samprokṣya brahmaudanikam agnim mathitvā
translated: On the next day, wearing the sacred thread, having performed the Shanti water rite, having sprinkled the sacrificial ground, having churned the fire for the Brahman's oblation,
Whatever the gods do in their anger,
Whatever the learned ones do, whatever the unlearned ones do,
Whatever is not measured, not accepted,

analyzed: iti etaiḥ tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ anvārabdhe dātari pūrṇahomam juhuyāt
translated: Thus, with these three hymns, the giver should offer a full oblation when the Anvārambha is begun.
Now, the sacrificial ground.

original: tadyat samaṃ samūlamavidagdhaṃ pratiṣṭhitaṃ prāgudakpravaṇamākṛtiloṣṭavalmīkenāstīrya darbhaiśca lomabhiḥ paśūnām // / / //
analyzed: tat yat samam sa mūlam a vidagdham pratiṣṭhitam prāc udak pravaṇam ākṛtiloṣṭa valmīkena āstīrya darbhaiḥ ca lomabhiḥ paśūnām
translated: That which is level, with roots, unburned, firm, sloping towards the northeast, having covered it with a lump of earth in the shape of an anthill, and with the hair of animals,

original: atha caturdaśyāṃ prātaryajñopavītī śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā devayajanaṃ samprokṣya ākṛtiloṣṭavalmīkenāstīrya devayajanaṃ darbhaiśca goaśvaajaavilomāni
analyzed: atha caturdaśyām prātaryajña upavītī śāntyudakam kṛtvā devayajanam samprokṣya ākṛtiloṣṭa valmīkena āstīrya devayajanam darbhaiḥ ca go aśva aja avilomāni
translated: Then, on the fourteenth day, in the morning, wearing the sacred thread over the right shoulder, having performed the Śānti water rite, having sprinkled the sacrificial ground, having covered it with a lump of earth in the shape of an anthill, having spread the sacrificial grass on the sacrificial ground, the hair of cows, horses, goats, and sheep in the reverse order,
having spread them.

analyzed: pālāśa mayī araṇi dvayena agnim manthayet yajamānaḥ
translated: The sacrificer should churn the fire with two kindling sticks made of Palāśa wood.
O Agni, be born.
He recites this while churning.
The wife bows down to the mantra.
And to the sacrificer.

original: 'agne jāyasva' ityṛcā manthantāvanumantrayate /🔽'agne jāyasvāraṇikā nāthiteyaṃ brahmaudanaṃ pacati putrakāmā /
analyzed: agne jāyasva iti ṛcā manthantau anumantrayate  agne jāyasva araṇikā nāthitā iyam brahmaudanam pacati putra kāmā
translated: He recites the mantra O Agni, be born while churning.🔽O Agni, be born. This woman, seeking a son, is churning you, cooking Brahma's rice.

original: agne jāyasva keśavadattaśarmā nāthito'yaṃ brahmaudanaṃ pacati putrakāmaḥ' /
analyzed: agne jāyasva keśava datta śarmā nāthi toyam brahmaudanam pacati putra kāmaḥ
translated: O Agni, be born. This man, seeking a son, is churning you, cooking Brahma's rice.

original: evaṃ patnīnāmayajamānanāmagrahaṇaṃ kṛtvā prathame'rdharce //🔽kṛṇuta dhūmam / /🔽iti dhūmam // / / //
analyzed: evam patnīnām a yajamāna nāma grahaṇam kṛtvā prathama irdharce  kṛṇuta dhūmam  iti dhūmam
translated: Having thus mentioned the names of the wives and the sacrificer in the first half-verse,🔽he should recite the verse beginning with Make smoke.

analyzed: tatas kṛṇuta dhūmam iti ṛcā dhūmam anumantrayate  agni janiṣṭhā  iti jātam
translated: With the verse Make smoke he follows the smoke.

original: 'agne'janiṣṭhā' iti tribhiḥ pādairjātam /🔽'asyai rayim' iti pādena patnīmanumantrayate //🔽samiddho agne / /
analyzed: agni janiṣṭhāḥ iti tribhiḥ pādaiḥ jātam  asyai rayim iti pādena patnīm anumantrayate  samiddhaḥ agne
translated: With the three feet beginning with O Agni, you were born he follows the born fire.
With the foot For this wealth he follows the wife.

original: 'samiddho agne samidhā' iti tribhiḥ pādaiḥ samidhyamānamanumantrayate /
analyzed: samiddhaḥ agne samidhā iti tribhiḥ pādaiḥ samidhyamānam anumantrayate
translated: With the three feet beginning with O Agni, kindled with fuel he follows the kindling fire.

analyzed: uttamam nākam iti pādam dātāram vācayati
translated: With the foot The highest vault he makes the giver recite.

original: evaṃ brahmaudanikamagniṃ mathitvā sthaṇḍile'gniṃ kṛtvā abhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā 'yaddevā devaheḍanam' /
analyzed: evam brahmaudanikam agnim mathitvā sthaṇḍile ignim kṛtvā abhyātāna antam kṛtvā yat devāḥ deva heḍanam
translated: Having thus churned out the Brahmanical fire and having placed the fire on the sacrificial ground, having performed the rites up to the pouring of clarified butter, he should offer the Pūrṇāhuti while the giver is engaged in the recitation of the three hymns beginning with Whatever offence against the gods.
With the three hymns beginning with Whatever learned ones.
With the three hymns beginning with Unmeasured, unknown.

analyzed: iti etaiḥ tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ anvārabdhe dātari pūrṇahomam juhuyāt
translated: He should offer the Pūrṇāhuti while the giver is engaged in the recitation.
The procedure for the Pūrṇāhuti is stated in the Śāntikalpa.

original: agnīnādhāsyamānaḥ savān vā dāsyan saṃvatsaraṃ brahmaudanikamagniṃ dīpayati //🔽ahorātrau vā //
analyzed: agnīn ādhāsyamānaḥ savān vā dāsyan saṃvatsaram brahmaudanikam agnim dīpayati  ahar rātrau vā
translated: One who is about to install the fires or who is about to perform the Savanas kindles the Brahmo-danika fire for a year.🔽Or for a day and night.
Or as one wishes.
But a year is praised.

analyzed: sava agni senā agnī tādarthikau nirmathyau vā bhavataḥ
translated: And the Savana fire and the Senagni are either produced for that purpose or are produced by churning.
And both are known as the Upasanas.
In that (fire) one should offer clarified butter with the Devagati (hymn).
One should put on the Samidhs.
Or on the chips.

original: tasmin yathākāmaṃ savān dadātyekaṃ dvau sarvān vā //
analyzed: tasmin yathākāmam savān dadāti ekam dvau sarvān vā
translated: In that (fire) one gives the Savanas as one wishes, one, two, or all.

analyzed: api vā ekaikam ātma āśiṣaḥ dātāram vācayati
translated: Or he makes each one recite the blessings for the giver.

analyzed: para āśiṣaḥ unumantraṇam anirdiṣṭa āśiṣaḥ ca
translated: The benediction is recited by the other, and the blessings are not specified.
The two givers perform the rites.
He recites after them according to the characteristics.

analyzed: ubhaya liṅgaiḥ ubhau pum liṅgaiḥ dātāram strī liṅgaiḥ patnīm
translated: With both genders, both with masculine genders, the giver, with feminine genders, the wife.
Except for the Urdhvamsatya and the Samprishya.

analyzed: tatas yat devāḥ deva heḍanam  iti anuvākena ājyam juhuyāt  samidhobhyā ādadhyāt
translated: Then with the Anuvaka beginning with 'yad devā devagati'🔽one should offer clarified butter.🔽One should put on the Samidhs.
Or one should put on the chips.

original: evaṃ brahmaudanikamagniṃ mathitvā sthaṇḍile'gniṃ kṛtvābhyātānāntaṃ kṛtvā dīpayati ahorātraṃ vā yāthākāmī vā /
analyzed: evam brahmaudanikam agnim mathitvā sthaṇḍile ignim kṛtvā abhyātāna antam kṛtvā dīpayati ahar rātram vā yāthākāmī vā
translated: Having thus churned out the fire from the Brahmaudana, having made the fire on the ground, having performed the rites up to the Abhyarana, he kindles it for a day and night or as much as he desires.
But a year is praised.
Go forth, O woman!

analyzed: iti uda hṛtam sampreṣyati anuguptām alaṅkṛtām
translated: Having recited this, he sends her, well-covered and adorned.

analyzed: atha amāvāsyāyām prātar udaka āharaṇam karoti
translated: Then in the morning on the new moon day, he performs the bringing of water.

original: brāhmaṇīmalaṅkṛtvā tāṃ sādhuvādinīmudakaghaṭaṃ haste gṛhītāṃ 'parehi nāri' ityṛcodakagatāṃ preṣayati //
analyzed: brāhmaṇīm alaṅkṛtvā tām sādhu vādinīm udaka ghaṭam haste gṛhītām parehi nāri iti ṛcā udaka gatām preṣayati
translated: Having adorned a Brahmin woman, he sends her, speaking well, holding a water pot in her hand, with the verse Go forth, O woman! to the water.🔽They have come

analyzed: ā imāḥ aguḥ iti āyatīm anumantrayate
translated: he recites the following verse.🔽They have come

analyzed: ā imāḥ aguḥ iti pādena udaka pūrṇām nārīm anumantrayate
translated: with this half-verse he recites after the woman filled with water.
Rise up, O woman!🔽he sends his wife.🔽Rise up, O woman!

original: 'uttiṣṭha nāri' ityādi 'ā tvāgan yajñaḥ' ityantena dātrīṃ preṣayati //
analyzed: uttiṣṭha nāri ityādi ā tvā agan yajñaḥ ityantena dātrīm preṣayati
translated: with this and the following verses up to The sacrifice has come to you he sends the giver.
Take hold of each pot!
he receives.🔽Take hold of each pot!

original: 'prati kumbhaṃ gṛbhāya' iti pādārdhena jalakumbhaṃ gṛhadvāre pratigrāhayati dātrī //
analyzed: prati kumbham gṛbhāye iti pāda ardhena jala kumbham gṛha dvāre pratigrāhayati dātrī
translated: with this half-verse the giver makes the woman receive the water pot at the door of the house.
A share of strength!
Thus he places it.

original: 'ūrjo bhāgaḥ' iti pādena bhūmau nidadhāti uttarataḥ /
analyzed: ūrjaḥ bhāgaḥ iti pādena bhūmau nidadhāti uttaratas
translated: With the verse, 'A share of strength' (Taitt. Samh., loc. cit.), he places it on the ground to the north.

analyzed: avyasaḥ ca barhiḥ lavanam  vedi uttaravedi agni pratiṣṭhāpanam
translated: And the 'unfailing' (verse).🔽The cutting of the sacrificial grass.
The establishing of the Vedi, the Uttaravedi, and the sacrificial fire.🔽The putting of fuel on the fire.🔽The taking of the vow.

analyzed: pavitrakaraṇam  pavitreṇa idhma prokṣaṇam  idhma upasamādhānam
translated: The making of the two strainers.🔽The sprinkling of the fuel with the two strainers.🔽The putting of fuel on the fire.
The sprinkling of the sacrificial grass.🔽The Brahman's seat.🔽The choosing of the Brahman.
The establishing of the Brahman.🔽The strewing (of the Vedi).
The sprinkling of the strewn (Vedi).🔽The sacrificer's seat.
The consecration of the water-pot.
Then he places to the south a new garment,
together with gold.

original: tatra dve udapātre nihite bhavato vedimadhye agnerdakṣiṇataḥ /
analyzed: tatra dve uda pātre nihite bhavataḥ vedi madhye agneḥ dakṣiṇatas
translated: There two water-pots are placed in the middle of the Vedi, to the south of the fire.

original: ahatavāsāḥ sahiraṇyāṃ vastraghaṭikāṃ kṛtvā stṛṇāti tadupari dakṣiṇārtham /
analyzed: ahata vāsāḥ sa hiraṇyām vastra ghaṭikām kṛtvā stṛṇāti tad upari dakṣiṇā artham
translated: Having put on a new garment, having made a cloth-case with gold, he strews (the Vedi) on it, for the sake of the sacrificial fee.

analyzed: dakṣiṇatas dakṣiṇatas uda pātra dvayam sthāpayati
translated: He places two water-pots to the south, to the south.

analyzed: pūrvāhṇe bāhyatas śānta vṛkṣasya idhmam prāñcam upasamādhāya
translated: In the forenoon, outside, having put a piece of wood from a tree which has good fruit on the fire, with its top to the east,

original: parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya barhirudapātramupasādya paricaraṇenājyaṃ paricarya //
analyzed: parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya barhiḥ uda pātram upasādya paricaraṇena ājyam paricarya
translated: Having strewn (the altar), having sprinkled (the water), having strewn Barhis grass, having placed the water-pot, having clarified the ghee by means of the Paribhâṣa (verse),
having offered the regular oblations in front (of the fire), and the two Âgya portions,

original: tataḥ prakṛtamudapātraṃ jāṅmāyanaṃ vedyāṃ bahirbrahmāgrataḥ dakṣiṇamanyadantaramanyadantaraṃ yato'dhicariṣyan bhavati /
analyzed: tatas prakṛtam udapātram vedyām bahis brahma agratas dakṣiṇam anyat antaram anyat antaram yatas adhicariṣyan bhavati
translated: then the water-pot which is used in the regular (sacrifices), the water-pot which is used in the birth-rites, on the sacrificial ground, outside (the altar), in front (of the fire), to the south (of the Âhavanîya), one on the other, so that he who is going to perform the rite (shall be able to reach the water-pot) from within (the altar).

original: bāhyaṃ jāṅmāyanaṃ kṛtvā paricaraṇenājyaṃ paricarya nityān purastāddhomān hutvājyabhāgau ca hutvā //
analyzed: bāhyam kṛtvā paricaraṇena ājyam paricarya nityān purastāddhomān hutvā ājyabhāgau ca hutvā
translated: Having placed the water-pot which is used in the birth-rites outside (the altar), having clarified the ghee by means of the Paribhâṣa (verse), having offered the regular oblations in front (of the fire), and the two Âgya portions,

original: paścādagneḥ palpūlitavihitamaukṣaṃ vānaḍuhaṃ vā rohitaṃ carma prāggrīvamuttaraloma paristīrya //
analyzed: paścāt agneḥ palpūlita vihita maukṣam vā ānaḍuham vā rohitam carma prāk grīvam uttara loma paristīrya
translated: having spread to the west of the fire a skin of a black antelope, or of a cow, or of a spotted deer, with the neck to the east, the hairy side upwards,
he prepares the two strainers.

analyzed: darbha avapracchinna prāntau prakṣālya anulomam anumārṣṭi
translated: Having washed the two Darbha blades, the ends of which are not cut off, he wipes (the skin) from the front upwards,🔽(with the formula), 'This earth' ,

original: iyaṃ mahī / / iti carmāstṛṇāti prāggrīvamuttaraloma //🔽pumān puṃsaḥ / /
analyzed: iyam mahī iti carma āstṛṇāti prāk grīvam uttara loma  pumān puṃsaḥ
translated: and he spreads the skin, with the neck to the east, the hairy side upwards.
(The sacrificer) touches (the skin) with (the formula), 'The male of the male' .
(The Adhvaryu) makes the sacrificer mount the skin.🔽(The sacrificer) calls (the wife).
(The Adhvaryu) causes the wife to call (the sacrificer) for the third (time).
(The sacrificer) touches (the wife) with (the formula), 'The female of the female' .🔽(The Adhvaryu) makes the sacrificer descend (from the skin).
Thus he places the water-pot on the skin.

original: tataḥ paścādagneḥ palpūlitavihitamaukṣaṃ vānaḍuhaṃ vā rohitaṃ carma prastṛṇantaṃ 'iyaṃ mahī' ityṛcā yajamānaṃ vācayati /
analyzed: tatas paścāt agneḥ palpūlita vihita maukṣam vā ānaḍuham vā rohitam carma prastṛṇantam iyam mahī iti ṛcā yajamānam vācayati
translated: Then, to the west of the fire, he makes the sacrificer recite the verse This earth while spreading a red skin of a bull or a cow, washed and prepared.

original: 'ṛṣipraśiṣṭā' iti pādena patnī udakaghaṭaṃ carmaṇi nidhāpayati //
analyzed: ṛṣi praśiṣṭāḥ iti pādena patnī udaka ghaṭam carmaṇi nidhāpayati
translated: With the foot Taught by the sages, the wife places the water-pot on the skin.
Then the sons of the waters.
Thus they descend with their sons.
Eastward, eastward.
As stated in the mantra.
They go around the water-pot with four (verses).
Firm in every direction, the Virāj.
They worship.
Like a father his sons.

analyzed: iti avarohya bhūmim tena udaka arthān kurvanti
translated: Having descended to the ground with this, they perform the water rites.
Again, silently he places it on the ground.
One should perform all rites with that water.
They sprinkle with the purifying (verses).
May they purify me. Purified by Vāyu.
Vaisvānara by the rays.
This is the group of purifying (verses).

original: etena dātā patnī apatyāni ca pavitreṇa samprokṣayet //
analyzed: etena dātā patnī apatyāni ca pavitreṇa samprokṣayet
translated: With this purifying (verse) the giver should sprinkle the wife and the children.
Now the implements for the oblations
He sprinkles the sacrificial substance on the skin with the tips of Darbha grass.

original: dātā muṣṭiprasṛtāñjalidvayaparimite triguṇān vrīhīṃścarmaṇi kṛtvā darbhapavitrābhyāṃ tūṣṇīṃ carmahaviḥ samprokṣati /
analyzed: dātā muṣṭi prasṛta añjali dvaya parimite triguṇān vrīhīn carmaṇi kṛtvā darbha pavitrābhyām tūṣṇīm carma haviḥ samprokṣati
translated: The giver, having made three times as many Vrihi grains as can be contained in two closed fists, on the skin, silently sprinkles the sacrificial substance on the skin with the two Pavitras of Darbha grass.
Then he makes three divisions on the skin.
He gives to the appointed Anjati for the Ancestors.

original: tato devapitṛmanuṣyatrayaṃ patnī anajānatyai prayattaiḥ prayacchati /
analyzed: tatas deva pitṛ manuṣya trayam patnī an a jānatyai prayattaiḥ prayacchati
translated: Then the wife gives to the three, the gods, the ancestors, and men, with the Anjati for the Ancestors.
The performer gives the command.
He divides them into three parts.
He places them in the heaps of Vrihi.

original: teṣāṃ yaḥ pitṝṇāṃ taṃ śrāddhaṃ karoti //
analyzed: teṣām yaḥ pitṝṇām tam śrāddham karoti
translated: Of them, he performs the Sraddha for the ancestors.
He feeds the Brahmanas for the men.
He offers the one for the gods to the fire.

original: iti dakṣiṇaṃ jānvācyāparājitābhimukhaḥ prahvo vā muṣṭiprasṛtāñjalibhiḥ kumbhyāṃ nirvapati // / / //
analyzed: iti dakṣiṇam jānu ācya aparājitā abhimukhaḥ prahvaḥ vā muṣṭi prasṛta añjalibhiḥ kumbhyām nirvapati
translated: Thus, placing his right knee on the ground, facing the Aparajita (plant), or bending down, he pours out of the pot with closed fists and extended palms.

original: vrīhīn vibhāgeṣu kartā 'tredhā bhāgo nihitaḥ' iti tribhiḥ pādairvibhāgān devapitṛmanuṣyasambandhānanumantrayate /
analyzed: vrīhīn vibhāgeṣu kartā tredhā bhāgaḥ nihitaḥ iti tribhiḥ pādaiḥ vibhāgān deva pitṛ manuṣya sambandhān anumantrayate
translated: In the divisions, he divides the rice, with the three feet, 'The threefold division is laid down here', he recites the divisions relating to gods, ancestors, and men.

analyzed: yaḥ devānām iti pādena patnīm anumantrayate
translated: With the foot 'He who is of the gods', he recites after the wife.

analyzed: yaḥ pitṛ bhāgaḥ tena avabhṛtha ante vṛddhiśrāddham karoti
translated: With the part belonging to the ancestors, he performs the Vrddhi Sraddha at the end of the Avabhrittha.

analyzed: yaḥ manuṣyāṇām bhāgaḥ tam brāhmaṇān bhojayati
translated: With the part belonging to men, he feeds the Brahmanas.
With the two (Mantras), 'In the fire' (he cooks).

analyzed: yaḥ devānām iti etena vakṣyamāṇam karma kuryāt
translated: With 'He who is of the gods', he should perform the rite to be described.

original: dakṣiṇaṃ jānvācyāparājitābhimukhaḥ prahvo vā muṣṭinā prasṛtināñjalinā yasyāṃ śrapayiṣyan syāt tayā caturtham //
analyzed: dakṣiṇam jānu ācya aparājitā abhimukhaḥ prahvaḥ vā muṣṭinā prasṛtinā añjalinā yasyām śrapayiṣyan syāt tayā caturtham
translated: Having bent the right knee, facing the Aparajita, or stooping, with the fist, the open hand, or the joined palms, with that in which he is going to cook, he cooks the fourth (oblation).

original: śarāveṇa catuḥśarāvaṃ devasya tvā savituḥ prasava ṛṣibhyastvārṣeyebhyastvaikarṣaye tvā juṣṭaṃ nirvapāmi // / / //
analyzed: śarāveṇa catur śarāvam devasya tvā savituḥ prasave ṛṣibhyaḥ tu ārṣeyebhyaḥ tvā eka ṛṣaye tvā juṣṭam nirvapāmi
translated: With the pot, the four-pot (oblation), 'By the impulse of the god Savitri, with the arms of the Asvins, with the hands of Pusan, I pour out (the oblation) dear to the Rishis, to the Rishis' sons, to the single Rishis.'

original: tato nirvapati 'devasya tvā savituḥ prasave'śvinorbāhubhyāṃ pūṣṇo hastābhyāmṛṣibhyastvārṣeyebhyastvaikaṛṣaye tvā juṣṭaṃ nirvapāmi' //
analyzed: tatas nirvapati devasya tvā savituḥ prasava īśvinoḥ bāhubhyām pūṣṇaḥ hastābhyām ṛṣibhyaḥ tu ārṣeyebhyaḥ tvā eka ṛṣaye tvā juṣṭam nirvapāmi
translated: Then he pours out (the oblation), 'By the impulse of the god Savitri, with the arms of the Asvins, with the hands of Pusan, I pour out (the oblation) dear to the Rishis, to the Rishis' sons, to the single Rishis.'
May the Vasus pour thee out with the Gayatri metre,

analyzed: ūrjam a kṣitam a kṣīyamāṇam upajīvyāsam iti dātāram vācayati
translated: May I live on the inexhaustible strength that is not consumed. He makes the giver recite this.
Rudras with the Tristubh metre,

Here, O ancestors, he murmurs for each ball.

analyzed: atra patnyaḥ mādayadhvam yathābhāgam yathālokam āvṛṣāyadhvam iti
translated: Here, O wives, rejoice! As your share, as your light, be vigorous.

analyzed: atra patnyaḥ iti patnī piṇḍe japati  yaḥ asau antaragniḥ bhavati tam pradakṣiṇam avekṣya tisraḥ tāmīḥ tāmyati
translated: Here, O wives, he murmurs for the wife's ball.🔽Having looked around the inner fire, he should look at those three.

analyzed: yaḥ asau antaragniḥ bhavati tam pradakṣiṇam avekṣya trīn prāṇāyāmān kuryāt
translated: Having looked around the inner fire, he should perform three breath-control exercises.

analyzed: pratiparyāvṛtya amīmadanta pitaraḥ yathābhāgam yathālokam āvṛṣāyiṣata iti

analyzed: amīmadanta patnyaḥ yathābhāgam yathālokam āvṛṣāyiṣata iti
translated: The wives rejoiced, as according to their share, according to their light, were satisfied.

analyzed: punar amīmadanta iti piṇḍeṣu upatiṣṭhate  āpaḥ agnim iti adbhiḥ agnim avasicya
translated: Again, with 'They rejoiced,' he stands by the balls.🔽The waters the fire. Having sprinkled the fire with water with the verse 'The waters the fire,'

analyzed: āpaḥ agnim iti ṛcā adbhiḥ agnim avasicya
translated: With the verse 'The waters the fire,' having sprinkled the fire with water,
Satisfying the son, the grandson,

analyzed: iti ācāmata mama pratatāmahāḥ tatāmahāḥ tatāḥ sa patnīkāḥ tṛpyantu ācāmantu iti prasavyam pariṣicya
translated: Having sprinkled counter-sunwise, with 'May my great-great-grandfathers, great-grandfathers, grandfathers, together with their wives, be satisfied; may they sip water,'

original: 'putraṃ pautram' ityṛcā 'ācāmata mama pratatāmahāstatāmahāstatāḥ sapatnīkāstṛpyantvācāmantu' iti bhājanaṃ prakṣālya tena piṇḍopari savyaṃ pariṣicya
analyzed: putram pautram iti ṛcā ācāmata mama pratatāmahāḥ tatāmahāḥ tatāḥ sa patnīkāḥ tṛpyantu ācāmantu iti bhājanam prakṣālya tena piṇḍa upari savyam pariṣicya
translated: Having washed the vessel with the verse 'The son, the grandson,' with 'May my great-great-grandfathers, great-grandfathers, grandfathers, together with their wives, be satisfied; may they sip water,' having sprinkled counter-sunwise with that over the balls,

original: vīrān me pratatāmahā datta vīrān me tatāmahā datta vīrān me pitaro datta pitṝn vīrān yācati // / / //
analyzed: vīrān me pratatāmahāḥ datta vīrān me tatāmahāḥ datta vīrān me pitaraḥ datta pitṝn vīrān yācati
translated: He asks for the heroes of his great-great-grandfathers, the heroes of his great-grandfathers, the heroes of his grandfathers, the heroes of the fathers.

analyzed: vīrān me pratatāmahāḥ iti piṇḍān upatiṣṭhate
translated: With 'The heroes of my great-great-grandfathers,' he stands by the balls.
Salutations to you, O Fathers.🔽Thus he worships.

original: akṣan / / ityuttarasicamavadhūya // / / //🔽'akṣannamīmadanta' ityṛcā uttarasicamavakuryāt /🔽parā yāta / / iti parāyāpayati // / / //
analyzed: akṣan iti uttara sicam avadhūya  akṣan amīmadanta iti ṛcā uttara sicam avakuryāt  parā yāta iti parāyāpayati
translated: Having shaken the northern ladle, with the verse They have eaten, they have rejoiced,🔽he should perform the northern ladle with the verse They have eaten, they have rejoiced.🔽With the verse Go away, he sends away.

analyzed: parā yātaḥ iti ṛcā pitṝn visarjayet
translated: With the verse Go away, he should dismiss the Fathers.

original: ataḥ pitryupavītī yajñopavītī yanna idaṃ pitṛbhiḥ saha mano'bhūt tadupāhvayāmi iti mana upāhvayati // / / //
analyzed: atas pitryupavītī yajña upavītī yat naḥ idam pitṛbhiḥ saha manaḥ bhūt tat upāhvayāmi iti manaḥ upāhvayati
translated: From there, wearing the sacred thread like a Brahmin, with the sacred thread on the right shoulder, he invokes the mind, saying What mind I had in common with the Fathers, that I invoke.
Then, wearing the sacred thread like a Brahmin.
In the eleventh, the ninth section.
We invoke the mind indeed with the Narashamsa hymn.
And with the thoughts of the Fathers.

original: ā na etu manaḥ punaḥ kratve dakṣāya jīvase /
analyzed: ā naḥ etu manaḥ punar kratve dakṣāya jīvase
translated: May the mind come back to us again for wisdom, for strength, for life,
And to see the sun for a long time.

translated: Those kinsmen who are well-disposed, living among the living, who belong to me,

He gives the first ball to a learned Brahmin.

translated: Food is the bond of life, with that I bind you to me.🔽 With the verse, Come hither, he gives the last rice grains to the maid servant.

translated: We will kindle this one, being long-lived and of good splendour.🔽You, O Agni, are invoked.

translated: With these he puts the kindling sticks.

analyzed: abhūt dūtaḥ iti ṛcā agnim pratyānayati
translated: With the verse He has become a messenger he brings back the fire.

original: yadi sarvaḥ praṇītaḥ syād dakṣiṇāgnau tvetadāhitāgneḥ // / / //🔽gṛhyeṣvanāhitāgneḥ // / / //
analyzed: yadi sarvaḥ praṇītaḥ syāt dakṣiṇāgnau tu etat āhitāgneḥ  gṛhyeṣu anāhitāgneḥ
translated: If the entire (rite) is to be performed, this (is done) in the southern fire of one who has established the sacred fires.🔽In the case of one who has not established the sacred fires, in the domestic (fire).
The offering in the case of one who has not established the sacred fires is in the domestic (fire).

analyzed: idam cit me kṛtam asti idam cit śaknavāni
translated: This much have I done, this much I am able to do,
may the fathers also know this.

translated: This much have I done - with this mantra he worships the fire.
From which womb - with this.🔽The Pindapitryajña is completed.

analyzed: pratipatti artham śarīrasya pitṛ medhasya karmaṇaḥ
translated: For the sake of maintaining the body, for the sake of the rite of the ancestral offering,

The eleventh chapter of the Dasami Kanda.
Thus ends the eleventh chapter in the Koushika Padhati.
Now, the twelfth chapter.
Madhuparka

analyzed: ācārye gahama āgate idam karma karoti
translated: When the teacher comes to the house, he performs this rite.

The giver says:
Desiring to offer Madhuparka.

Bring the Darbha grass.

Then prepare the seats.

analyzed: sa yāvataḥ manyeta tāvataḥ upādāya vivicya samparyāpya mūlāni ca prāntāni ca yathā vistīrṇaḥ iva syāt iti upotkṛṣya madhyadeśebhisannahyati
translated: He cuts them off, beginning from the root and the end, as many as he thinks fit, and having separated and arranged them, he fastens them together in the middle part, so as to form a bundle as large as he wishes.

translated: With the formula, 'By truth I bind thee, by penance I bind thee, by work I bind thee,' he binds them together.

analyzed: atha ha sṛjati atisṛṣṭaḥ dveṣṭā yaḥ asmān dveṣṭi yam ca vayam dviṣmaḥ

translated: With the formula, 'Scattered is the hater,' he makes the bundles.

analyzed: viṣṭarān kṛtvā asya ca dātuḥ iti dātāram īkṣate

analyzed: tatas dātā kurute pādyam bho iti

analyzed: hiraṇyavarṇābhiḥ pratimantrya dakṣiṇam pādam prathamam prakarṣati mayi brahma ca tapaḥ ca dhārayāṇi iti

translated: Having muttered this hymn, the teacher again recites the water.

translated: Salutations to the slayers of the gods, one should offer the ghee.

analyzed: devatāḥ nṛtyanti cyotanti hasanti gāyanti prasthijyanti pradhūpayanti unmīlayanti

having gone half the distance of the forest,
having established the eastern furrow,

translated: If any changes are seen in milk, rice, or oblations,

analyzed: āhatāḥ ca na vādyante acalāni calanti vā
translated: Or if struck they do not sound, or if immovable things move,

A stone falling into a well, a mountain not moving,
The conjunction of the stars, and changes in the moon and sun,

translated: A woman suckling a woman, the birth of rice, fear,🔽The withdrawal of the senses, the wandering of trees, stones, and plants,

translated: The appearance of birds, fish, animals, and birds in water,

translated: The confusion of wombs, the rain of flesh and blood,

translated: The burning of fire without fuel, and the rain from the sky,🔽The burning of weapons, the descent of dry trees from the caitya,

analyzed: gīta vāditra śabdāḥ tu yatra syuḥ animittataḥ
translated: The sounds of singing and musical instruments that occur without cause,

analyzed: ye ca anye kiñcid utpātāḥ jāyante vikṛta ātmakāḥ
translated: And any other portents that arise with a distorted nature,

analyzed: teṣām sarveṣām utpātānām eṣā śāntiḥ vidhīyate
translated: For all of these portents, this pacification is prescribed.

original: candraprātipadike grahayuddhe grahasaṅgrahe rāhucāre ketucāre rāhuketulakṣaṇe kūmavibhāge🔽maṇḍaleṣu digdāheṣu ulkāpataneṣu vidyutpataneṣu vidyuddarśaneṣu nirghātapataneṣu
analyzed: candra prātipadike graha yuddhe graha saṅgrahe rāhu cāre ketu cāre rāhu ketu lakṣaṇe kūma vibhāge  maṇḍaleṣu digdāheṣu ulkā pataneṣu vidyut pataneṣu vidyut darśaneṣu nirghāta pataneṣu

translated: In the eclipses of the moon and sun, in the characteristics of the calamities of the stars and planets, in the characteristics of calamities, in the characteristics of sudden rain,

Similarly, in the western half.
Having placed (the fire) in the northern half, he should offer with the Vāstospati (verses).
Having brought the remnants (of the oblations) to the place where it has caved in, having placed (the fire there), he should offer the oblations.
Having sprinkled the place where it has caved in with the water of appeasement,
he should give those (cows) to a Brahmin.

analyzed: sīram vaiśya uśvam prādeśikaḥ grāma varam rājā
translated: A plough to a Vaisya, a horse to a local king, and the best village to a king.

analyzed: tāsām etat dvādaśa rātram sandugdham navanītam nidadhāti

In all rituals, the opinion of Dārila is that

analyzed: anudaka deśe yadi atiśayena udakam dṛśyate
