analyzed: utthānam ca eva ketūnām vināśāya iti hi smṛtam
translated: It is said that the rising of the stars is for destruction.

analyzed: tasmāt ātharvaṇaiḥ mantraiḥ śamanam kārayet budhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the wise one should perform the pacification with the Atharvan mantras.
The sacrificial fee there is one's entire property.
Its redemption is as much as one can afford, or according to one's means.
The Ketu appeasement is recited in the Ketu ritual.

original: pañcatriṃśī kaṇḍikā // //🔽atha nakṣatrāṇi patanti tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: pañcatriṃśī kaṇḍikā  atha nakṣatrāṇi patanti tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: The thirty-fifth chapter.🔽Now, when the stars fall, the appeasement is recited there.

original: atha yatraitannakṣatrāṇi patāpatānīva bhavanti tatra juhuyāt // / / //
analyzed: atha yatra etat nakṣatrāṇi patāpatāni iva bhavanti tatra juhuyāt
translated: Then, when the stars there seem to be falling, one should offer into that.

original: yannakṣatraṃ patati jātavedaḥ somena rājñeṣiraṃ purastāt /
analyzed: yat nakṣatram patati jātavedaḥ somena rājñā iṣiram purastāt
translated: The star that falls, O all-knower, with Soma the king in front,

original: tasmānmāmagne pari pāhi ghorāt pra ṇo jāyantāṃ mithunāni rūpaśaḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt mām agne pari pāhi ghorāt pra naḥ jāyantām mithunāni rūpaśas
translated: from that, O Agni, protect me from the terrible one. Let the pairs be born from us in various forms.

original: indrāgnibhyāṃ svāhā iti hutvā // / / //🔽somo rājā savitā ca rājā ityetena sūktena juhuyāt // / / //
analyzed: indra agnibhyām svāhā iti hutvā  somaḥ rājā savitā ca rājā iti etena sūktena juhuyāt
translated: Having offered with Svâhâ to Indra and Agni,🔽one should offer with this hymn:

original: somo rājā savitā ca rājā bhuvo rājā bhuvanaṃ ca rājā /
analyzed: somaḥ rājā savitā ca rājā bhuvaḥ rājā bhuvanam ca rājā
translated: Soma the king, and Savitar the king, the king of the earth, and the king of the world,

original: śarvo rājā śarma ca rājā ta u naḥ śarma yachantu devāḥ //
analyzed: śarvaḥ rājā śarma ca rājā te u naḥ śarma yacchantu devāḥ
translated: Śarva the king, and Śarma the king, may those gods grant us protection.

analyzed: ādityaiḥ naḥ bṛhaspatiḥ bhagaḥ somena naḥ saha
translated: May the Âdityas, and Brhaspati, and Bhaga, and Soma with us,

original: viśve devā urvantarikṣaṃ ta u naḥ śarma yachantu devāḥ // / / //
analyzed: viśve devāḥ uru antarikṣam te u naḥ śarma yacchantu devāḥ
translated: the All-gods, and the wide atmosphere, may those gods grant us protection.
And the ignorant one, the one with a cut throat, and the one with a cut nose, as appropriate.

original: mā no viśve devā maruto hetimichata // / / //
analyzed: mā naḥ viśve devāḥ marutaḥ hetim ichata
translated: May the All-gods, the Maruts, not wish harm upon us.
One should give gold to the performer.
That is the expiation there.

analyzed: śāntyudaka ādi ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā yat nakṣatram patati jātavedaḥ iti ekā
translated: Having performed the Śānti water and up to the Ajyabhaga, he recites the one verse beginning with The constellation that falls, O all-knowing one.

analyzed: somaḥ rājā iti sūktena ājyam juhoti
translated: He offers clarified butter with the Sūkta beginning with Soma is the king.
The subsequent ritual is as in the Pārvaṇa and other rites.
One should give gold to the performer.
And cows and other things.

original: nakṣatrapatane uparyuparipatane bahuśaḥpatane rātrau vā divā vā sandhyāyāṃ vā nakṣatrapatane śāntiḥ samāptā /
analyzed: nakṣatra patane upari upari patane bahuśas patane rātrau vā divā vā sandhyāyām vā nakṣatra patane śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The Śānti is complete for the falling of a constellation, for falling one above the other, for falling many times, at night or during the day or in the evening, for the falling of a constellation.

original: sarvatra pūrvaṃ śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā tata uttaravedyādi karoti /
analyzed: sarvatra pūrvam śāntyudakam kṛtvā tatas uttaravedi ādi karoti
translated: Everywhere else, having first performed the Śānti water, he then performs the Uttaravedi and other rites.

original: kecit pradhānahomaṃ kṛtvā tataḥ śāntyudakaṃ karoti /
analyzed: kecid pradhāna homam kṛtvā tatas śāntyudakam karoti
translated: Some, having performed the principal Homa, then perform the Śānti water.
Then the subsequent ritual.

original: ṣaṭtriṃśī kaṇḍikā // //🔽atha māṃsamukho nipatati tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: ṣaṭtriṃśī kaṇḍikā  atha māṃsa mukhaḥ nipatati tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: The thirty-sixth chapter.🔽Now the Śānti is described for when a meat-faced [object] falls.🔽Then, where this meat-faced [object] falls, one should offer there...

analyzed: atha yatra etat māṃsa mukhaḥ nipatati tatra juhuyāt
translated: Then, wherever the mouth of the meat falls, one should offer it there.

original: ghoro vajro devasṛṣṭo na āgan yadvā gṛhān ghoramutā jagāma /
analyzed: ghoraḥ vajraḥ deva sṛṣṭaḥ naḥ āgan yat vā gṛhān ghoram uta ā jagāma
translated: The terrible thunderbolt created by the gods has come to us, or if it has gone to the houses, it is terrible.

original: tannirjagāma haviṣā ghṛtena śaṃ no astu dvipade śaṃ catuṣpade //
analyzed: tat nirjagāma haviṣā ghṛtena śam naḥ astu dvipade śam catuṣpade
translated: That has gone out with oblation and ghee. May it be well with our bipeds and quadrupeds.
Having offered with Svāhā to Rudra,
O Bhava and Śarva, be gracious, do not attack us.
One should offer with this hymn.
That is the expiation there.

original: tāsāmetad dvādaśarātraṃ sandugdhaṃ navanītaṃ nidadhāti /🔽trayodaśe'hani śāntyudakādyājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā yathāmuṃ navanītaṃ sauvarṇasthālyāṃ vilāpya sautraśāntirucyate /
analyzed: tāsām etat dvādaśa rātram sandugdham navanītam nidadhāti  trayodaśe hani śāntyudaka ādi ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā yathā amum navanītam sauvarṇa sthālyām vilāpya sautraśāntiḥ ucyate
translated: For twelve nights she keeps that churned milk, fresh butter, in a pot.🔽On the thirteenth day, after performing the Śānti water and other rites up to the Ajyabhaga, the fresh butter is melted in a golden vessel, and the Śānti is recited according to the Sūtra.

analyzed: śāntyudaka ādi ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā ghoraḥ vajraḥ iti ṛcā
translated: After performing the Śānti water and other rites up to the Ajyabhaga, with the verse The terrible thunderbolt,
O Bhava and Śarva,

analyzed: mṛḍatam iti sūktena ca ājyam juhuyāt
translated: one should offer clarified butter with the hymn Be gracious.
The subsequent ritual of the Parvan and other rites.

original: gṛdhrādiṣvāhipatati māṃsamukhaḥ māṃsaṃ cāgatagṛhe māṃsamukhe nipatanaśāntiḥ samāptā //
analyzed: gṛdhra ādiṣu āhi patati māṃsa mukhaḥ māṃsam ca āgata gṛhe māṃsa mukhe nipatana śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The pacification of a vulture or other bird falling on meat, and of meat falling in a house where meat is being eaten, is completed.

original: gṛhe grāme kṣetre vā nagare śirasi aṅge vā māṃsaṃ patati tatra śāntiḥ samāptā //
analyzed: gṛhe grāme kṣetre vā nagare śirasi aṅge vā māṃsam patati tatra śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: If meat falls in the house, village, field, city, on the head, or on the body, there the peace is completed.
The thirty-seventh chapter.

original: atha yatra anagnideśe agnidarśanaṃ bhavati tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha yatra anagni deśe agni darśanam bhavati tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, where there is the appearance of fire in a place without fire, the peace is stated there.

analyzed: atha yatra etat anagnau avabhāsaḥ bhavati tatra juhuyāt
translated: Now, where there is this appearance of fire in a place without fire, one should offer there.

original: yā te'vadīptivarūpā jātavedo'peto rakṣasāṃ bhāga eṣaḥ /
analyzed: yā jātaveda upetaḥ rakṣasām bhāgaḥ eṣaḥ
translated: The form of your blazing, O all-knower, is the share of the Rakshasas.

original: rakṣāṃsi tayā daha jātavedo yā naḥ prajāṃ manuṣyāṃ saṃ sṛjante //
analyzed: rakṣāṃsi tayā daha jātavedaḥ yā naḥ prajām manuṣyām sam sṛjante
translated: Burn the Rakshasas with that, O all-knower, who afflict our offspring and humans.
Having offered to Agni, Svâhâ,
Agni drives away the Rakshasas.
Thus is the expiation.

original: 'yā te'vadīptiḥ' ityekā 'agnī rakṣāṃsi' ityekā dvābhyāṃ juhuyāt /
analyzed: yā teva dīptiḥ iti ekā agniḥ rakṣāṃsi iti ekā dvābhyām juhuyāt
translated: With the two verses, The form of your blazing and Agni drives away the Rakshasas, one should offer.
The subsequent ritual of the Parvana and other (rites).
Having performed up to the Ajyabhaga ending with the water for peace,

original: anagnideśe gṛhe grāme kṣetre vā yadi śālāyāṃ pradṛśyate agnidarśanaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: anagni deśe gṛhe grāme kṣetre vā yadi śālāyām pradṛśyate agni darśanam ca bhavati
translated: if the appearance of fire is seen in a house, village, field, or in a hall in a place without fire, and the appearance of fire occurs,
and the appearance of fire is completed.
The thirty-eighth chapter.

analyzed: atha agni śabda karaṇe śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, when the word 'fire' is uttered, the peace offering is mentioned.

analyzed: atha yatra etat agniḥ śvasati iva tatra juhuyāt
translated: Then, where that fire seems to be breathing, one should offer there.

original: śvetā kṛṣṇā rohiṇī jātavedo yāste tanūstiraścīnā nirdahantīḥ śvasantīḥ /
analyzed: śvetā kṛṣṇā rohiṇī jātavedaḥ yāḥ te tanūḥ tiraścīnāḥ nirdahantīḥ śvasantīḥ
translated: The white, the black, the red, O all-knower, those bodies of yours that burn obliquely, that burn, that breathe,

original: rakṣāṃsi tābhirdaha jātavedo yā naḥ prajāṃ manuṣyāṃ saṃ sṛjante //
analyzed: rakṣāṃsi tābhiḥ daha jātavedaḥ yā naḥ prajām manuṣyām sam sṛjante
translated: with them burn the Rakshasas, O all-knower, those that afflict our offspring, those that afflict men.
Having offered to Agni Svāhā,
Agni drives away the Rakshasas.
Thus is the expiation.

analyzed: śāntyudakam ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā śvetā kṛṣṇā iti ṛcā agneḥ iva asya
translated: Having performed the Śānti water rite up to the Ājyabhāga, with the verse The white, the black and Like the fire of this,
he offers the Ājya with the two verses.
The subsequent rites are like the Pārvaṇa.
The peace offering when the word 'fire' is uttered is completed.
The thirty-ninth section.

original: atha sarpirvā tailaṃ vā madhu vā viṣyandate tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha sarpiḥ vā tailam vā madhu vā viṣyandate tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, when ghee, oil, or honey spills out, the peace offering is mentioned there.

original: atha yatraitat sarpirvā tailaṃ vā madhu vā viṣyandati yadyāmaṃ cakrurnikhanantaḥ /
analyzed: atha yatra etat sarpiḥ vā tailam vā madhu vā viṣyandati yat yāmam cakruḥ nikhanantaḥ
translated: Then, where that ghee, oil, or honey spills out, if they dig while making a hole,
with this hymn one should offer.
That is the expiation there.

analyzed: śāntyudakam ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā yat yāmam cakruḥ nikhanantaḥ iti etābhiḥ catasṛbhiḥ ājyam juhuyāt
translated: Having performed the water for peace up to the portion of ghee, he should offer ghee with these four verses beginning with If they have made a hole digging.
The subsequent ritual of the parvan and other (rites).

analyzed: sarpiḥ taila madhu kṣaraṇa śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The peace offering of ghee, oil, and honey is completed.
The fortieth chapter.

original: atha laukikāgniḥ śālāṃ dahati tatra śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha laukika agniḥ śālām dahati tatra śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, when the worldly fire burns a house, the peace offering is stated there.

analyzed: atha yatra etat grāmyaḥ agniḥ śālām dahati apamityam apratīttam
translated: Now, when the village fire burns a house, it is not measured and not accepted.

analyzed: iti etaiḥ tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ maiśradhānyasya pūrṇa añjalim hutvā
translated: Having offered a handful of fully ripe rice with these three hymns,

analyzed: mama ubhā mitrāvaruṇā  mahyam āpaḥ madhumat arayantām
translated: Both Mitra and Varuna are mine.🔽May the waters grant me honey and ghee.
One should offer with these two hymns.

analyzed: mama ubhā mitrāvaruṇā mama ubhā indrābṛhaspatī
translated: Both Mitra and Varuna are mine, both Indra and Brihaspati are mine.

original: mama tvaṣṭā ca pūṣā ca mamaiva savitā vaśe //
analyzed: mama tvaṣṭā ca pūṣā ca mama eva savitā vaśe
translated: Tvastr and Pusha are mine, Savita is under my control.

original: mama viṣṇuśca somaśca mamaiva maruto bhavan /
analyzed: mama viṣṇuḥ ca somaḥ ca mama eva marutaḥ bhavan
translated: Vishnu and Soma are mine, the Maruts are mine alone.

original: sarasvāṃśca bhagaśca viśve devā vaśe mama //
analyzed: sarasvān ca bhagaḥ ca viśve devāḥ vaśe mama
translated: Sarasvati, Bhaga, and the Vishvedevas are under my control.

analyzed: mama ubhā dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam svar mama
translated: Both heaven and earth are mine, the atmosphere and heaven are mine.

original: mamemāḥ sarvā oṣadhīrāpaḥ sarvā vaśe mama //
analyzed: mama imāḥ sarvāḥ oṣadhīḥ āpaḥ sarvāḥ vaśe mama
translated: All these herbs are mine, all the waters are under my control.

original: mama gāvo mamāśvā mamājāścāvayaśca mamaiva puruṣā bhavan /
analyzed: mama gāvaḥ mama aśvāḥ mama ajāḥ ca avayaḥ ca mama eva puruṣāḥ bhavan
translated: Mine are the cows, mine are the horses, mine are the goats and sheep, mine are the men.

analyzed: mama idam sarvam ātmanvat ejat prāṇat vaśe mama iti
translated: This entire world belongs to me, all that has life is under my control.
Having heated the kindling wood, having wiped around the sacrificial surface,
one should then kindle the fire.

original: ita eva prathamaṃ jajñe agnirābhyo yonibhyo adhi jātavedāḥ /
analyzed: itas eva prathamam jajñe agniḥ ābhyaḥ yonibhyaḥ adhi jātavedāḥ
translated: From here first was born Agni, the all-knower, from the sources of birth.

original: sa gāyatryā triṣṭubhā jagatyānuṣṭubhā devo devebhyo havyaṃ vahatu prajānan iti janayitvā // / / //
analyzed: sa gāyatryā triṣṭubhā jagatyā anuṣṭubhā devaḥ devebhyaḥ havyam vahatu prajānan iti janayitvā
translated: May that god, knowing, carry the offering to the gods with the Gayatri, Tristubh, Jagati, and Anustubh meters. Having generated,
Be united with us in mind and in abode.
With this hymn one should offer.
That is the atonement there.

original: śāntyudakamājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'apamityamapratīttam' ityetaistribhiḥ sūktairmaiśradhānyasya pūrṇāñjaliṃ juhuyāt / 'mamobhā'
analyzed: śāntyudakam ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā apamityam apratīttam iti etaiḥ tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ maiśradhānyasya pūrṇa añjalim juhuyāt mama ubhā
translated: Having performed the Śānti water rite up to the Ājyabhāga, one should offer a handful of mixed grain with these three hymns: Not measured, not accepted, mine are both,

original: iti kalpajaṃ sūktaṃ 'mahyamāpaḥ' iti sūktaṃ dvābhyāmājyaṃ juhoti /
analyzed: iti kalpa jam sūktam mahyam āpaḥ iti sūktam dvābhyām ājyam juhoti
translated: one should offer clarified butter with the two hymns To me, O waters and For me the waters.
The subsequent rites are as in the Pārvaṇa rite.

original: tata araṇī pratāpya sthaṇḍilaṃ parimṛjya athāgniṃ manthati /
analyzed: tata araṇī pratāpya sthaṇḍilam parimṛjya atha agnim manthati
translated: Then having churned the two pieces of wood, having cleansed the sacrificial ground, he churns out the sacred fire.

analyzed: itas eva prathamam jajñe iti ṛcā manthanam
translated: The churning is done with the verse, 'From this very place he was born first' .

original: tata ājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'bhavataṃ naḥ samanasau' ityetena sūktenājyaṃ juhuyāt /
analyzed: tatas ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā bhavatam naḥ samanasau iti etena sūktena ājyam juhuyāt
translated: Then having performed the rites up to the offering of the two portions of clarified butter, he should offer clarified butter with the hymn, 'Be favourable to us, O two' .
The rites subsequent to the Pārvaṇa rite are the same.

original: grāmadāghe gṛhadāghe agniśālāśāntimaṇḍapakuṭīgośālādāghe sarvāgnidāghe śāntiḥ samāptā /
analyzed: grāma dāghe gṛha dāghe agniśālā śāntimaṇḍapa kuṭī gośālā dāghe sarva agni dāghe śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: In the case of a fire breaking out in a village, a house, the fire-chamber, the sacrificial shed, a hut, a cow-pen, or in any fire, the Śānti rite is concluded.

analyzed: śāntyudakena sarvatra kārayitrā vā ācamana prokṣaṇe bhavataḥ
translated: In all cases, the sprinkling with Śānti water and the Ācamana rite are to be performed by the person who causes the rite to be performed.

analyzed: sarvatra adbhuta sthāna prokṣaṇam gṛha grāma ādi prokṣaṇam sarvam kuryāt
translated: In all cases, the sprinkling of the place of the portent, the sprinkling of the house, village, etc., everything should be done.
In all cases, the Śrāddha rite for the manes.
'The Brāhmaṇas are satisfied with devotion' .
Thus it is said.
The Śānti rite for a fire breaking out in a village.
The forty-first chapter.

original: atha svayamagnirutthite vidyute vā patite śāntirucyate
analyzed: atha svayam agniḥ utthite vidyute vā patite śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now the Śānti rite is described when the fire rises by itself or lightning falls.

analyzed: atha ced āgantuḥ dahati evam eva kuryāt
translated: If a stranger sets fire, one should do the same.
That is the expiation there.

analyzed: śāntyudakam ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā apamityam apratīttam iti etaiḥ tribhiḥ sūktaiḥ maiśradhānyasya
translated: Having performed the water for peace up to the portion of ghee, he should offer a handful of mixed grains with these three hymns beginning with Apamitryam apratītam.

original: pūrṇāñjaliṃ hutvā 'mamobhā' iti sūktaṃ 'mahyamāpaḥ' iti sūktaṃ ca dvābhyāmājyaṃ juhuyāt /
analyzed: pūrṇa añjalim hutvā mama ubhau iti sūktam mahyam āpaḥ iti sūktam ca dvābhyām ājyam juhuyāt
translated: With the two hymns Mamo bhā and Maṃhyā apaḥ, he should offer ghee.
The subsequent rites are as in the Parvana rite.
In that fire, the heating of the kindling woods.
Having smeared the sacrificial ground with cow dung, the churning of the fire.

analyzed: itas eva prathamam jajñe iti ṛcā
translated: With the verse From here he was first born.

original: tata ājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'bhavataṃ naḥ samanasau' ityetena sūktenājyaṃ juhoti /
analyzed: tatas ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā bhavatam naḥ samanasau iti etena sūktena ājyam juhoti
translated: Then, having performed up to the portion of ghee, he offers ghee with this hymn Bhavataṃ naḥ samanasaḥ.
The subsequent rites are as in the Parvana rite.

original: vidyute dāghe gṛhe svayaṃ prakṛtidāghe śāntiḥ samāptā //
analyzed: vidyute dāghe gṛhe svayam prakṛti dāghe śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The peace rite is completed in the case of lightning, burning in the house, and natural burning.
The forty-second chapter.

analyzed: atha vaṃśa bala haraṇa bhaṅge śāntiḥ ucyate
translated: Now, the peace rite is described in the case of the breaking of the bamboo used for strength.

original: atha yatraitadvaṃśaḥ sphoṭati kapāle'ṅgārā bhavantyudapātraṃ barhirājyaṃ tadādāya // / / //
analyzed: atha yatra etat vaṃśaḥ sphoṭati kapāla iṅgārāḥ bhavanti uda pātram barhiḥ ājyam tat ādāya
translated: Now, when that bamboo breaks, the skull becomes embers. Taking the water pot, sacrificial grass, and ghee,
he approaches the back of the house.

analyzed: tatra aṅgārān vā kapālam vā upanidadhāti ā santapanāt
translated: There he places the coals or the potsherd, from the burning.

analyzed: prāñcam idhmam upasamādhāya  parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya barhiḥ uda pātram upasādya
translated: Having put the fuel on the east,

having strewn (the fire-place) around, having sprinkled (water) around, having strewn (Darbha grass) around, having placed the water-pot,🔽having anointed the clarified butter with the Paribhâṣa formula,
having offered the regular oblations in front and the Âgyabhâga oblations,
he then offers (the following oblations).

original: asau vai nāma te mātāsau vai nāma te pitā /
analyzed: asau vai nāma te mātā asau vai nāma te pitā
translated: Such and such is the name of thy mother, such and such is the name of thy father,

original: asau vai nāma te dūtaḥ svavaṃśamadhi tiṣṭhati //
analyzed: asau vai nāma te dūtaḥ sva vaṃśam adhi tiṣṭhati
translated: such and such is the name of thy messenger who stands over thy race.

original: uttamarātrī ṇāma mṛtyo te mātā tasya te antakaḥ pitā /
analyzed: uttamarātrī ṇāma mṛtyo te mātā tasya te antakaḥ pitā
translated: The last night, O Death, is thy mother, thy father is the Ender of it,

analyzed: samanda dhānaḥ te dūtaḥ sva vaṃśam adhi tiṣṭhati
translated: the one who has appointed thy messenger stands over thy race.

original: bahavo'sya pāśā vitatāḥ pṛthivyāmasaṅkhyeyā aparyantā anantāḥ /
analyzed: bahavaḥ asya pāśāḥ vitatāḥ pṛthivyām asaṅkhyeyāḥ aparyantāḥ anantāḥ
translated: Many are the snares spread out by thee on the earth, innumerable, endless, infinite,

original: yābhirvaṃśānabhinidadhāti prāṇināṃ yān kāṃścemān prāṇabhṛtāṃ jighāṃsan /
analyzed: yābhiḥ vaṃśān abhinidadhāti prāṇinām yān kān ca imān prāṇabhṛtām jighāṃsan
translated: with which thou layest hold of the races (of men), and all these living beings whom thou wishest to kill.

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśaṃ mṛtyave svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam mṛtyave svāhā
translated: Let him drive away this messenger of thine from the back of the race; let him go to the abode of my enemies. To Death Svâhâ!

original: bṛhaspatirāṅgiraso brahmaṇaḥ putro viśve devāḥ pradadurviśvamejat /
analyzed: bṛhaspatiḥ āṅgirasaḥ brahmaṇaḥ putraḥ viśve devāḥ pradaduḥ viśvam ejat
translated: Brihaspati, son of Angiras, the All-gods have given him all this world.

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu niveśaṃ bṛhaspataya āṅgirasāya svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gacchatu niveśam bṛhaspataye āṅgirasāya svāhā
translated: May he drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. May he go to the abode of Brihaspati, to Angirasa, hail!

original: yasya te'nnaṃ na kṣīyate bhūya evopajāyate /
analyzed: yasya tena nam na kṣīyate bhūyaḥ eva upajāyate
translated: Whose food is not exhausted, but increases more and more,

original: yasmai bhūtaṃ ca bhavyaṃ ca sarvametat pratiṣṭhitam /
analyzed: yasmai bhūtam ca bhavyam ca sarvam etat pratiṣṭhitam
translated: To whom this past and future all is established,

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśamindrāya svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam indrāya svāhā
translated: May he drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. May he go to the abode of my enemies, to Indra, hail!

original: mukhaṃ devānāmiha yo babhūva yo jānāti vayunānāṃ samīpe /
analyzed: mukham devānām iha yaḥ babhūva yaḥ jānāti vayunānām samīpe
translated: He who became here the mouth of the gods, who knows the nearness of the arrangements,

original: yasmai hutaṃ devatā bhakṣayanti vāyunetraḥ supraṇītiḥ sunītiḥ /
analyzed: yasmai hutam devatāḥ bhakṣayanti vāyu netraḥ su praṇītiḥ su nītiḥ
translated: To whom the gods eat what is offered, with the wind as an eye, well-guided, well-ordered,

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśamagnaye svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam agnaye svāhā
translated: May he drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. May he go to the abode of my enemies, to Agni, hail!

original: yaḥ pṛthivyāṃ cyāvayanneti vṛkṣān prabhañjanena rathena saha saṃvidānaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ pṛthivyām cyāvayan eti vṛkṣān prabhañjanena rathena saha saṃvidānaḥ
translated: He who moves over the earth, shaking the trees, with a chariot of destruction, in agreement,

original: rasān gandhān bhāvayanneti devo mātariśvā bhūtabhavyasya kartā /
analyzed: rasān gandhān bhāvayan eti devaḥ mātariśvā bhūta bhavyasya kartā
translated: The god Matariśvan, producing juices and scents, goes, the maker of the past and future.

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśaṃ vāyave svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam vāyave svāhā
translated: Let him drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. Let him go to the abode of my enemies. To Vayu, hail!

original: brahmacārī carati brahmacaryamṛcaṃ gāthāṃ brahma paraṃ jigāṃsan /
analyzed: brahmacārī carati brahmacaryam ṛcam gāthām brahma param jigāṃsan
translated: The celibate one practices celibacy, seeking the highest Brahman in the Rg verse and song.

original: taṃ vighnā anupariyanti sarve ye antarikṣe ye ca divi śritāsaḥ /
analyzed: tam vighnāḥ anupariyanti sarve ye antarikṣe ye ca divi śritāsaḥ
translated: All the obstacles follow him, those that are in the atmosphere and those that are in the sky.

original: taṃ viśo anupariyanti sarvāḥ karmāṇi loke parimohayanti /
analyzed: tam viśaḥ anupariyanti sarvāḥ karmāṇi loke parimohayanti
translated: All the social classes follow him, confusing his actions in the world.

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśamādityāya svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam ādityāya svāhā
translated: Let him drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. Let him go to the abode of my enemies. To the sun, hail!

original: yo nakṣatraiḥ sarathaṃ yāti devaḥ saṃsiddhena rathena saha saṃvidānaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ nakṣatraiḥ sa ratham yāti devaḥ saṃsiddhena rathena saha saṃvidānaḥ
translated: The god who goes with the stars in a chariot, in agreement with a well-equipped chariot,

analyzed: rūpam rūpam kṛṇvānaḥ citra bhānuḥ su bhānuḥ
translated: assuming various forms, with variegated and beautiful light.

original: sa imaṃ dūtaṃ nudatu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśaṃ candrāya svāhā //
analyzed: saḥ imam dūtam nudatu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam candrāya svāhā
translated: Let him drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. Let him go to the abode of my enemies. To the moon, hail!
The plants, the glorious ones with Soma as their king,

original: tā imaṃ dūtaṃ nudantu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśamoṣadhībhyaḥ somarājñībhyaḥ svāhā //
analyzed: tāḥ imam dūtam nudantu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam oṣadhībhyaḥ soma rājñībhyaḥ svāhā
translated: let them drive this messenger away from the ridge of the house. Let him go to the abode of my enemies. To the plants, the glorious ones with Soma as their king, hail!
The plants are the queens of Varuna, the glorious ones.

original: tā imaṃ dūtaṃ nudantu vaṃśapṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣato niveśamoṣadhībhyo varuṇarājñībhyaḥ svāhā //
analyzed: tāḥ imam dūtam nudantu vaṃśa pṛṣṭhāt sa me gachatu dviṣataḥ niveśam oṣadhībhyaḥ varuṇa rājñībhyaḥ svāhā
translated: May they drive away this messenger from the top of the bamboo. May it go to the abode of my enemies. To the plants, the queens of Varuna, svāhā!

analyzed: aṣṭa sthūṇaḥ daśa pakṣaḥ yadṛcha jaḥ vanaspate
translated: O tree, you who have eight pillars and ten wings, you who are self-existent,

analyzed: putrān ca eva paśūn ca abhi rakṣa vanaspate
translated: Protect the sons and the cattle, O tree!

original: yo vanaspatīnāmupatāpo babhūva yadvā gṛhān ghoramutā jagāma /
analyzed: yaḥ vanaspatīnām upatāpaḥ babhūva yat vā gṛhān ghoram uta ā jagāma
translated: Whatever heat there was among the trees, or whatever terrible thing went to the houses,

original: tannirjagāma haviṣā ghṛtena śaṃ no astu dvipade śaṃ catuṣpade //
analyzed: tat nirjagāma haviṣā ghṛtena śam naḥ astu dvipade śam catuṣpade
translated: That has gone out with the oblation of ghee. May it be well with our bipeds and our quadrupeds.

original: yo vanaspatīnāmupatāpo na āgadyadvā yajñaṃ🔽no'dbhutamā jagāma /
analyzed: yaḥ vanaspatīnām upatāpaḥ naḥ āgat yat vā yajñam  nā udbhutamā jagāma
translated: Whatever heat there was among the trees that came to us, or whatever wonderful thing went to our sacrifice,

original: sarve tadagne hutamastu bhāgaśaḥ śivān vayamuttaremābhi vājān //
analyzed: sarve tat agne hutam astu bhāgaśas śivān vayam uttarema abhi vājān
translated: All that, O Agni, let it be offered in parts. May we attain the auspicious boons.
Having offered to Tvastr,

analyzed: tvaṣṭā me daivyam vacaḥ  iti atra uda pātram ninayati
translated: Tvastr my divine speech.🔽Here he pours down a water pot.
Taking the fire in a potsherd, he approaches.
That is the atonement there.

original: śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā kapāle'gniṃ kṛtvā udapātraṃ barhirājyaṃ tadādāya śālāyāmupari gūḍhakarma karoti /
analyzed: śāntyudakam kṛtvā kapāla ignim kṛtvā uda pātram barhiḥ ājyam tat ādāya śālāyām upari gūḍha karma karoti
translated: Having prepared the water for peace, having made a fire in a skull, having taken an earthen pot, sacrificial grass, and ghee, he goes to the upper part of the hall and performs the secret rite.

original: śālāyāḥ pṛṣṭhe gatvā tatra kapālāni vā upanidadhāti ā santapanāt /
analyzed: śālāyāḥ pṛṣṭhe gatvā tatra kapālāni vā upanidadhāti ā santapanāt
translated: Having gone to the back of the hall, he places the skulls there, up to the heated ones.

original: prāñcamidhmamupasamādhāya parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya barhirityādi ājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'asau vai nāma te mātā' iti sūktenājyaṃ juhoti
analyzed: prāñcam idhmam upasamādhāya parisamuhya paryukṣya paristīrya barhiḥ ityādi ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā asau vai nāma te mātā iti sūktena ājyam juhoti
translated: Having put the firewood towards the east, having enclosed it, having sprinkled it around, having strewn it around with sacrificial grass, having done up to the offering of the two portions of ghee, he offers ghee with the verse, This is your mother's name.

original: 'tvaṣṭā me daivyaṃ vacaḥ' iti sūktenājyaṃ juhuyāt /
analyzed: tvaṣṭā me daivyam vacaḥ iti sūktena ājyam juhuyāt
translated: He should offer ghee with the verse, Tvaṣṭṛ my divine speech.
The subsequent ritual is as in the Parvan and other rites.

analyzed: uda pātram ninayati  kapāla ignim ca ādāya upasarpati
translated: He pours out the water pot.🔽Having taken the fire in the skull, he approaches.

analyzed: gṛha vaṃśa bhagne gṛha vaṃśa dāghe ca śāntiḥ samāptā
translated: The peace rite is completed when a house beam breaks or a house beam is burnt.
The thirty-fourth chapter.

original: atha yatraitat kumbhodadhānaḥ saktudhānī vokhā vāniṅgitā vikasati tatra juhuyāt // / / //
analyzed: atha yatra etat kumbha uda dhānaḥ saktu dhānī vā ukhā vā an iṅgitā vikasati tatra juhuyāt
translated: Now, wherever this pot, flour bin, or pan is cracked or split, one should offer there.

analyzed: bhūmiḥ bhūmim agāt mātā mātaram api agāt
translated: The earth has gone to the earth, the mother has gone to the mother.

original: ṛdhyāsma putraiḥ paśubhiryo no dveṣṭi sa bhidyatām iti // / / //
analyzed: ṛdhyāsma putraiḥ paśubhiḥ yaḥ naḥ dveṣṭi sa bhidyatām iti
translated: May we prosper with sons and cattle; let him be split who hates us.

original: atha kumbhe bhagne udadhāne saktudhānī vokhā vā vikasati tatra śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā ājyabhāgāntaṃ kṛtvā 'bhūmirbhūmimagāt' ityṛcājyaṃ juhuyāt🔽sadasi sanme bhūyāt iti saktūnāvapet // / / //
analyzed: atha kumbhe bhagne uda dhāne saktu dhānī vā ukhā vā vikasati tatra śāntyudakam kṛtvā ājyabhāga antam kṛtvā bhūmiḥ bhūmim agāt iti ṛcā ājyam juhuyāt  sat asi sat me bhūyāt iti saktūn āvapet
translated: If the pot is broken, or if the flour-bin or the pan in the water-pot becomes cracked, then having prepared the water for sprinkling, having performed the rites up to the offering of the two portions of clarified butter, he should offer clarified butter with the verse, The earth has gone to the earth.

original: 'sadasi sanme bhūyāt' iti mantreṇānyasyāṃ navatarāyāṃ saktudhānyāṃ saktūnāvapet //
analyzed: sat asi sat me bhūyāt iti mantreṇa anyasyām navatarāyām saktu dhānyām saktūn āvapet
translated: In the assembly, may I be united, with this verse he should pour the flour into another new flour-bin.

original: atha cedodanasya annamasyannaṃ me dehyannaṃ mā mā hiṃsīḥ iti triḥ prāśya // / / //
analyzed: atha ced odanasya annam asi annam me dehi annam mā mā hiṃsīḥ iti tris prāśya
translated: If it is rice, having eaten three mouthfuls with the formula, Give me food, do not injure my food,
he may then eat as he wishes.

original: atha cedodanasya 'annamasyannaṃ me dehyannaṃ mā mā hiṃsīḥ' iti mantreṇānyasyāṃ prakṣipyānumantrayate /
analyzed: atha ced odanasya annam asi annam me dehi annam mā mā hiṃsīḥ iti mantreṇa anyasyām prakṣipya anumantrayate
translated: If it is rice, having poured it into another vessel with the formula, Give me food, do not injure my food, he should recite over it.
Having eaten three mouthfuls,
then the performer or not the performer should eat.

original: atha cedudadhānaḥ syāt samudraṃ vaḥ pra hiṇomi / /
analyzed: atha ced uda dhānaḥ syāt samudram vaḥ pra hiṇomi
translated: If it is the water-pot, with the two verses, I send you forth to the ocean
having recited over it with these two,

analyzed: anyam kṛtvā dhruvābhyām dṛṃhayitvā  tatra hiraṇya varṇāḥ
translated: having made another, having made it firm with the two Dhruva verses,
there he should sprinkle water with the verse, The golden-coloured ones.🔽with the verse, The golden-coloured ones.

original: atha cedudakakalaśaṃ bhajyate 'samudraṃ vaḥ pra hiṇomi' iti dvābhyāmṛgbhyāmabhimantryānyaṃ kṛtvā udakakalaśaṃ navaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: atha ced udaka kalaśam bhajyate samudram vaḥ pra hiṇomi iti dvābhyām ṛgbhyām abhimantrya anyam kṛtvā udaka kalaśam navam kuryāt
translated: If the water-pot breaks, he should consecrate another new water-pot with the two Ṛiks beginning with 'I send you to the ocean', and make it.
'I have brought you' (Taitt. Sam. 1. 1. 1. 1).
'Firm is the sky' (Taitt. Sam. 1. 1. 1. 2).

original: iti sūktābhyāmabhimantrya navamudakakalaśaṃ 'hiraṇyavarṇāḥ' iti sūktena udakamabhimantrya kalaśaṃ ninayet /
analyzed: iti sūktābhyām abhimantrya navam udaka kalaśam hiraṇya varṇāḥ iti sūktena udakam abhimantrya kalaśam ninayet
translated: Having consecrated with these two Sūktas, he should pour water into the new water-pot with the Sūkta beginning 'Of golden complexion' (Taitt. Sam. 1. 1. 1. 3).

analyzed: atha asmin sthāne kecid śāntyudakam kurvanti
translated: At this place some perform the Śānti-udaka (consecrated water for peace).
The subsequent ritual of the Parvan and other (sacrifices).

original: udakasthālyāṃ bhagnāyāṃ vrīhyādi pūlye udakadhānyāṃ saktudhānyāṃ vā kumbha ukhāgnihotrasthālyādibhāṇḍe bhinne bhagne udakapūrṇakalaśe bhagne
analyzed: udaka sthālyām bhagnāyām vrīhi ādi pūlye udaka dhānyām saktu dhānyām vā kumbhe ukhā agnihotra sthālī ādi bhāṇḍe bhinne bhagne udaka pūrṇa kalaśe bhagne
translated: When the water-pot breaks, or when the rice and other grains in the water-pot or flour-pot break, or when the pot such as the sacrificial ladle, the fire-pot, the cooking vessel, etc. break or are broken, or when the water-filled pot breaks,

original: śāntiḥ samāptā /🔽śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā vedyāditantraṃ karoti rudramatam /
analyzed: śāntiḥ samāptā  śāntyudakam kṛtvā vedi ādi tantram karoti rudra matam
translated: the Śānti (peace) is completed.🔽Having performed the Śānti-udaka (consecrated water for peace), he performs the ritual beginning with the altar, according to the opinion of Rudra.

analyzed: pradhāna homa anantaram śāntyudakam kuryāt iti dārila matam
translated: After the principal offerings, one should perform the Śānti-udaka, according to the opinion of Dārila.
The extraordinary events are completed.

original: sa khalveteṣu karmasu sarvatra śāntyudakaṃ kṛtvā sarvatra cātanānyanuyojayanmātṛnāmāni ca // / / //🔽sarvatra varāṃ dhenuṃ kartre dadyāt // / / //
analyzed: sa khalu eteṣu karmasu sarvatra śāntyudakam kṛtvā sarvatra cātanāni anuyojayan mātṛnāmāni ca  sarvatra varām dhenum kartre dadyāt
translated: He should perform the Śānti water rite in all these rites, and employ the Ātana rites everywhere, and the names of the mother.🔽Everywhere he should give an excellent cow to the performer.
Everywhere a cow with a pot of ghee is the sacrificial fee.
The Brahmins are satisfied with devotion.

analyzed: yathoddiṣṭam ca ādiṣṭāsu iti prāyaścittiḥ prāyaścittiḥ
translated: And as prescribed, in the rites that are enjoined, the expiation is an expiation.
One should perform a Śrāddha.

original: adbhutamanteṣu yat patitaṃ tad 'agnaya indrāgnibhyām ādityāya uṣasyai svāhā' iti /
analyzed: adbhuta manteṣu yat patitam tat agnaye indra agnibhyām ādityāya uṣasyai svāhā iti
translated: In the case of wonders, what has fallen is offered with the formula, To the fires, to Indra and Agni, to Āditya, to Uṣas, svāhā.
To Samāya, svāhā.
To Bhadra, svāhā.
To Indra, svāhā.
To Abhayā, svāhā.
To the field, svāhā.

analyzed: vināyaka snapana īśāna yāga abhipaśya ete paṭhitāḥ
translated: The bathing of Vināyaka and the sacrifice to Īśāna are recited here.
Those should be performed.

analyzed: graha nakṣatra ādi pakṣaḥ sarvatra kāryaḥ
translated: The consideration of the planets, stars, etc. should be done everywhere.
There is a verse:

original: yāni deśe kule vāpi adbhutaṃ yatra dṛśyate /
analyzed: yāni deśe kule vā api adbhutam yatra dṛśyate
translated: Whatever wonder is seen in a country or family,

analyzed: sa vinaśyati jānīyāt tasya śāntiḥ trayodaśe
translated: One should know that it will perish, and its Śānti is in the thirteenth.
The forty-fourth chapter.
Thus ends the thirteenth chapter in the Kauśika Paddhati.
Now, the fourteenth chapter.

analyzed: ājya tantram  yathāvitānam yajña vāstu adhyavasyet
translated: The Ājya Tantra.🔽One should determine the sacrificial ground according to the extent of the ritual.
The altar is the sacrificial ground, and the northern altar is the altar of Agni.

analyzed: ubhe prāc āyate kiñcid prathīyasyau paścāt udyatatare
translated: Both are a little wider in the east, and higher in the west.
One should construct the altar equal in width.

analyzed: ṣaṣ śamīm prāc āyatām catur śamīm śroṇyām
translated: Six Śamī trees in the east, four Śamī trees in the buttocks,
three in the middle, half the fourth in front.
One should construct the northern altar in front of the three.

analyzed: dvis śamīm prāc āyatām ṛjvīm adhyardha śamīm śroṇyām
translated: Two Śamī trees in the east, a straight one, three and a half Śamī trees in the buttocks.
One should determine the sacrificial ground according to the extent of the ritual.

original: sambhāralakṣaṇe uktaṃ yathāvitānaṃ ca maṇḍapaṃ kārayet //
analyzed: sambhāra lakṣaṇe uktam yathāvitānam ca maṇḍapam kārayet
translated: It is said in the definition of the collection that one should make the pavilion according to the extent of the ritual.
The summer is your ground.
Having approached thus...
Do thou measure the milk-rich one.
He recites this while measuring.
And the unobstructed.

original: barhirlavanaṃ kṛtvā 'grīṣmaste bhūme' ityṛcā upasthāya 'vi mimīṣva' ityṛcā śāntavṛkṣakāṣṭhaṃ mimānamanumantrayate /

translated: He should perform the rites prescribed by the Atharva Veda, such as peace and prosperity.

analyzed: tathā cāṇakye śāntika pauṣṭika ābhicārika adbhuta śānti ādīni
translated: And thus in the Aṇakya: The priest's duties are peace, prosperity, sorcery, and the pacification of portents, etc.
The four Vedas are employed in sacrifices.

original: tathā bhārate 'paurohityaṃ pautro atharvavidyāṃ śāntiṃ kārayet' iti /
analyzed: tathā bhārate paurohityam pautraḥ atharva vidyām śāntim kārayet iti
translated: And thus in the Bhārata: The grandson should perform the Atharva Veda and peace rites, not the priest.

original: indreṇa bṛhaspatiratharvāṅgirasaṃ suśrāva svargo me'surairgṛhīta iti /
analyzed: indreṇa bṛhaspatiḥ atharva aṅgirasam suśrāva svargaḥ mesuraiḥ gṛhītaḥ iti
translated: Indra heard from Bṛhaspati the Atharva Veda, saying, 'Heaven has been seized by the Asuras.'

original: sa śāntikarmādīni jayakarmāṇi kṛtvā punaḥ svargo abhavat //
analyzed: sa śānti karma ādīni jaya karmāṇi kṛtvā punar svargaḥ abhavat
translated: Having performed the peace rites and other rites of victory, he again became heaven.

original: tathā bhārate drupadena sarvakulakṣayārthamatharvāṅgirasau yājopayājau dvau bhrātarau staḥ /
analyzed: tathā bhārate drupadena sarva kula kṣaya artham atharva aṅgirasau yāja upayājau dvau bhrātarau staḥ
translated: And thus in the Bhārata: Drupada had two brothers, Yaja and Upayaja, who were Atharva Veda scholars.
From one side, a rite was performed to destroy the entire family.
And thus in the Atharva Veda Pariśiṣṭa:

original: na haviḥ pratigṛhṇanti devatāḥ pitaro dvijāḥ /
analyzed: na haviḥ pratigṛhṇanti devatāḥ pitaraḥ dvijāḥ
translated: The gods, ancestors, and twice-born ones do not accept oblations

analyzed: tasya bhūmipateḥ yasya gṛhe na atharva vid guruḥ
translated: of that king in whose house a teacher well-versed in the Atharva Veda resides.

analyzed: tathā raghukāvye vasiṣṭhastutiḥ  athā atharva nidheḥ tasya vijita ari purassaraḥ
translated: Similarly, in the Raghuvamsa, there is praise of Vasishtha.

analyzed: arthyām arthapatiḥ vācam ādade vadatām varaḥ
translated: Then, the lord of wealth, the best of speakers, spoke these meaningful words to him, the abode of the Atharva Veda, who had conquered his enemies.

analyzed: tathā ca manuḥ śrutiḥ atharva aṅgirasī kuryāt abhicārakam
translated: Similarly, Manu, the Vedas, and the Atharva-Angirasa should perform black magic.
Similarly, Paithinasin says:

analyzed: ṛgveda ekaguṇam dānam dviguṇam ca yajurvede
translated: The gift is equal to the quality of the Rig Veda, twice that of the Yajur Veda,

analyzed: triguṇam sāmavede proktam anantam syāt atharvaṇe
translated: three times that of the Sama Veda, and is said to be infinite in the Atharvana.

original: tathā ca vārāhajyotiṣe atharvāṅgirasamahāśāntibhiḥ koṭihomāccādbhutānāṃ ca śamanaṃ bhavati //
analyzed: tathā ca vārāhajyotiṣe atharva aṅgirasa mahāśāntibhiḥ koṭi homāt ca adbhutānām ca śamanam bhavati
translated: Similarly, in the Varaha Jyotisha, the great peace of the Atharva-Angirasa and the burning of ten million oblations bring peace to the portents.

original: tathāriputrake ca vāyulakṣaṇe khaṇḍakhādye atharvamahāśāntiḥ paṭhitāḥ śamanārthāḥ /
analyzed: tathā ariputrake ca vāyulakṣaṇe khaṇḍa khādye atharva mahāśāntiḥ paṭhitāḥ śamana arthāḥ
translated: Similarly, in the Vayu Lakshana of Ripu's son, the great peace of the Atharva Veda is recited for the purpose of pacification.

analyzed: tathā puṇya abhiṣeka ādi atharva vida uktāni rāja karmāṇi ca
translated: Similarly, the royal duties described by those well-versed in the Atharva Veda, such as the sacred ablution, etc.
Similarly, in the Charaka medical treatise, there are two types of diseases.
Those caused by diet and those caused by evil.
In the case of inauspicious acts, pacification is done through the peace mantras of the Atharvaveda.

original: tathā purāṇe ayutalakṣakoṭihomādiṣu agnisthāpanaṃ gṛhasthāpanaṃ pūrṇāhutivasordhārādi atharvavede /
analyzed: tathā purāṇe ayuta lakṣa koṭi homa ādiṣu agni sthāpanam gṛha sthāpanam pūrṇāhuti vasordhārā ādi atharvavede
translated: Similarly, in the Puranas, the establishment of fire, the establishment of the house, the final oblation, the continuous oblation of milk etc. are mentioned in the Atharvaveda in the course of ten thousand, one hundred thousand, and one crore oblations etc.

analyzed: tathā ca gautamaḥ śāntika pauṣṭika abhicāraka vaśīkaraṇa ādi karmāṇi kārayet
translated: Similarly, Gautama says one should perform the rites of peace, prosperity, sorcery, subjugation etc.

original: tathā mīmāṃsāyāṃ bhaṭṭaḥ śāntipuṣṭyabhicārā ekabrahmartvigāśrayāḥ kriyā atharvavede kriyante //
analyzed: tathā mīmāṃsāyām bhaṭṭaḥ śānti puṣṭi abhicārāḥ eka brahma ṛtvij āśrayāḥ kriyāḥ atharvavede kriyante
translated: Similarly, Bhatta in the Mimamsa says the rites of peace, prosperity, and sorcery are performed in the Atharvaveda, based on a single Brahman priest.

original: tathā mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇe atharvamantrairabhiṣikastu pṛthivīṃ bhuṅkte sasāgarām //
analyzed: tathā mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇe atharva mantraiḥ abhiṣikaḥ tu pṛthivīm bhuṅkte sa sāgarām
translated: Similarly, in the Markandeya Purana it is said one who is consecrated with Atharvan mantras enjoys the earth with its oceans.

original: tathā ca pariśiṣṭe 🔽yasya rājño janapade atharvā śāntipāragaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca pariśiṣṭe  yasya rājñaḥ janapade atharvā śānti pāragaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the Parashishta🔽In whose kingdom an Atharvan who has mastered peace mantras resides,

analyzed: nivasati api tat rāṣṭram vardhate nirupadravam
translated: that kingdom prospers without calamities.

original: tasmād rājā viśeṣeṇa atharvāṇaṃ jitendriyam /🔽dānasanmānasaṃskārairnityaṃ samabhipūjayet //
analyzed: tasmāt rājā viśeṣeṇa atharvāṇam jita indriyam  dāna sat māna saṃskāraiḥ nityam samabhipūjayet
translated: Therefore, the king should especially honor an Atharvan who has conquered the senses🔽with gifts, respect, and honor, and should always perform peace rituals

analyzed: nityam ca kārayet śāntim graha ṛkṣāṇi pūjayet
translated: and worship the planets and constellations.

original: tathā mīmāṃsāyāṃ ṣaṣṭhe'dhyāye purohitādhikaraṇe ekavacanam atharvavede śrūyate /
analyzed: tathā mīmāṃsāyām ṣaṣṭha idhyāye purohita adhikaraṇe eka vacanam atharvavede śrūyate
translated: Similarly, in the sixth chapter of Mimamsa, in the section on Purohita, the singular is heard in the Atharvaveda:
One Purohita.

original: tathā purāṇe brāhmaṇāni dānāni vā'tharvavedavihitāni kārayet //
analyzed: tathā purāṇe brāhmaṇāni dānāni vā atharvaveda vihitāni kārayet
translated: Similarly, in the Purana, one should perform the Brahmana rites and gifts prescribed by the Atharvaveda.

analyzed: etaiḥ ca anekaiḥ ca vākyaiḥ vihitam atharvaveda śāntikam
translated: And this peace of the Atharvaveda is enjoined by these and many other statements.

analyzed: sarveṣām matena sa vivaraṇaḥ sarva śāstreṣu samastakeṣu
translated: According to the opinion of all, with explanations, in all the scriptures.

analyzed: tathā gṛhya ṭīkāyām mahāśāntyā sarva rāṣṭra vṛddhiḥ bhavati vṛddhiḥ ca
translated: Similarly, in the commentary on the Grihya Sutras, by the great peace, there is prosperity for the entire kingdom, and growth.

original: tathā vāyupurāṇe catvāro vedā vyāsena vibhajya hotradhvaryurudgātraṃ brahmatvamiti /
analyzed: tathā vāyupurāṇe catvāraḥ vedāḥ vyāsena vibhajya hotṛ adhvaryuḥ udgātṛ am brahma tvam iti
translated: Similarly, in the Vayu Purana, the four Vedas were divided by Vyasa into Hotra, Adhvaryu, Udgata, and Brahman.

analyzed: śāntim ca brahmatvam ca atharvaveda vihitam
translated: And peace and Brahmanhood are prescribed by the Atharvaveda.

original: tathā aṣṭādaśapurāṇeṣu brahmatvaṃ ca śāntim atharvavede /
analyzed: tathā aṣṭādaśa purāṇeṣu brahmatvam ca śāntim atharvavede
translated: Similarly, in the eighteen Puranas, Brahmanhood and peace are in the Atharvaveda.

original: tathā aṣṭādaśapurāṇeṣu rājā atharvavedena sarvakarmāṇi kārayet /
analyzed: tathā aṣṭādaśa purāṇeṣu rājā atharvavedena sarva karmāṇi kārayet
translated: Similarly, in the eighteen Puranas, the king should perform all rites by the Atharvaveda.
By the peace of the Atharvaveda for the king, there is victory.
And there is growth of the kingdom.

original: tathā brāhmaṇe 'atharvāṇaśca ha vā āṅgirasaśca' ityādi yajñe śrāddhādi karmasu /
analyzed: tathā brāhmaṇe atharvāṇaḥ ca ha vā āṅgirasaḥ ca ityādi yajñe śrāddha ādi karmasu
translated: Similarly, in the Brāhmaṇa, Atharvaṇa and Aṅgiras and so on, in sacrifices, Śrāddha and other rites.
When his speech is satisfied, the fire is satisfied.

analyzed: prāṇe tṛpte vāyuḥ tṛpyati ādi praśaṃsa vidhiḥ atharvavedasya
translated: When the vital breath is satisfied, the wind is satisfied, and so on, it is an injunction of praise for the Atharvaveda.

original: tathā bhārate bhṛgvaṅgireṇa viśvāmitro rājā brāhmaṇaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tathā bhārate bhṛgvaṅgireṇa viśvāmitraḥ rājā brāhmaṇaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the Bhārata, by Bhṛgu and Aṅgiras, King Viśvāmitra was made a Brāhmaṇa.

original: tathā bhārate bhṛguṇā pratardano rājā brāhmaṇaḥ kṛtaḥ /
analyzed: tathā bhārate bhṛguṇā pratardanaḥ rājā brāhmaṇaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: Similarly, in the Bhārata, by Bhṛgu, King Pratardana was made a Brāhmaṇa.

original: tathāṅgirasena kāśirājasya naṣṭarājyasya putraśāntiṃ kṛtvā pṛthivīṃ bhuṅkte /
analyzed: tathā āṅgirasena kāśi rājasya naṣṭa rājyasya putra śāntim kṛtvā pṛthivīm bhuṅkte
translated: Similarly, by Aṅgiras, after performing the peace rite for the son of the king of Kāśī whose kingdom was destroyed, he enjoyed the earth.

original: indramarutvatīye ākhyāne marutve varte purohitaṃ kṛtvā indrapratimo bhavasyāhave indreṇa tasya vajraṃ prakṣiptam /
analyzed: indramarutvatīye ākhyāne marutve varte purohitam kṛtvā indra pratimaḥ bhavasya āhave indreṇa tasya vajram prakṣiptam
translated: In the Indramārutavatīya narrative, after making Marutvat the priest, he became equal to Indra in battle. The thunderbolt was thrown at him by Indra.
It was warded off by the Atharvāṅgirasa.

original: tathā bhṛgūṇāṃ śāpena nahuṣo rājā sarpo ajagaro bhavati /
analyzed: tathā bhṛgūṇām śāpena nahuṣaḥ rājā sarpaḥ ajagaraḥ bhavati
translated: Similarly, by the curse of the Bhṛgus, King Nahuṣa became a snake, a python.

original: tathā bhārgaveṇa ṛcīkena sukanyāvivāhaṃ kṛtvā aśvinīkumārābhyāṃ vedābhyāsaḥ yuvā kṛtaḥ tena tau devamadhyasthāpitau yajñabhāgaṃ ca prāpitau
analyzed: tathā bhārgaveṇa ṛcīkena sukanyā vivāham kṛtvā aśvinī kumārābhyām veda abhyāsaḥ yuvā kṛtaḥ tena tau deva madhya sthāpitau yajña bhāgam ca prāpitau
translated: Similarly, after Bhārgava Ṛcīka married Sukanyā, the young Aśvinīkumāras studied the Vedas. Therefore, they were established in the midst of the gods and were made to receive a share in the sacrifice.

original: tathā janamejayasya rājñaḥ purohitena bhārgaveṇa śaunakena sarpasatraṃ prārabdham /
analyzed: tathā janamejayasya rājñaḥ purohitena bhārgaveṇa śaunakena sarpa satram prārabdham
translated: Similarly, a serpent-sacrifice was begun by the Bhārgava Śaunaka, the priest of king Janamejaya.
There, Bhārgava is the Hotṛ.
The principal performer.
The serpents were slain.

original: tathā rākṣasaśastreṇa bhārgaveṇa vasiṣṭhapautreṇa pārāśareṇa rākṣasā nipātitāḥ /
analyzed: tathā rākṣasaśastreṇa bhārgaveṇa vasiṣṭha pautreṇa pārāśareṇa rākṣasāḥ nipātitāḥ
translated: Similarly, by the Bhārgava Pārāśara, the grandson of Vasiṣṭha, the demons were slain with the weapon of demons.
The remaining ones were protected by the words of Bhārgava and Pulastya.

original: tathā pūrvabrāhmaṇe tasmādya eva sarvavit syāt taṃ brahmāṇaṃ kurvīta /
analyzed: tathā pūrva brāhmaṇe tasmāt yaḥ eva sarva vid syāt tam brahmāṇam kurvīta
translated: Similarly, in the Pūrva Brāhmaṇa, therefore, one should make him who knows everything the Brahman.

original: eṣa ha vai vidvān sarvavid brahmā yad bhṛgvaṅgirovit /
analyzed: eṣa ha vai vidvān sarva vid brahmā yat bhṛgu aṅgiraḥ vid
translated: He, indeed, who knows this, who knows Bhṛgu and Aṅgiras, is the all-knowing Brahman.

original: ete ha vā asya sarvasya śamayitāraḥ pālayitāra iti /
analyzed: ete ha vai asya sarvasya śamayitāraḥ pālayitāraḥ iti
translated: For they are the pacifiers and protectors of all this.

original: tathā saṃhitāvidhau tatra rājā bhūmipatirvidvāṃsaṃ brāhmaṇamicchedeṣa ha vai vidvān
analyzed: tathā saṃhitā vidhau tatra rājā bhūmipatiḥ vidvāṃsam brāhmaṇam icchet eṣa ha vai vidvān
translated: Similarly, in the Saṃhitāvidhi, there the king, the lord of the earth, should desire a learned brāhmaṇa. He, indeed, who knows this,

original: yad bhṛgvaṅgirovidete ha vā asya sarvasya śamayitāraḥ pālayitāro yad bhṛgvaṅgirasaḥ KauśS / iti /
analyzed: yat bhṛgu aṅgiraḥ videte ha vai asya sarvasya śamayitāraḥ pālayitāraḥ yat bhṛgu aṅgirasaḥ iti
translated: For Bhṛgu and Aṅgiras are the appeasers and protectors of all this, since Bhṛgu and Aṅgiras are the Kautsa.

analyzed: tathā svastyayaneṣu śakadhūma kim adya ahar iti pṛcchati
translated: For the Bhrigus and Angiras are the pacifiers and protectors of all this, since they are the Bhrigus and Angiras. Thus in the auspicious rites, he asks, Shakadhuma, what is today's date?
He replies, Good, auspicious.
It is said, from the start.

original: tathā ca nakṣatrakalpe kariṣyamāṇasaṅgrāmaṃ pratipadyate tena kṣatriyaḥ atharvāṅgirasaṃ purohitamicched vidvāṃsaṃ śāstravittamam /
analyzed: tathā ca nakṣatra kalpe kariṣyamāṇa saṅgrāmam pratipadyate tena kṣatriyaḥ atharva aṅgirasam purohitam icchet vidvāṃsam śāstra vittamam
translated: Similarly, in the Nakṣatrakalpa, he takes up one who is about to engage in battle, and a Kṣatriya would desire an Atharvāṅgirasa priest who is learned and the best knower of the scriptures.

original: tathā atharvāṅgiraso brāhmaṇo vā ahorātrayoḥ puṇyāhaṃ pṛcchet /
analyzed: tathā atharva aṅgirasaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ vai ahar rātrayoḥ puṇyāham pṛcchet
translated: Similarly, an Atharvāṅgirasa Brāhmaṇa would ask about the auspicious day of the two, day and night.
By what is it not conquered?
If he were to say, It should be done,
he should do likewise.

original: puṇyāhaṃ bhavati puṇyāha eva kurute prasthāne /
analyzed: puṇya aham bhavati puṇya ahe eva kurute prasthāne
translated: It becomes an auspicious day, he makes it an auspicious day indeed at the start.

original: anyatra vā vyāso bhārgavaḥ mārkaṇḍeyo bhārgavo durvāsā bhārgavaḥ śukrabṛhaspatibhṛgvaṅgiraḥ /
analyzed: anyatra vā vyāsaḥ bhārgavaḥ mārkaṇḍeyaḥ bhārgavaḥ durvāsāḥ bhārgavaḥ śukra bṛhaspati bhṛgu aṅgiraḥ
translated: Elsewhere also, Vyāsa is Bhārgava, Mārkaṇḍeya is Bhārgava, Durvāsas is Bhārgava, Śukra, Bṛhaspati, Bhṛgu, and Aṅgiras.

original: tathā yajurvede pratijñā nāma pariśiṣṭam 'hastiśalyāṃ aśvalakṣaṇaṃ āyudhāyurvedavidyā
analyzed: tathā yajurvede pratijñā nāma pariśiṣṭam hasti śalyām aśva lakṣaṇam āyudha āyurveda vidyā
translated: Similarly, in the Yajur Veda, the Pratijñā named Pariśiṣṭa, The science of elephants, the characteristics of horses, the science of weapons and longevity,

analyzed: dātavya āntarikṣa bhūmi autpāta praśamanaḥ śānti svastyayana maṅgala arthāḥ para abhicāra uccāṭana vaśīkaraṇa sammohana arthāḥ ca
translated: To be given on the sky and earth, for the pacification of portents, for peace, well-being, and auspicious purposes, and for the destruction of others' spells, for driving away, for subjugation, and for bewitching.
As many as there are, all of them are the subsidiary Vedas of the Atharva Veda.

original: atha mahābhāṣye prathame pāde śrūyate ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo atharvaveda iti catvāro vedāḥ /
analyzed: atha mahābhāṣye prathame pāde śrūyate  ṛgvedaḥ yajurvedaḥ sāmavedaḥ atharvavedaḥ iti catvāraḥ vedāḥ
translated: Now, in the first chapter of the Mahābhāṣya, it is heard: The Ṛg Veda, the Yajur Veda, the Sāma Veda, and the Atharva Veda - these are the four Vedas.
The Ṛg Veda has twenty-one branches.

original: tathā 'catvāri śaṅgā iti catvāro vedā iti vyākhyātam' //
analyzed: tathā catvāri śaṅgāḥ iti catvāraḥ vedāḥ iti vyākhyātam
translated: Similarly, it is explained that the four corners means the four Vedas.

original: tathā mahābhāṣye dvitīye pāde vibhāṣā chandasīti sūtre 'śaṃ no devīḥ' /
analyzed: tathā mahābhāṣye dvitīye pāde vibhāṣā chandasi iti sūtre śam naḥ devīḥ
translated: Similarly, in the second chapter of the Mahābhāṣya, in the sūtra vibhāṣā chandasi, there are the verses śaṃ no devīḥ,

analyzed: agnimīīe iṣe tvā agne ā yāhi iti
translated: agnimīḷe, iṣe tvā, and agn ā yāhi.
The Atharva Veda is at the beginning, and the other Vedas follow.

original: tathā nirukte catvāri śṛṅgā iti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: tathā nirukte catvāri śṛṅgā iti vyākhyātam
translated: Similarly, in the Nirukta, it is explained as the four corners.

original: tathā atharvavede brāhmaṇe catvāri śṛṅgā ityṛcā catvāro vedāḥ iti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: tathā atharvavede brāhmaṇe catvāri śṛṅgā iti ṛcā catvāraḥ vedāḥ iti vyākhyātam
translated: Similarly, in the Atharva Veda and the Brāhmaṇa, in the verse the four corners, it is explained that the four Vedas are the four Vedas.

original: tathā mīmāṃsāyāṃ prathamapāde vedādhikaraṇe atharvavedasya śākhādvayamudāhṛtaṃ paippalādaṃ maudakamiti /
analyzed: tathā mīmāṃsāyām prathama pāde veda adhikaraṇe atharvavedasya śākhā dvayam udāhṛtam paippalādam maudakam iti
translated: Similarly, in the first chapter of Mīmāṃsā, in the section on the Vedas, two branches of the Atharva Veda are cited: Paippalāda and Maudaka.

original: akṛtakā nityāḥ pramāṇaṃ vedā iti sthāpitam //
analyzed: akṛtakāḥ nityāḥ pramāṇam vedāḥ iti sthāpitam
translated: It is established that the Vedas are not created, eternal, and a means of valid knowledge.

original: tathā mīmāṃsāyāṃ dvitīye'dhyāye sarvaśākhādhikaraṇe paippalādaṃ maudakamiti atharvavedasya śākhādvayamudāhṛtya sarvaśākhāpratyayakrame sthāpitam
analyzed: tathā mīmāṃsāyām dvitīya idhyāye sarva śākhā adhikaraṇe paippalādam maudakam iti atharvavedasya śākhā dvayam udāhṛtya sarva śākhā pratyaya krame sthāpitam
translated: Similarly, in the second chapter of Mīmāṃsā, in the section on all branches, citing two branches of the Atharva Veda: Paippalāda and Maudaka, it is established that they are accepted in the sequence of all branches.

original: tathā tṛtīye'dhyāye pravargyādhikaraṇe caturṣvapi vedeṣu na prathamayajño nāma yajño'sti caturvedagrahaṇaṃ kṛtam /
analyzed: tathā tṛtīya idhyāye pravargya adhikaraṇe caturṣu api vedeṣu na prathama yajñaḥ nāma catur veda grahaṇam kṛtam
translated: Similarly, in the third chapter, in the section on Pravargya, in all four Vedas, there is no first sacrifice named Yajña, and the four Vedas are mentioned.
It is said that the four Vedas are for the purpose of sacrifice.

original: bhāṣyakāreṇa tathā atharvavedādhikaraṇe catvāri śṛṅgeti catvāro hotrakāḥ prativedamiti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: bhāṣyakāreṇa tathā atharvaveda adhikaraṇe catvāri śṛṅgā iti catvāraḥ hotrakāḥ prativedam iti vyākhyātam
translated: The author of the commentary explains similarly in the section on the Atharva Veda that four are the peaks and four are the Hotrakas for each Veda.
Similarly, in Nyāyamala, it is said that there are four Vedas.
The first is the Atharva Veda.

analyzed: pūrva brāhmaṇe atharvavedena trayaḥ vedāḥ kṛtāḥ
translated: In the Purva Brāhmaṇa, the three Vedas are created by the Atharva Veda.

analyzed: atha u lokāḥ veda ādayaḥ ca
translated: Then the worlds and the Vedas.

original: tathā atharvavede brāhmaṇe atha ha prajāpatiḥ somena yakṣyamāṇo vedānuvācakaṃ vā hotāraṃ vṛṇīyāt /🔽kamadhvaryuṃ kamudgātāraṃ kaṃ brāhmaṇamiti /
analyzed: tathā atharvavede brāhmaṇe atha ha prajāpatiḥ somena yakṣyamāṇaḥ veda anuvācakam vā hotāram vṛṇīyāt  kam adhvaryum kam udgātāram kam brāhmaṇam iti
translated: Similarly, in the Brahmana of the Atharvaveda, it is said: Then Prajapati, about to perform a Soma sacrifice, said to the Vedas: You should choose a Hotri priest who knows the Rig Veda,🔽a Adhvaryu priest who knows the Yajur Veda, an Udgata priest who knows the Sama Veda, and a Brahman priest who knows the Atharva Veda.

original: ta ūcurṛgvidameva hotāraṃ vṛṇīṣva yajurvidamadhvaryuṃ sāmavidamudgātāramatharvāṅgirovidaṃ brahmāṇam /
analyzed: te ūcuḥ ṛk vidam eva hotāram vṛṇīṣva yajuḥ vidam adhvaryum sāma vidam udgātāram atharva aṅgiraḥ vidam brahmāṇam
translated: They said: You should choose a Hotri priest who knows the Rig Veda, an Adhvaryu priest who knows the Yajur Veda, an Udgata priest who knows the Sama Veda, and a Brahman priest who knows the Atharva Veda.

original: tathā hāsya yajñaścaturṣu lokeṣu caturṣu deveṣu caturṣu vedeṣu catasrāsu hotrāsu catuṣpādyajñaḥ pratitiṣṭhati /
analyzed: tathā ha asya yajñaḥ caturṣu lokeṣu caturṣu deveṣu caturṣu vedeṣu catasrāsu hotrāsu catuṣpād yajñaḥ pratitiṣṭhati
translated: Thus his sacrifice is established in the four worlds, the four gods, the four Vedas, and the four Hotras. The four-footed sacrifice is established.

analyzed: pratitiṣṭhati prajayā paśubhiḥ yaḥ evam veda
translated: One who knows this is established with offspring and cattle.

analyzed: tathā anucarā api tad vidaḥ bhavanti
translated: And those who know it follow him.
In the four Vedas as well.
Similarly, in the later Brahmana,
The four-footed complete sacrifice is created by the four-fold Hotra.
It is established by the four-fold mantras and the Veda-versed priests.

original: bhārate sabhāparvaṇi brahmasabhāyāṃ catvāro vai brahmapārśve tiṣṭhanti mūrtimantāḥ //
analyzed: bhārate sabhāparvaṇi brahma sabhāyām catvāraḥ vai brahma pārśve tiṣṭhanti mūrtimantāḥ
translated: In the Sabha Parva of the Mahabharata, in the assembly of Brahma, four embodied beings stand by the side of Brahma.

original: pūrvabrāhmaṇe triviṣṭapaṃ tridivaṃ nākamuttamaṃ tametayā trayyā vidyayeti /
analyzed: pūrva brāhmaṇe triviṣṭapam tridivam nākam uttamam tam etayā trayyā vidyayā iti
translated: In the previous Brāhmaṇa, it is said: The heaven, the world of the gods, the highest world, that is reached by this threefold knowledge.
Therefore, the worlds beyond are

original: mahānto'tharvaṇāmaṅgirasāṃ ca sā gatiratharvaṇāmaṅgirasa ca sā gatiriti brāhmaṇam //
analyzed: mahāntaḥ atharvaṇām aṅgirasām ca sā gatiḥ atharvaṇām aṅgirasām ca sā gatiḥ iti brāhmaṇam
translated: the great worlds of the Atharva Veda and the Aṅgiras. That is the goal of the Atharva Veda and the Aṅgiras. This is the Brāhmaṇa.
Thus ends the Kauśika Paddhati.
